description:
Ordered two type of meat together with rice - roast duck and roast pork. They give you a lot of meat and rice for $8.80. The skin of the roast pork was very crispy and the meat is also tender. The sauce they pour over the meat and rice was also good too. 

Do note that this restaurant only accepts cash, and there are limited seats inside.
author: Celine K.

description:
The best thing to do when entering a Chinese BBQ place is to stare into the window for 10 seconds to look over the delicious hanging meats and then immediately go for the duck upon ordering.  It's like trying the bread/oil combo at an Italian restaurant to judge how good everything else is or a basic taco at a full service Mexican place.

Well, the duck was some of the best I've ever had in the many major cities I've tried it in.  It still had the star anise hanging onto the crispy skin as I devoured every little piece possible.  The rice plate which costs as much as an extra value meal, comes with a good amount of rice and a small mix of choy and lettuce.  We also had beef chow foon and a side of cooked lettuce.  Neither were as spectacular as that roasted duck, though.  

In Boston, we are used to cold and quick service.  Not here, they took their time to listen to what we had to say, made sure we understood clearly that it was cash only and the lady taking our order made sure I didn't overpay for a crispy noodle dish.  I'm still a little weirded out by SF culture and those who are nice to you, it's not standard everywhere. 

All of the places we could have eaten in Chinatown and we decided to go back a second night, it was seriously that good.  I loved everything about this place, it was quaint, a little bit on the dirty side and still a big enough hole in the wall where you didn't feel cramped.  As mentioned, the service was stellar and the chefs greeted us both on our way in and way out.  You can't ask for anything better.
author: Jeff M.

description:
The old Asian lady next to spoke little-to-no English but still managed to indicate following...

I was using chopsticks correctly
Her Char Siu (rice plate) was better than my Roast Pork
She was enjoying that MJ was enjoying her Roast Duck
She liked Filipinos

Five Stars!
author: James G.

description:
everything is so darn good here.

Kam Po Kitchen doesn't serve up Michelin-standard cooking, but it serves up big hearty portions of delicious Hong Kong style dishes. There are a lot of tables within the restaurant but all the tables are very close to each other. Be prepared to share some personal space! Kam Po Kitchen offers sit-down meal service or a take-out line for those who wish to bring home roast duck, soy sauce chicken or any meat of the sort. 

I have tried a number of the dishes offered here. Roast duck over rice, duck wonton soup and prawn with egg chow fun are all good choices. Everything is also inexpensive. Unlike many of the butcher shops in Chinatown, Kam Po does not skimp out on the meat. I have tried the prawn with egg chow fun dish throughout many Chinese restaurants in Chinatown, and the one here is hands down the best. 

Many of the staff members here don't speak English. Two of the female staff speaks English and provides good service though. The only thing that irks me is that the dining tables are always so greasy or oily from a lack of quality deep cleaning. This is a very popular lunch spot for locals in Chinatown. Kam Po is great for your stomach and easy on your wallet and it's definitely one of my favorite lunch spots in Chinatown! CASH ONLY!
author: Philip M.

description:
This is a no frills cash only Chinese dive and it's damn delicious!

Don't expect much table service here and don't be too adventurous either. Their menu is vast, but for a place like this - stick with the basics: porridge, noodle dishes, or rice plates.

We began with a medium serving of fish filet porridge, my families baseline for porridge these days. I thought it was delicious - it had the right consistency and was very generous with fish. It was also infused with a good amount of ginger and cilantro which definitely kicked it up a notch!

Next came the beef chow fun and Peking duck and roasted pork over rice. Hands down, the latter won. The roasted pork was awesome! We also chose to order this because we noted the hanging pig was still within the half range point (the best area). It was meaty, not too fat, and well spiced. The pork skin was nice and crisp. The duck was on the fatty side, but like good Peking duck, it dripped all its glorious juices into the rice beneath and that greasy goodness reminded me of days when I used to throw a tantrum as a child and get this or soy sauce rice as my alternative dinner. And yeah, maybe I did this a little more often than I should have....but it's so worth. The beef chow fun was pretty standard but I liked that they didn't use too many fillers (onions and bean sprouts). The noodles were also sauteed correctly and not glued together. Kudos to the chef!

To get a few veggies in, we also opted for gai lan sauteed with beef tendons. The veggies were crisp but came soaking in beef tendon sauce/broth which probably eliminated all its health benefits but sure tasted good anyway. The tendons were also large and not chewy, cooked just right.

All in all, it's definitely one of Chinatown's best casual places to grab a bite!
author: Elaine Y.

description:
It's my go to. And I love it. Know what you want and you'll be stuffing your greedy little face before you know it. 
I'm a scrambled egg (runny) kinda gal and in my humble opinion it's the best in Chinatown. Super hearty and generous portions. I get it with flat noodles and shrimp. Not on the menu but the hostess knows the deal. The soups are HUGE and enough for two. Same for porridge. I'm not complaining. 
My dad always gets the curry which has loads and loads of green pepper which is super sweet and crunchy. 
There's not much time for fussing around - expect to sit down, have (free) hot tea slapped on the table and to order within about 5 minutes. Honestly I don't think there's better value.
author: Poppy C.

description:
This is a dive, a genuine hole in the wall.  With a capital D, capital I, capital V, capital E.  This no frills spot on the edge of Chinatown is known for its BBQ  and roasted Chinese meats. It's totally a quick, cheap eats spot.  

Arrived here because I had a real craving for wonton soup.  So much so that I couldn't proceed any further with my day before satiating my craving.  I've been here for take out of their roasted meats, as well as their beef chow fun.  The chow fun here is always nicely wok fried, and the noodles never clump or stick together. 

I heard this place served very generous portions, so that piqued my interest.  You know the saying though, "The proof is in the pudding".  Well, my response to that has always been, "Serve up the pudding!".  Show me!  Prove it to me!  And not with words.  Talk is cheap...Well, they did.

I was served a huge bowl of roasted duck with wontons and rice noodles, for just $8.00 pre-tip.  The massive portion of roasted duck was very meaty and moist.  Most importantly, unlike many noodle joints that literally drown their meats in the broth, Kam Po perfectly "floated" their meat atop a massive mound of rice noodles.  This kept the skin of the duck perfectly crispy.  This was worth the entire dish, my friend.  

The won tons, filled with pork and shrimp were fine. 

The amount of rice noodles were literally ginormous.  In fact, I would've preferred 50% less. Did I just say that?  Yes, simply because rice noodles tend to absorb liquid like a sponge, and by the time I finished only about 20% of the dish, I was left with gloppy rice noodles, and barely any remaining broth.  However, if you like huge portions, this is for you.

Again, this is a DIVE.  If one desires to dine here, one must remember that a nice ambiance is obsolete.  While I was here, an elderly Chinese gentleman was literally yelling on his phone in Chinese during the entire course of my lunch.  The other elderly Chinese customers also seemed perturbed.  However, this apparent soliloquy seemed to go completely unnoticed by the staff.  Just another day here, it seems...
author: Lori N.

description:
If you're looking for a cheap and good meal for two this is the place to go. If you're a clean freak, this may not be for you. They have a pretty good spread on their menu from soups to noodle dishes and bbq items.
We ordered the combo plate with roasted pork and roasted duck and both were so good! One plate was big enough for two hungry adults to share. The roasted pork had crispy skin and no foul pork odor that we've had at other Chinese bbq restaurants. It was so juicy and flavorful. The plate also had roasted duck and this was by far the best roasted duck I've had in SF! The crispy skin was the best part for me. :)
author: Jane C.

description: No frills, just straight up good food! Cash only please!! Grab a table and order yourself a bowl of duck noodle soup, skip the wontons. You'll thank me later.
author: Lizzy S.

description:
On the outskirts of Chinatown, right before the Broadway tunnel brings you to another neighborhood.  Totally worth the hike because there is just so much delicious meat at such a reasonable price.  A very unpretentious place, where office workers can eat beside construction workers.

Roast Pork: The bubbly crispy exterior is simply amazing!  The meat and fat underneath isn't quite fall part though.  It's firm to the bite, but not too tough.  The whole thing is really good with a little of the chili oil that's on the table.  Only disappointing thing was the inconsistency of the crispy skin; it seemed my table mates got more crispy skin on their plates.
 
BBQ Pork: The highly marinated end pieces are the best.  The large leaner pieces are good too, with a nice balance of flavoring.  Wasn't a fan of the fattier pieces since they didn't absorb the marinade as well and the fat seemed tougher than the fat in the roast pork.

Lo Mein: More exciting the white rice.  No flavoring or sauce, but that's ok given how intense the meats are.  Stuck together a bit though.
author: Adam B.

description: {Cash only} We came to Kam Po because they open early. The Chinese bbq entices you as it hangs in the window. We needed a place to eat before we caught a flight back to Houston. With us being used to the central time zone, eating Chinese bbq at 9am wasn't as odd. The woman working the restaurant seems to always be in a hurry. She talks fast and moves fast even though we were one of two tables there. You're offered a glass of water and a glass of hot tea. The hot tea is perfect for the cooler SF mornings. We ordered the two bbq meat option w/rice: roasted pork and roasted duck, bbq pork w/egg noodle soup, and a beef chow fun. The portions are huge and the food is cheap. The Chinese bbq was all delicious. Crispy skin on the roasted pork, the duck was juicy and not dry, the bbq pork wasn't overly sweet and not dried out as well. It's definitely worth a stop if you're in Chinatown. A lot of bang for your buck.
author: Lanha T.

description: Yummy. The cold boiled chicken is really similar to kainan chicken. I really like it.
author: Michael N.

description:
Note to self: do not come at 7:20 cause they'll lock the door and lock your booty outside the door. Typical Asian restaurant who holds strongly to their hours (7:30pm).

Portions are large, price reasonable, cleanliness iffy and services fast. 

Be ready to order right when you sit. This lady is like a lighting ball that flashes from table to table. If you don't have your orders ready, then she'll be running away to serve another table.

Duck was fatty and yummy. It's difficult to cook a duck wrong, but I only wish the skin were crispier.

West lake soup... not good at all, not what I wanted nor what I expected. The flavor profile on this one is all wrong and off... even the color.

Stir fry pea sprout, a huge plate with loads of msg on top. It's good, but the flavor is still a tab bit off.

Plain egg noodle soup, by far the best of the night. I think this is what they're known for; noodle soup. The noodles were cooked perfectly; the soup was nice and clean; the veggies were crispy and pairs well with the noodles. 

Tip: come before 7:20 or don't expect to even get into the door. For 2, keep at top 2 rice or 2 noodle dish unless you're looking for left overs for the next day
author: Rosemary T.

description:
A delicious spot to get your grub on. It's a little different than your typical restaurant in that the tasty meats are hung up for you to see but hey it makes it easier to point out. The menu it's vast but straightforward, I opted for the fried pork over rice. 

The pork over rice was amazing and the portion sizes were hefty. I wouldn't have imagined getting such a good deal for the quality, taste and large portions. 

The service is pretty good. My server was patient and was quick to answer my questions as I normally bombard people with my thoughts. She quickly took my order and promptly returned with my meal. 

Final and important note, this location is cash only. My general impression is that most of this area prefers cash only. 

Definitely, will return next time I am in the area.
author: Juan Carlos H.

description:
My bf loves hainan chicken, so one day we were on yelp searching for this specific dish and we decided to walk to this place to try it out.

This place was very dirty, but the food was really good. Unfortunately, every time we go here since they don't have hainan chicken. They have something similar called Chinese chicken.

My bf is addicted to this place, we go here almost every weekend to get his Chinese chicken with extra ginger. The to go line is actually more expensive than dining in or calling for to go. So we just call in now order to go. I like the roast pork.
author: Kimberly D.

description:
I never write reviews while I'm still out of town and i always end up writing reviews a few days after i get back home but we're currently waiting in a long line for boba so here it goes:

Dont go to Kam Po if you want a nice dining experience. Actually, dont go to Kam Po at all if you are looking for any kind of dining experience bc there really isnt one!  Well, except we had a funny experience...

We tried ordering the roasted duck & bbq pork and i couldnt explain to our waitress who did not speak english.  I pointed to roasted duck and bbq pork on the menu but i was trying to explain that we did not want two separate plates but that we wanted one combo plate with both the duck & pork.

Lucky for us, there was another table who ordered exactly what we wanted so i pointed my finger at their plate and told her thats what we wanted and she said "OHHHHHHH WOASTED DAK & FARFEQUE FORK COMBO!" 

The roasted duck was arguably one of tbe best I've ever had.  Super juicy, full of flavor, and most importantly: ZERO GAMEYNESS.  The BBQ pork was very good also but I've had comparable pork at other places but the duck here is almost in a class by itself.

Unfortunately the customer service is not all that great, the restaurant is not all that clean, and i don't know how long this place will hold up but i hope it stays open long enough for people to try their roasted duck...
author: Jang N.

description:
Lol @ the reviews griping about customer service. I mean, bitch, what did you expect? 

Like, it's 2018. You should know you ain't gonna get cloth napkins and indoor voices in a Chinatown establishment. You're lucky that she even brought you the tea. 

Anyways, I love this place. 

Super fast service, and efficient.

And I don't even speak Cantonese properly but that waitress was like that one aunt with RBF that actually loves you deep down.

If you were drawn in by the BBQ, get a BBQ and rice combo. You could even be extra fancy and get half and half roast pork/cha shu. So damn good.

I dunno if it's the same in English but she'll give you a choice between leaner or fattier cuts of pork. 

I'd come back.
author: Andrew C.

description: A great place for bbq chinese food. Huge portions for what you pay for. Little room to sit and It may not be the cleanest place for sit down to eat. I take out is probably the best way
author: Derek L.

description:
If you can get over the dried pieces of food on your utensils, layer of unidentified oil on top of your scalding hot tea, and other cleanliness question marks, this place is pretty darn solid for hole-in-the-wall Chinese food. Just don't grab the underside of the table with your bare hands to pull yourself closer to it. 

Wonton soup, rice plate with roasted pork were pretty straight forward, just tastier than most. Maybe I lucked out with super fatty pieces of pork, but the white pieces weren't dry. A feat, when it looks like the hanging pig from which they cut your meat looks like it's been there for a while. 

Maybe that's it. It looks like just another Chinese food place, but they have lots of customers.
author: Sheewon B.

description:
CASH ONLY!!!

An amazing value for authentic chinese food and the best you can get in SF (saying that because this place would be just average in LA). This place has large portion sizes for cheap. My boyfriend and I spent $15 on two dishes and had lots of leftovers to bring home even though we eat a looooot:

Dish 1: Porridge! With duck and preserved egg. We got the large and it was huge, but primarily lots of porridge and not much duck/egg. I still loved it and felt the porridge itself had its own subtle, comforting flavor. I didn't like that the duck had bone in it - was hard to eat.

Dish 2: Two items with rice - we got the roasted pork and hainan chicken. Both were good and tender, but I wish they had actual hoisin sauce and soy sauce for hainan chicken available. They had typical soy sauce and chili oil, but it's not the same.

Overall, great chinese food for cheap.
author: Elvi T.

description: Ok, I feel bad for giving this review 3 stars in the past. I ended up coming back and getting the Chicken Chow Fun (~$6.50 ish). It was pretty good. Much better than the mushroom chicken dish I ate earlier. I was able to make three meals out of this dish! I think I will come back here in the future since the food is sooo cheap.
author: Kristina M.

description: This place is bomb. I don't think the guy chopping everything up spoke English but we were able to communicate just fine by pointing! We got a huge portion of roasted pork and another huge portion of BBQ pork for less than $15. The skin on the roasted pork was so crunchy and delicious. The BBQ pork was perfection. We also got a side of white rice and cabbage. So delicious. Cash only!
author: Taylor P.

description:
If you're looking for cheap but delicious roast duck or pork this is the place to go. You can get a giant plate of meat with rice for only $6.50. 
The menu can be somewhat daunting, I believe there's around 140 items, but if you stick with what you know you'll be fine.
Might not be the cleanest place or the friendliest service but it adds to the character.
author: Taylor B.

description: Came here around 10:30am on a cold gloomy day looking for some comfort food. We ordered a Hainanese Chicken and Rice dish as well as a Roast Duck Wonton Noodle Soup bowl. The wonton soup bowl was a generous portion size, with a large amount of roast duck and several large fresh tasting wontons. The Hainanese Chicken was tender and the green onion topping was flavorful. Both were excellent and at a very good price. The restaurant also served complimentary hot tea. Service was efficient and the restaurant was clean. Plenty of indoor seating. Parking can be difficult to find however. Overall definitely worth a visit.
author: Tina D.

description:
Cheap noodle soup place that definitely hits the spot when you're battling a massive hangover. Cash only!

I've been here a few times and my personal favorites are the Beef Tendon Noodle Soup w/Egg Noodles ($6.95) and Beef Chow Fun ($5.50). The portions are huge and is it enough to feed me 2 meals!

I'm looking forward to coming back to try their porridge with some Chinese Donuts. Yum!
author: MyTien P.

description:
Great place for Chinese BBQ! I purchased a few items to go on a Sunday afternoon, and it wasn't too busy around 4pm. I tried:

-Roast Duck: Super flavorful, and they marinate their duck well since all the pieces of duck have flavor. I also loved the crispy skin, and the duck wasn't super fatty- highly recommended!
-BBQ Pork: Great version of BBQ Pork, but I liked the one from New Golden Daisy slightly more since I believe they use more wine. However, this version has a great sweet undertone, and I loved the sticky exterior- recommended!
-Poached Chicken?: I'm not sure what the English name for this style of chicken is, but the skin is white/yellow, and it's not roasted. The version here was also really good, and very flavorful- recommended!

I will definitely be back here for more Chinese BBQ! The BBQ chef is not the nicest, but their other staff were really nice. Parking in this area is the most difficult part about coming here- with all the construction, spots are extremely limited. You'll likely need to circle for a while to find a street parking spot. Plan to come with another person so that they can double park while you run in!
author: Amy D.

description:
Awesome takeout roast duck and pork. No English or credit cards allowed. We pointed, paid, and tried to be friendly and were met with some deadpan looks that will stay with me. I almost felt...unwelcome. I stupidly mentioned that we had found them on yelp and we had come all the way from LA to try their duck, and the look they gave me made me feel that I had just pissed all over their grandmothers grave. Ok, so not friendly but the food...

Awesome; we ordered a half duck and a half pound of roast pork for about $25. Both so very good, my mouth is watering thinking about it. The pork skin was crispy and delicious, even cold. 

We took our loot to the hotel room and snacked over the course of a few hours. At no point did it turn and not taste absolutely amazing. Can't wait to come back! Awesome meat for a great price.
author: Kyung E.

description: I have a very mixed opinion of Kam Po that ultimately leans negative. While my roast duck was delicious and moist, my husband's was dry and his wontons had a very unpleasant taste. The stained plastic dishes and sticky tables made the overall atmosphere poor. If the food had been excellent, we could have overlooked that. Unfortunately, we had a bad experience and would not return.
author: Marie S.

description:
Kam Po Kitchen is a Cantonese restaurant that is outside the tourist circuit in Chinatown but it looks any other restaurant in the heart of Chinatown with various BBQ meats hanging from the window. The menu is your typical Cantonese style which means it a gazillion choices ranging from wonton noodle soup, porridge, rice plates and pan fried noodles to curries and snacks.

The BBQ meats in the window looked good so I decided to get a 2 Item with rice ($8.30) combo to-go and went for the soy chicken and duck. Payment was cash only. I got a huge container that was filled to the brim with good quality cuts of both chicken and duck. I mean their serving size is almost double of what you will get at Yee's which is in the heart of Chinatown. The duck here actually had some meat on the bone and did not consist of all fat that you get elsewhere. I've come back here a couple of times and the quality has been consistent across visits. I haven't tried anything from their huge menu but if it is anything like their BBQ meats, I think it would be really good. Kam Po Kitchen gets a thumbs-up from me.
author: Ahmad J.

description:
I read all the reviews and my family and I planned to visit this establishment while vacationing in San Fran. We were all glad we did! The food was so delicious and the price for each dish is ridiculously cheap! 

I recommend the BBQ pork, roasted duck, shrimp fried rice, and combination chow mein!

We will definitely be back when in town!
author: Bianca G.

description:
During my family's quick stay in San Francisco, it became our purpose to find great Cantonese food. Online Kam Po had great reviews, in person it looked like any other restaurant in Chinatown. It had the roast duck decorations and the jam packed dining room. Our eyes grew larger than our stomachs when we saw that most plates were under $6. 

Cue the order for bbq pork, chicken chow mein, fried rice, bbq short ribs, roast duck, Mongolian beef, and kung pao chicken. Everything was succulent but maybe a tad heavy on the salty side. I feel like I gained 10 lbs in one meal but I couldn't stop. Even my family the picky eaters were in love with this place. 

My only cons were that the Mongolian beef was more onions than beef and don't expect to have your own table. We shared ours with other customers. The restaurant can fill up but we didn't mind. 

This location is a bit off from Chinatown which helped us find parking as well. I did notice a lot of customers ordering different variations of their noodle soups. They looked and smelled delicious. Hopefully someone else has reviewed them.
author: Cam M.

description: Neighborhood eateries. Prices are reasonable and taste like home cooking.  Most of the diners are people who live in the neighborhood. They have soup, noodles, rice plates and entrees.  It's the same people who has been working here since I moved back to the city.  I think I remember the waitress when I used to have dinner with the family on vacation.  They do tons of take outs!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Kam Po has been consistently my favorite restaurant in Chinatown. It's rarely crowded, the service is friendly and, most importantly, the food is REALLY good.

This small eatery specializes in roasted meats, namely char siu (BBQ pork), roasted duck and roasted pig (with the crispy skin). My favorite dish is the BBQ pork won ton noodle soup. It's the only place in the world where I enjoy won ton noodle soup, because they give you such big portions of everything for about $7.

The char siu is phenomenally good, and I'm very picky about char siu. You can choose if you'd rather have a fatty or lean cut. I always choose lean, and it's still tender and moist, not unlike a fine Texan brisket. All meats can be taken to go by the pound for home consumption.

I usually only come here when my folks are in town, mostly because I don't eat out often. The kind woman who works here somehow remembers us and always treats us well.

I recommend Kam Po to everyone looking for a delicious but affordable bite in Chinatown.
author: Keane L.

description:
TL;DR - Cheap, tasty, filling. Don't expect to be treated like royalty, and no, the customer is not always right. CASH ONLY

If you are the kind of person that only cares about how tasty the food is, this place is for you.

If you like paying as little as you can for said tasty food, this place is for you.

If you think that customer service is the most important part of a meal, please avoid.

Get any of the bbq items, but I recommend the duck and the pork. I've basically never had a bad item here.
author: Crystal Z.

description:
1. Delicious Cantonese bbq: duck was tender. Just slightly dry maybe because it was the last batch of the day

2. Casual environment. The space gets crowded and tight. Had trouble moving among the chairs, maybe I need to either lose some weight or lower my food consumption 

3. Decent portion for two people to share. Great value.
author: Eileen H.

description: Quality-wise cannot compare to what's in HK, and it's weird how they use wide rather than thin noodles with wontons. But they do give you a LOT of food, so you're guaranteed to leave full.
author: Mike L.

description:
I grew up in the neighborhood and ate here often as a kid - without knowing better.  This is still a great place to fill your stomach, but this "restaurant" is glorified fast food for dirt cheap.  There's the staple selections of Chinese BBQ items hanging in the front as well as cooked items from the back kitchen.  

I ate here with my mom recently, and I can't recommend this place as an adult.  First, Kam Po has anywhere seating with no host/hostess.  Be prepared to elbow/jockey for position against elderly folk who know that the rule is make-your-seating-anywhere-there's-an-opening.  Be prepared to sit with random people, whether you like it or not.  Once you grab a seat, you will have to wait to be served if other customers are more aggressive than you.  There is one waitress for the entire restaurant.  Your table may or may not be bussed when you sit.  Have fun ordering from the impatient waitress.  Good luck with refills of tea or tap water.  Don't be surprised if you see vermin.  Yes, I saw a dead rat on the floor in plain sight.

On the positive front, food comes out fresh and hot, and it still tastes as good as it did when I was a kid, hence 2 stars.
author: Don L.

description:
Kam Po Kitchen is the perfect place to grab a delicious and cheap dinner. The restaurant offers a variety of different meats to go with their soups, rice plates, and porridges. 

I highly recommend getting the Roast Duck and BBQ Pork Rice dish. The portion size is very large and filling, and I would suggest either sharing the plate with another person or being prepared to bring back some leftovers. The meats themselves are very well-cooked and super flavorful, but the best part about the dish was that it was less than $10.

Do note that this place is quite no-frills, so keep your expectations for the service low and just come here for the great food!
author: Yuan J.

description:
I LOVE this place. 

It's very convenient to call your order in ten minutes prior, illegally park, then run in to grab your bags of enough food to survive for the next two days, all
for something like $20! 

My go-to items are their chow fun, roast duck, roast pork, and wonton soup.

Sweet customer service goes a long way, too.
author: Camille L.

description: My brother took me here because he knows how much I love BBQ delicacies! Oh man, delicious! We had the oh so delicious barbecued roast pork/roast duck (which sold out shortly after we ordered ours), prawns with salt & pepper, and water spinach with preserved tofu. The roast pork was so crispy!! Mmmmm. There's so much on this menu that you'll be sure to find the Chinese dish that you're looking for! And the prices are not too shabby at all! My parents have been here as well so it's a family fave. Will definitely be coming back for more!
author: Monissa W.

description: Every time I go there to eat they always serve me better bbq pork there. The service is really good
author: King Hong C.

description: Pretty good roast duck and BBQ Pork that's similar to several spots in Oakland's China town.  A little bit of each (but enough for a a meal) came out to $9 out the door which by SF standards is excellent. You can order to go or eat in the restaurant itself which seats I'd say around 30 ish people.
author: Rod M.

description: This is a hole in a wall type of restaurant but that's usually where you can find the most authentic Chinese food! We got to San Francisco and were craving some good Cantonese food and found this spot. You really get a lot of food for the money (7 dollars for a large plate of meat and rice) and the food was really good.  You just can't expect great customer service but we didn't walk in with that mindset so we walked away very full and satisfied.
author: Rongling Y.

description: This gem is located outside of the busy tourists area. No one speaks English, the floor and tables are dirty, but the food was phenomenal! We ordered the shrimp wonton, yum!!!! The duck was to die for! And the fried rice and delicious. Best of all: we only spent $17!!!! It is dirt cheap, especially by San Fran standards!!!
author: Frances R.

description:
DO NOT COME HERE. YOU WILL NEVER WANT TO PAY MORE THAN 10 BUCKS FOR ROAST DUCK AGAIN​. The chow mein was also pretty amazing. I wish we got more stuff because​ their menu has an absolutely​ insane spread of dishes (I think we counted like 100+ items). I'm​ coming back here whenever I'm in the city. Great place to eat after day drinking. Cash only though but almost everything is so reasonably​ priced you could put yourself and your date in a diabetic coma for 40 bucks.


I've since returned (while sober even) and the food was still great. The roast pork is also fantastic, same with the fried rice with with scrambled egg and shrimp ( get it with the gravy)
author: Matthew W.

description:
Food is heaven! I had preggo craving so caught a uber here. I slurp down their beef stew wonton soup on 5 mins and ordered a rice place with 2 bbq items to go and half duck ohhhh and half lb of beef tendon. Don't judge me who doesn't love a skinny girl that can eat? Lol

Cash only. 

Customer service was ok. The chef/butcher was mean, I actually wanted some cuttlefish too he said I have to buy the whole thing or nothing at all  I know I got a big appetite but I can't eat that much now... overall good experience. Brings back childhood memory like 15 years ago when I lived in CT and used to do laundry with my mom across the street and eat here to wait for our laundry. Awwwww
author: Kris J.

description: Great place came here from OC. I got half and half duck and pork with rice. Big amount of meat fast service.  You have to look past the ambiance here. The most important thing here is the food and it's awesome.
author: Dimitry J.

description:
This is gets busy during lunchtime or else you have to stand there and wait. The hot food to go line is decent.
The menu prices is reasonable . I get the combo - duck with bbq pork over rice and sometimes, I get the roast duck wonton rice noodles. Come and visit soon
author: Jsphn T.

description:
I will admit, for value and convenience Kam Po cannot be beat! They were open at 9:30 am on a Saturday when I woke up in a daze with a hankering for noodle soup. Their congee was only $3.50 and the roast duck and wonton noodle soup about $7. I mean, geez, we were stuffed with a total check amount of less than $12! For these reasons, I do recommend Kam Po and will probably be back...only when it's the only option available.

The preserved duck egg and pork had good flavor but the pork had that weird off taste of lower end Chinese restaurants. The duck was good but the noodle soup and wontons were otherwise lacking in flavor.

Great stop to stop by when you're looking for a quick, cheap bite, otherwise there are definitely other options nearby.
author: Christina L.

description:
This week, I came down with a cold and a sore throat so I wanted to get something simple and soothing. I decided to go for some porridge because this place was close by and they serve sampan porridge. I came with a friend and we were seated immediately in the middle of the restaurant. We ordered the sampan porridge, the frog porridge, and the curry beef over rice. 

The sampan porridge was the first dish to come out and it was pretty large. I'd say there was enough porridge for roughly five small bowls in the big bowl that it came with (it seems to be what they classified as a medium, which is very generous, especially for $3.90).  

The curry beef over rice came out next, and then finally the frog porridge came out. I ordered the frog porridge mostly because I never had frog in porridge. The bowl that the frog porridge came in was of equivalent size to the sampan porridge, which means that we had the equivalent of ten small bowls of porridge to eat, along with the curry beef over rice (the sampan porridge only had one size (medium), while we also got the frog porridge in medium size for $5.10).  

Now, this is probably one instance where I should have checked the pictures of the porridge on Yelp to get a feeling of the sizing because when everything came out, I didn't know if we were going to be able to finish this. I must emphasize again that the portions are very generous here, and in retrospect, I think we should have just ordered one bowl of porridge instead of two. We were hungry, but not ten small bowls of porridge and a rice plate hungry. 

Anyways, the Sampan porridge contained assorted seafood, and a generous helping of peanuts to top it off as seen in the picture. I was honestly a little surprised to see little slices of squid in there. The curry beef was delicious as well. I was also pleasantly surprised by the frog porridge and its deliciousness, and the only thing that could have made this dish better was if they stripped away all the bones beforehand cooked with the porridge, but that's probably asking a bit too much. We managed to finish all three dishes in roughly forty minutes, although it was a bit difficult finishing the porridge due to the sheer size of it.

Overall, my assessment of this place is solid four, and I came away from this experience very bloated and satisfied. As I sit here writing this review, I could feel myself feeling a bit better after the large helpings of the porridge. The only thing that could be better about this place is if they took credit cards, but it is what it is. Now if you skipped all the way down here and didn't read any of the literature preceding this sentence, all you need to know is that there are very large helpings of porridge at a very reasonable price; that's my one takeaway from eating here.
author: Nelson X.

description:
honestly yall idk why people be trippin over service quality. the nonchalance is kinda just a part of the Chinese food culture and adds to the authenticity. Besides the service was fine when i went. The workers were eating when we came in to sit, but server still came to serve us and took our order and etc. 

Anyway, I LOVE THIS PLACE. I was raised in Hong Kong and this place totally brings back memories. If you want authentic taste, this is it. If i had to show someone what i usually eat in hk, id take them to this place. Andddd this is what they call "best value". you get a good amount of food for the price you pay, and its so tastyyy! Total GOOD DEAL.

I got the roast duck rice noodles ($6.25). The soup was amazing (the magic of MSG, i think LOL this assumption is not verified but it tasted like it). I was stuffed afterward. Honestly i was so happy the entire time i was eating. I WOULD DEFINITELY COME BACK.

and remember, CASH ONLY.
author: Jen K.

description:
Minus 2 stars for the food excluding the bbq items. The service wasn't too good either. But I guess for the price, you can't really expect much. 

Singapore Fried Noodles - 1/5 no flavor to it, just oil taste and literally all noodles.

Congee - 3/5 Not bad tbh, 

Stir Fried Noodles - 2/5 No exact name for it 

4/5 for the duck, octopus and roasted pork . Definitely tastes better than the places we have up in Seattle but they forgot  the pork skin when they gave us roasted pork. Kinda awkward considering we had to ask for it, when it should've came with it... We were given the back part of the duck, so there wasn't really any meat on it, and there was no plum sauce that came with it???
author: Carol T.

description:
The price is amazing. You can't really find cheap Chinese food anywhere else. Some of the entrees need a little more or less salt, but I'm not complaining at the price!

They always serve tea in a cup that gets really hot. If you want water you have to ask for it. It's also cash only, so be prepared for that.
author: Brad C.

description: Great pricing and it tasted like homemade Chinese, but better! The roast pork belly was really good and had a really crispy skin, definitely the best part. The roast duck was also delicious. We also had seafood tofu clay pot and the beef stew noodle. Everything hit the spot after a nice long walk. We'll be back when we're in town again!
author: Clifford M.

description:
one of the most authentic Cantonese kitchen I've been so far.
this place (in terms of ambiance) is a real basic Hong Kong style hole in the wall eatery. 
so, the focus here is the food.
I had the Herbal & Pig Liver Soup & Roast Duck and Roast Pork over Rice.

if you don't speak any Cantonese, just pretend that you're a tourist somewhere in Hong Kong being stranded in alleyways somewhere in Mong Kok, Yau Ma Tei or Sam Shui Po.

big menu, generous portions, hearty and delicious.
I really like this place. 

by the way, it's cash only.
author: Rudy H.

description:
Yes, it's cheap, and the portion is huge and the food tastes okay but I tasted a lot of MSG in the food.  

Also, the restaurant needs to pay more attention to the cleanliness.  The table smelled like an old rag and it really made me lose my appetite.
author: Phyllis K.

description:
I have been eating at this place since I was a child and it has never disappointed me. If you're looking for good portions, cheap price, and good food, this is the place to go. 

If you're looking for a spacious and clean restaurant however, this is not the place to go. It is your typical hole in the wall (ish) Chinese restaurant where people come to eat and leave, but it's always busy so you know it's good.

The BBQ, wonton noodle soup, rice noodle soup, fried noodles... everything. Everything is good.
author: Lauren J.

description:
Best roast pork I've ever had (better than Hong Kong too)

Sometimes I'll just look at pictures and reminisce about the good times when I had it

Thank you Kam Po
author: Vi T.

description: Big portion. Yummy Roasted Duck, Roasted pork, Soya source chicken, porridge. It is very delicious. The restaurant was so simple but the taste is equivalent or better that Hong Kong.
author: Natalee R.

description: Prices are great! Had a generous portion of roast pork, rice and cabbage for $6. When you eat there they also offer tea and soup.
author: Goldy C.

description: This is your Chinatown BBQ place, good BBQ, good portions, bad service. For large plate of rice and BBQ is $6, and everything else is reasonable. Another order of BBQ is $5 so you know. The BBQ is quiet good for the price, but don't expect gourmet fancy. It will get you full and keep you wallet full. The waitress seem very busy so don't expect getting your check quickly, just go up and hand it to them. It is also close to the Broadway tunnel so expect it to be noisier with the faster cars going through. Prepare to share a table and eat.
author: Tony C.

description: This a great place to eat traditional Chinese BBQ. I love to order the combo plate: half bbq pork and half roast duck rice plate. They give large portions of food for a low price. They've been around for at least 30 years serving the community, got to appreciate how they keep their prices low too!
author: lydia m.

description:
Ordered roast duck and rice to go ($7.50).  Service was fast.  Duck was absolutely delicious - just the right amount of saltiness and fat.  Rice was way more than enough.  

I originally wanted 2 meats and rice but the man behind the counter didn't hear me well and I didn't bother to correct him once I saw how much duck I was getting and how good it looked.

Will definitely be back!
author: Siv L.

description:
HK style BBQ is a must for me when I hear of a place that does it right! 

My boyfriend introduced me to this little gem tucked away in the corner of SF's Chinatown. I ordered the half and half roasted pork belly and roasted duck while my boyfriend had half and half roasted pork belly and char siu. 

Even though I was ordering in Cantonese, there was still some mix up in the orders. One of the waitress spoke extremely fast and gave us double the portion of meat rather than half and half. There was another waitress who was more patient and asked us if we wanted "lai tong" which is the free soup that usually comes with BBQ meals.

The soup came first. It was carrots and leafy greens in a clear pork bone broth. Even though the description isn't that appealing, I'd still encourage you to try it out! It's very light and clear tasting and the carrots add sweetness to it. 

I knew our roasted pork would be good the moment I saw it hanging near the butchering station. The pork skin was roasted to perfection and was extra crispy, and the flavor was consistent throughout the pieces of it! The pork belly was fatty enough for it to melt nicely with the rice. 

The roasted duck was not bad, but I had better. My boyfriend didn't enjoy his char siu as much as he thought he would. Overall, the meal came out to be ~$20 for food enough for 2 meals (we both took our food home for another meal). Roasted pork belly was definitely the winner though!
author: Alice L.

description:
This was my first time here, and I ordered the duck wonton soup and chicken fried rice. First off, probably the best sized portions for the price in the city. The fried rice was awesome, but the duck was cold and the soup was 3/4 rice noodles. I want to come back for another dish, because I really want to like this restaurant more than I do. My review is
Flexible to be changed.
author: Ross S.

description:
Extremely great value for money. Kam Po is slightly out of the way from the main street of Chinatown. I was there after the lunch rush, so no problem getting a seat.

Got a two item combo- roast duck and bbq pork over rice $9. I was amazed at the portion. It was huge. Thankfully, i was hungry. You also get a complimentary bowl.of soup with your meal. definitely value for money.

I asked for duck breast and lean pork- which was what I got. Bonus point. Taste wise, it was on the bland side. The duck wasn't crispy - the skin was soggy but the bbq pork had a nice flavor. The tiny hole  in the wall place also appeared to be clean. No greasy table, which is A++

They have a variety on the menu - wanton noodles,  claypot rice and stews, as well as stir fried noodles. Definitely give this place a try.
author: Reese D.

description: Old school Cantonese deli.  Portions are huge.  Not a lot of staff so be patient.  Had bbq pork, preserved egg and salted pork porridge and beef noodles.  BBQ prom was v fresh and tender.  Too bad there were burnt bits. Unpretentious and I'd definitely visit again.
author: Kam L.

description:
Pure heaven. Delicious, authentic, cheap - Chinese BBQ at its best. The prices are so...1980s. I don't know how they can possibly find margin in a $6 rice plate with a healthy - wait, maybe UNhealthy - serving of meat, but they seem to have been in operation for a long time, and will no doubt continue to thrive. Good news for all of us! Nom nom nom.

Oh by the way, skip the soups. Not good at all. I may have just found their margin!
author: Kristen S.

description:
If you want to dive into the Chinese culture and surroundings, you must come to Kam Po to eat. We first came here about 10 years ago and have been waiting for the day when we would come back to eat here. It is exactly as I remembered. 

It's a little intimidating when you first walk in here. The customers are mostly local Chinese and a few others who have braved the parking and the streets to try out their food. Don't expect 5 star dining or service. This is a no frills place - you come in, sit down, order and eat. Cash only, by the way. 

We stayed a total of 5 days here in San Francisco, and of all the places we've eaten, this is the one we talked about the most. We had their roast duck, roast pork, pork fried rice, shrimp fried rice, shrimp wonton soup, and their Chinese broccoli. Everything was delicious! For a party of 6, we only paid $57. Most, if not all of their dishes are $6-$8.

After returning from our trip, we were craving Kam Po food, so we ordered from our go-to Chinese restaurant, and nothing comes close. I guess we're going to have to wait for another trip to SF for a visit!
author: Anna D.

description: Nice little roast duck and pork restaurant. Roast duck wonton egg noodle soup is grub. The garlic pea sprouts is really tasty. Roast pork is just average. It's a tiny place but service is fast. They only accept cash.
author: Andy V.

description: We walked a fair distance to grab a whole duck here. So glad we did! Line was out the door even at 5pm Christmas Day. We ended up getting the last duck hanging in the window. We felt bad for the few patrons behind us, but there was plenty of other good food available. The duck was amazing. The broth that comes with it was so full of flavor!!! It was the kind of place that looked like they hadn't changed a bit in all the years it's been open. Why mess with perfection?
author: Jennifer D.

description:
While not to the same extent as other parts of the city (hello, Mission), Chinatown has seen its fair share of changes over the years.  Unfortunately (for me), it seems that a lot of those changes have involved the restaurants my relatives and I used to frequent.  Great Wall, Pacific Court Cafe...all gone.  Thank goodness Kam Po is still around though.  It's been a while since I've been back, but my first trip here was over 20 years and they're still going strong!

Stepping inside, Kam Po likely won't impress, save for the tasty looking rack of roasted pork, ducks, and chickens next to the counter (https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kam-po-kitchen-san-francisco?select=GOlu69zPbWbawS0Moe9L2g)  The place is somewhat small, the floors aren't exactly spic-and-span, and the tables have obvious signs of wear and tear.  However, the menu and, more importantly, the food do not disappoint.  The range of offerings may not amaze, but the quality, as well as the cheap prices, definitely stand out!

-- HAINANESE CHICKEN WITH RICE...$5.55
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kam-po-kitchen-san-francisco?select=IMKRS_R8gTerP666h8K6Vg)
Such a large portion for such a tiny price!  The chicken was meaty, tender, and moist and they certainly didn't skimp on the garlic sauce (poured on top rather than on a separate dish).  Plus, there was a lot of pickled vegetables too!  As good as everything was though, I wish the rice itself had a stronger taste of chicken and ginger to it.

-- TWO BBQ ITEMS WITH RICE - Roast Duck and Roast Pork...$8.30
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kam-po-kitchen-san-francisco?select=ZZTE_asvtu5sg-Ilq7tgzQ)
Compared to my go-to for Chinese BBQ (Cheung Hing), Kam Po holds up pretty well!  While some of the skin could have been crispier, the cut of Roast Pork was fairly thick and didn't have a ton of fat on it.  As for the duck, it was just as good as what I had as a kid - very juicy, luscious, and oh so tender.  Plus, the sauce they pour on the meat and rice is so delicious!

Admittedly, had I been on the fence with how many stars to give, I likely would have been a little more generous simply because of all of the memories I have from coming here as a kid (it's been a family favorite ever since my grandfather had moved to Chinatown).  However, I can honestly say I didn't have to in this case.  Sure, I can see why some might not be as enthused as I am, but we've never had any problems here and the food (and value) more than warrant the four star rating.

Thanks, Kam Po, for the delicious comfort food and trip down memory.  Here's to you guys sticking around for another 20+ years!
author: Mike L.

description:
Was really, and I mean REALLY, looking forward to roast duck. Expectations were high thanks the four stars this place has here on yelp and also cause the roast ducks hanging by the front window made it seem legit. 

We ordered the roast duck wanton noodles ( turned out to be soup) and roast pork and rice. Soup and wanton were flavorful. I wish there were meatier pieces of duck. The bbq pork was all fat and scarce on meat. So all in all, ate a ton of carbs here. 

Service was friendly hence the 3 stars. Also the noodles were pretty good tho not what I came for. And so the search for good roast duck continues.
author: Joanne N.

description: CASH ONLY. Don't go there without CASH. CASH ONLY CASH ONLY! I hate walking into restaurants to find out it's cash only, so I hope you read this before you go there. A total hole-in-the-wall gem, there's nothing foo-foo about it. We went there for the duck and the duck only. Okay...we ordered the green beans w/ garlic because we needed something green to make ourselves feel like we were eating somewhat healthy. Very tasty, the service is normal service in a place like that. Go and eat the duck!
author: Samantha G.

description:
Been here a few times already for their roasted pork and Chinese BBQ pork, and it's really good! Possibly the best around Chinatown San Francisco. 

Service is a whole another story, they are really rude, and be ready to be aggressive if you want to order something because the other Asians around will cut in line and not care even if you been waiting.  

Overall long story short, service is horrible but good is great and price is decent. And also they only accept cash just like many other places in Chinatown.
author: Christopher G.

description:
Depends on the day. Today I got 2 meats with rice: BBQ pork and some kind of chicken. I think I ended up choosing some sort of special chicken because it ended up being $11 (still, tons of food), but everything was great. The bbq pork was super crispy today and chicken was flavorful. 

The last time I came the BBQ pork wasn't as crispy, so I think it really depends on the day/time you get there and if they pull it out fresh.
author: Michelle T.

description:
It was our first time coming here, so our server helped us out a little bit. She immediately told us that they're famous for their duck. And that they're one of the cheapest restaurants in the city. So while I was in the bathroom, she somehow convinced my friends to order 5 dishes for the 3 of us. We had plenty of leftovers to take home but somehow those 5 dishes came out to only be $40 before tip. Incredible. I'm used to the food scenes in NY and DC, and the Chinese foods that I found there were not this cheap while tasting this good. 

It is cash only, so be sure to bring some. It's also a small place, so it's better to come a little off the busy lunch and dinner times.
author: David K.

description:
Appears to be an authentic Chinese restaurant. 

We had the following for lunch:

Century egg porridge - 4 stars. I've been looking for hearty Cantonese 'zhok' for some time and this hit the spot. It was not too salty and the pork was seasoned just right. Real comfort food in cold weather. 

Roast duck rice - 3 stars. The roast duck was not bad although I think I've had better elsewhere in the city. 

Roast pork noodles - 2 stars. The roast pork had a thin smooth crust which wasn't what we were looking for. I guess we envisioned the dim sum roast pork version with the crackled skin. The noodles were very dry and the cabbage was unfortunately not well-cooked. 

I wanted to like this place since it came with a bit of hype but the roast meats did not live up to expectations for a roast meats restaurant. But portions were huge and very good value for money. I saw a neighbouring table having egg horfun and may try that next time. 

Cash only.
author: Lindt C.

description:
A traditional Cantonese / Hong Kong style restaurant in Chinatown. 
We only ordered two items, and we couldn't finish everything.  The portions were HUGE.  One of the good things about small traditional cantonese restaurants is they always give you a bowl of complimentary soup. 

Note - if you are looking for a clean and comfortable place for dinner, this place probably is not for you.  

1- shrimp with veggies - the gravy was just okay.  BUT the portion was huge, it had good amount of shrimp and veggies.  I wanted to have a lot vegetables, so it worked out for me. 
2- Two BBQ items over rice -  the roasted pork and duck were so delicious. I don't mind eating this dish everyday.
author: Rachael C.

description: Like all things prices goes up but this place still offers one of the best chinese bbq in town at a reasonable price. Remember this is a place to get fed for a cheap price so don't expect fancy surroundings or service. My usual is a big plate of roast duck and crispy roast pork over rice for $8.30. Easily good for two people. Beef Chow Fun was $5.95 which usually goes for 8 to 11 bucks elsewhere.  Remember old people and blue collar workers are indicating of good plentiful food at a very reasonable price.
author: Laurence C.

description: This place is how San Francisco use to do it! A local no frills cash only Chinese place with reasonable prices and good portions. I had wonton noodle soup for $4.25. And I was reasonably full afterwards. Where can you get a meal in San Francisco for less than 4.50? Granted there is virtually no service,decor, or hipsters around but this was fine for me. I've been looking for a place where I can get decent meal for under 10 bucks and I finally found it. I'm not saying the food was life-changing-but it was wonderful for the price point. And this certainly a place that I will be back.
author: Robert C.

description: Not a hygienic dining experience as they scored below 90 on healthy inspection.  We stopped in here for a quick lunch which it is not. They only have 2 waitresses and the place was packed. We had to wait for the menu and to order. The portions are generous but the food isn't the best quality. Truly can be described as a greasy spoon. Certainly our noodle dish was ful of oil. My water cup was dirty so I went without liquids with my meal because you can't find a waitress. My roast pork didn't taste fresh.  Hubby even sad he wouldn't return.
author: Ry T.

description:
This restaurant is the real definition of a hole in the wall. It looks run down, there's no huge sign that grabs your attention, the tables look shabby, and yet... there's the amazing prices, the feels-like-home comfort food, and unpretentious eating!

Located in Chinatown, don't expect great customer service or amazing English. It's not that they're rude or anything, but servers will definitely cater to Chinese-speaking customers first and will give them faster service!

Your meal starts with a complementary chicken and vegetable soup. It's very simple, designed to warm your stomach and clean your palate while eating. The menu is a bit overwhelming? There are so many different rice plates, soups, noodles that all I can say is... just pick what your heart desires and you'll probably enjoy it LOL. Prices are very CHEAP. I would say most items are ballpark $5-$8 and the portions you get are worth like twice the amount of food you paid for. Go here if you're trying to get the bang for your buck!

TIP: portions are large so order a rice dish if you want to take it to go. Otherwise, share the noodles with someone because it gets pretty soggy and oily. Definitely not something you would want to take home if you can't finish it.
author: Lizzie P.

description: Definitely can't beat a $4 bowl of shrimp wonton noodle soup for lunch on a cold rainy day.  The wontons were near perfect and the portion was plentiful.   Noodles were cooked perfectly and have that "al dente" crunch that is the epicenter of great wonton noodles.  The broth was flavorful, but not quite the best I've ever had.  Though the waitress had limited English for dine-in, she was really nice.
author: Patricia N.

description: Super big portion. I got rice with Char siu, but can't finish it. Would love to try beef one in summer.
author: Raydolph Z.

description:
This is the taste of HK I've been searching for...
I must admit, food in SF is much more authentic old HK style compared to LA. But this place has really exceeded my expectation!!! Large portion too. The server with the mullet has the service of fine dining restaurant to my surprise. I give it 5 stars and 4 thumbs up!! (2 from my husband)
author: Gigi K.

description:
Disappointed.

This is truly a great place for a fast bite if you order anything from the window... but if you get something fancy like the clay pot or even the noodles, make sure you have over 45 minutes to wait!

The food was just alright. It didn't have that wow factor I was really hoping and even borderline expecting from a local Chinatown joint. We ordered the duck, the pork, the clay pot. The duck noodles were pretty good but the duck was mostly fat and the skin was not crispy. The pork was practically chewy and drenched in watery sauce. The clay pot took over 45 minutes and was undercooked... I feel bad taking my parents there ON VACATION!

The service was like any Asian restaurant and the cleanliness likewise.
author: Linda S.

description:
Kam po kitchen may look a bit rundown on the outside (and inside.) but the food is quite good and decently priced. A group of 8 of us were originally planning on eating at Lai Hong Lounge, but after we found out the wait was over an hour, no one wanted to wait. Kam Po Kitchen is conveniently located a block away! 

They serve a variety of authentic cantonese dishes with large portions and reasonable prices. Although a bit on the oily side, I like their huge menu. They have everything including but not limited to: jook (porridge), many different types of noodles, clay pots, clay pots with rice, duck, chicken, pork, whatever you can think of they probably have it! :) 

A great place for lunch. I'm pretty sure they take card but don't quote me on that.
author: Annie Z.

description:
Kam Po Kitchen is famous for their Hong Kong foods. Their chicken and ducks are juicy and delicious. I always come in to get their beef and egg rice. Their egg is so smooth when you mix it with the rice. 

1 word. Delicious!
author: Andy L.

description: Like being stuck in a 90s time warp in the best way possible. Huge portions, amazing food. This place reminded my parents of the kind of food they used to eat when they first came to America, both in quality and in price. They don't have many Chinese restaurants like this any more.
author: Danielle Q.

description:
Authentic BBQ pork place in the outskirts of Chinatown, tender juicy and fatty cha siu on rice for only $4.99, generous portions
Also got the egg shrimp rice noodle which was just as good at $5.99
Can't beat the price and quality here for awesome authentic Cantonese food just like back in the old days in Hong Kong
author: Arcadian B.

description: My husband and I came here after seeing all the great Yelp reviews and it didn't disappoint. We got in around 3pm and it wasn't packed, but wasn't empty. Service was a little slow, but we weren't in a rush after walking up from Union Square. A nice leisurely late lunch was what we wanted. Portions were super big, which made sense why it was all families and groups besides us. This is the only congee I've ever had that tastes like my Aunt's arroz caldo. It would be exactly like my Aunts if I could still see full rice kernels and if the skin was still on the chicken. Be careful when you order roast pork, it is the crunchy lechon style pork hanging by the counter, not the BBQ style pork in the front window. That is what they call BBQ pork. I ordered the roast duck noodle soup, which came as expected. I wasn't a big fan of the dumplings, but the duck, broth, and noodles more than made up for that. We had so much food leftover, we decided to take it home for dinner. Great value and super good.
author: Mabel J.

description: Wow very very good food. This is extrmly traditional so if you are looking for Americanized this is not it. But if you want to feel transported to China go experience the best Chinese food I have ever had!!!!
author: Sarah W.

description:
Kam Po doesn't have the most exciting interior and decor but makes up for it by having food that doesn't suck. It's a small restaurant giving you an intimate setting and a view of all the meat hanging from hooks and being chopped.
The menu is too big, sometimes it's bad having too many options. You can try to narrow it down to what you want like porridge, noodle dishes, rice dishes, bbq meats etc or go with some of their more exotic options like duck feet dishes.
Food here is fairly good overall and the prices are so affordable. The food here is so varied and prices are so cheap that you can come here frequently without having second thoughts.
BTW, the lady may pick your dish for you if you seem unsure about what you want.
author: Roman S.

description:
Boss lady does not play here, you better know what you want before sitting down.  We don't even ask for menus anymore, ain't nobody got time for that!  Been coming here the last two decades since they opened.  My uncle said they remodeled the interior last year, still looks the same to me.  We order the usual roast duck/BBQ pork rice plates, and boss lady hustles over with a pot of tea on our table and voila!  Often times, there's also soup on the house.  Within minutes, plates of food arrives, and everyone digs in as if we've been famished for weeks. 

I've also seen her chop up the meats for take-out; she does it all I tell ya!  The chefs are inside cooking and wrestling with gigantic woks, ensuring your food comes out super hot & fresh.  Watch out Martin Yan j/k lol.  This place is definitely a hole-in-the-wall if you want some awesome Chinese food.  Not only is it cheap, you can feed the entire family and still bring leftovers home for lunch the next day.  Everyone goes home happy with a fuller tummy.

P.S.  If you order any clay pots, order immediately, as they take longer than roast duck or any other rice/noodle/vegetable dish.
author: Christine R.

description:
Wow!  I have come here four to five time now and am never disappointed.  I usually get the roast duck and crispy pork over rice, which comes with a bit of cabbage.  The portion sizes are insanely large!  For 9 dollars, the amount of food i got could legitimately feed a family of four.  Not an exaggeration.  I felt like I got 3-4 pounds worth of total food.  The meat is really tasty, and the sauce the butcher pours over everything is very savory.

The butcher is a really legit looking Cantonese guy that wields his massive blade with great efficiency while appearing lackadaisical and chatting up the locals. Pretty cool local feel inside.  Not many tourists/non-locals to be found.
author: Patrick J.

description:
Mediorce chinese food.
 That tasted bland nothing specail.
Friend told me it was his favorite resturaunt, I was not impressed at all.

Sorry William!!!
author: Anthony M.

description: Holiest hole in the wall. Makes me think of Macau. They only take cash. The noodles are fresh and homemade. I ordered the roasted duck wonton soup. The wonton was decent but not to my liking. The duck was generous and flavorful. There were pieces of cabbage in it. They ran out of chicken feet which made me sad. I also got the BBQ duck and pork over rice. The portion was insanely huge. It was a ton of food for such a small small price. The food tastes as good as Macau-so incredibly authentic and delicious. I will have to come back and bring the whole gang.
author: Elle R.

description:
One of the best Chinese food I ever have. Hand down for the grilled duck. Add a fried agg then you meal will.be perfect! !
Generous portion and friendly service. 
Also the taste was authentic! 
Highly recommend and definitely come back!
author: Sea P.

description: Chinatown and SF in general is undergoing a major construction boom, as a result many moms and pops businesses like this one are either going out, or are changing their business model.  This is one of the last of the dying breed, in terms of good quality Cantonese/Chinese food in Chinatown.  They do a good job on Cantonese rotisserie.  Most items are under $10.  When I come though I like to ball out a little bit, so I get the rotisserie combo rice plate, but instead of regular chicken I ask for free range, and instead of regular roast pork I ask for the belly ribs, the best part of the roast pig.  This sets you back $13, but it's enough food for two people, and pretty delicious.  If you haven't done this place do it soon, like I said they're quickly dying out!
author: Jackson Z.

description: The bbq pork is still the way to go. I know their roast pork is supposed to be famous but at Saturday lunchtime it was not great - dry meat, hard skin (not crispy hard, but hard hard). The wonton soup with roast duck was okay. Good wontons. Okay roast duck.
author: Jean K.

description:
Ahhh Kam Po, a childhood favorite from my Chinatown days. I used to come here all the time as a kid, even after dentist appointments. I'd be numb from Novocaine yet I'd still shovel roasted duck and rice into my face. In  my opinion, it is still one of the best Cantonese roasties shops in SF. 

It's cheap. Ca$h only. It's small. It's a dirty hole in the wall. If there's a line, it moves quickly. Helps immensely if you speak Cantonese, but if not the waitress usually can figure out what you want or need. 

Although I grew up with the roasted duck and rice, I've grown to love roasted duck over lo mein. The sauce from the duck mixed into the cabbage and noodles just does it for me. Salty, a little sweet, fatty, umami goodness. I also really like the complimentary bowl of MSG soup they give you. Yea, I call it MSG soup. My folks have called it that since I was a kid and to be honest, that's pretty much what it is. 

I was recently able to take 2 friends here and they thoroughly enjoyed it as much as I always have. Glad to have others enjoy a childhood favorite.
author: Susy C.

description:
The food: OH MY GOD THIS IS THE BEST CHINESE FOOD I'VE EVER HAD. My boyfriend (who's Chinese) says it's "delicious", and he's usually pretty picky about what he deems good authentic Chinese food. You HAVE to try the duck. It's juicy, tender, and the skin just melts in your mouth.

The place: When eating in Chinatown, you need to have expectations of how the seating and restaurant will be. The meat is hung sizzling and gleaming behind the windows, and don't worry, there aren't any flies or bugs swarming around. The meat is only in the window a short while before being pulled down for an order. 

There's plenty of seats but it is a small place and the tables do feel crowded. I'd suggest ordering to-go and enjoying your food in the comfort of your home or hotel room. The service is fast and friendly.
author: Jayme D.

description:
Flip to the back page and order one of the rice dishes. For the extremely fair prices (mostly $5.10), the portions are gigantic. I love the roast duck on rice, which comes with some cabbage and an entire plate of rice. You really can't go wrong with any of the bbq options. If you stay to eat, you get soup as well.

Service is very quick whether you take to go or eat in, though there is often a lineup at the front for togo orders, don't make the mistake of trying to order it without waiting in line. If you go in to eat by yourself, expect to share a table. If you are seated near the take out counter, expect customers to be temporarily putting their belongings on your table trying to recollect themselves before they leave to head out, because the restaurant is quite crowded and there really isn't anywhere else to do that.

The wait staff are busy so the best tactic is to put the money on the table so it's ready to go for the bill. Sometimes if they recognize you, they don't even bring you a menu, probably assuming you know what you want, so you have to be ready for that too. 

Of course the service isn't that great and the interior isn't the cleanest - what do you expect from a Chinese restaurant with such reasonable prices? I love coming here for quick 20min meals.
author: Elisa L.

description:
As far as I can tell, the roast duck I got at Kam Po was a faithful interpretation of the duck dish iterated upon and canonized several centuries ago in China. In other words, it was hella good.

SF is blessed with many a cheap and tasty restaurant - but Kam Po edges out the competition with borderline uncompetitive prices and non-soul-crushing wait times. 

More and more people are starting to flock to this restaurant and its giant, glistening pieces of poultry hanging by the window. Regardless, I'll be back for more of that dank duck meat.
author: Dian J.

description: Don't simply judge on their decoration because you would be amazed by the food quality-everything is so good!!!! Just a tip: the noodles are a bit dull. Not as good as their rice.
author: Annabelle L.

description:
CASH ONLY

This is one of my favorite spots for cheap Chinese food! Don't expect anything fancy or the service to be overly friendly and attentive. Yes the server throws menus at you when you sit and you might have to flag them down if you want something but it's all part of the local Chinatown experience. It's more about good cheap food in large quantities.

Ordered the porridge with preserved egg ($3.50). It was served in a massive bowl and was enough for 2 people by itself. Personally I LOVE this dish. It feels so homey and filling. I took my friend who had never had preserved egg before and he really didn't like it so it's definitely an acquired taste.

Ordered the roast duck in wonton noodle soup ($7) but unfortunately 10 minutes into making it they told me they didn't have roast duck anymore and asked if roast pork was fine. It wasn't really the best alternative but it was still good too. The soup broth and wontons really made up for it. You get this giant bowl enough for 2 people on its own!

Overall go for the food and prices not the service.
author: Linda X.

description:
This is my go to spot for crispy BBQ pork and roast duck. They do roast duck extremely well. The bites are juicy and tender and never seems to get dry. It looks like they pour some sauce or oil over it to make it even more moist. 

Don't expect service to be anything great. They get you the food and that's all that matters.
author: Victor N.

description:
This corner joint brought me straight back to memories of delicious Catonese food in my grandma's kitchen. The smells, the food, the service was exactly what I needed to combat my homesickness from Vancouver for a good hour. 

With dishes at $5.95, the experience is what you'd expect - NO FRILLS, JUST GOOD FOOD. 

Note: CASH ONLY. 

Food: 
1. Tomato beef chow mein: 3/5
- Not as good as the one at Sam Po and it was a little too greasy. 
2. Lettuce and fish ball soup: 4/5 
- The flavor was on point and the fish balls were yummy. 
3. Duck chow main: 4/5
- The duck was so good!! Slid right off the bone and had wonderful flavor.
author: Emma W.

description:
Came by to grab some roasties the other day. I think this joint is considered more North Beach than Chinatown! ...if the walk is too far from any of the Chinatown garages/streets, just grab a ride from a rideshare! (Uber/Lyft)

Despite a queue at the door, the line moved quickly. Ducks are now priced by size with varying prices depending on the qualitative size... The "Large" duck is now ~$22...not sure how they would define a "Large" vs. "Small" duck... 

The duck was surprisingly very meaty, juicy and flavorful despite being rather pricey!

The BBQ Pork was decent, especially at $5.75/lb.

...notice how they don't use the register to enter sales, and don't fully close the till... I wonder if they pay tax?!?
author: Derek S.

description:
It is cheap for sure but you get what you pay for.  Food was okay but cheap.  We got salt and pepper prawns, roast duck, cod with Chinese broccoli, American broccoli with garlic sauce and bbq pork fried rice.  

Duck was greasy and unimpressive.  Waitress tried to push the half duck.  Thank god I didn't get it.    Prawns was tasty but overly oily.   Same with fish.  Western broccoli and fried rice was decent. 

I give it 3 stars for the price and speed of service.   Won't be back any time soon and definitely not for dinner again.  


Place feels not clean and there is no service to discuss - typical Chinese fast food service.
author: Lei H.

description: The restaurant is small and crowded, so we decided to order take away and find a good view to enjoy our lunch. The price is super cheap! I ordered roasted duck, char siew and roasted pork with rice, only USD 15, and that's totally can feed 3-4 pax!
author: Caster T.

description:
Fairly cheap. Big portions. Quick service! Always packed! So not really great for big groups unless you're willing to wait..

Came in today with my family (party of 10) around 2:30pm and there were no tables open so we waited a good 20-25 minutes before a table opened up. The staff was very nice and quick to let us know it'll be a while until we were seated which was no problem because only half of us were there first. 
--Minus 1 star for all the people who came in after us and seated themselves at random tables instead of waiting to be seated.--
By the time the rest of the party was there it only took us about 5 more minutes until we were seated.

Onto the food... We decided to do family style dinner, so we ordered wonton soup, seafood tofu soup, salted fish fried rice, pan fried house noodles, beef chow fun, roasted pork belly, Garlic Chinese broccoli, garlic water spinach and fish with sweet corn over rice, all to share amongst each other. Everything was really good and our tummies were satisfied! The dish that stood out the most to me was the fish w sweet corn! It sounded weird at first, but don't knock it til you try it!

Obviously, since they sell fresh af Chinese bbq in store as well, we had to buy some to bring home for family dinner! Sadly they didn't have oxtail.. But we ordered roast duck, roast pork, bbq pork, pork intestines, chicken feet, &soy sauce chicken. When we got home tonight, we had a feast! Ate all that with side of baguettes & soy sauce, Vietnamese style! 

This is always my family's go to lunch spot when we're in Chinatown SF. We'll be back soon!
author: Lihz P.

description: Real authentic Chinese restaurant. Cheap price but the food is really good. I would say to try it out and make sure to bring cash cause they don't accept creditcarfs
author: Reyzell M.

description: Really good Chinese BBQ (char siu, roast park, roast duck). Their other dishes are really good too and very reasonably priced. Highly recommended!
author: howie f.

description:
Yes, the ambiance is less than stellar.  Yes, the service is not friendly or smiley, but I'm not paying $5.50 for a HUGE order of house chowmein with shrimp, bbq pork, chicken, probably some beef, bok choi, mushrooms and onions for the ambiance or service.

The food is awesome.  If you like noodles, you will like this place.  If you don't like noodles, stop reading my review, I don't really want to help you out.  If you like noodles but you just aren't in the mood for noodles, that's cool, you may continue reading.

The meat is pretty good quality and fresh.  There is a butcher knife wielding tactician working every type of meat you can imagine that is hanging from the various meat hooks.  He has a weird mole on his face with a few 7 inch hairs growing from them.  It looks gross, but in Chinese it is good luck.  Again, I'm there for the food, not for what people look like.

The portions are big here.  The value is amazing.  If there is a line to eat there, don't worry, tables turn over fast.  Do not go in with an expectation of great service.  It is usually tough to find courteous service in chinese restaurants, especially casual ones, and especially in chinatown.  I do not mean any of this in a racist way.  I'm just trying to prepare your expectations, so you don't get bent out of shape after your visit.

Do not take a first date here, it is not romantic.

Everything on the menu looks good.  Give them a try.

Cash only.
author: Ty C.

description:
