Classic Chinatown! I didn't know places like this still existed! (Certainly not that I've seen Seattle). Everything on the menu is ~ $7 or less. Cash only. Giant portions. They speak Canto. There's hanging roast meats (duck & pork) in the window. So many soup noodles. 

Came here for dinner seeking some roast duck. We left stuffed with duck, noodles, bitter melon, BBQ pork (char siu), wontons... The roast duck over rice is a good deal. Not only does it feel like you're served half a duck, but it's also really tasty! The flavor seemed pretty great and the meat was juicy.  The skin wasn't super crisp and on the fattier side, but I kinda like it that way. You can also get the roast duck in a bowl of won ton noodles - you get a lot of duck and wonton dumplings, but the skin isn't crispy.. the addition of won ton dumplings (they're just ok, a little starchy and dense) isn't worth soggy duck.  

Char siu (BBQ pork) was definitely homemade and not cloyingly sweet - which I really appreciated. It also isn't bright red like you might find at other restaurants. What you end up with is a natural looking savory BBQ pork, with a hint of sweetness. It's also a bit fatty. Yum!

Veggies - the garlic green beans aren't as garlicky or salty or fried as other places, but it's a simple dish. It's still a bit oily, so I don't know if you actually feel healthier for eating these vegs.  The bitter melon was pretty good though - if you enjoy bitter melon. I found it pretty mild and simply seasoned here.
author: Lydia N.

description:
To me, Kam Po is exactly what you would expect in any Chinatown. It's a bit off the beaten path, and seemed to house more locals than tourists (aka me). When we entered at 2 for a late lunch, there were no tables available, which made me really excited. Secondly, the staff spoke minimal English, so it seemed more authentic than American. Lastly, like the Chinatown visits of my childhood, roast duck and pork hung in the window and there was a cook with his large cleaver slicing them on his wood stump. All of these things just made me break out into a gigantic grin. 

After a bit of a wait and some awkward waving/eye contact attempts, we were seated crammed in a small table. I opted for the beef tendon noodle soup, and my friend went with the duck noodle soup. We ordered a side of crispy roast pork, because he had never tried it before and I was curious if it was as good as the one my grandmother used to make or ones I have eaten out at restaurants throughout life. The pork, I was disappointed. I think they served us some that had been previously cut, so the meat was a little dry and it was cold-ish. The skin was oily but not very crispy, lacking the crackle I love so much. Redemption came in the form of noodles, as we both enjoyed the dishes they brought out. My friend, unaccustomed to Chinese noodle soups, was surprised to see how bland the broth was in comparison to say pho or ramen. I agreed, but this is the style of the Chinese and what I grew up with, so I still love it dearly along with pho and ramen!

Overall, this is a great place simple place to either dine in or carry out. The meat hanging in the window is chopped for you and weighed per pound, so you can come and try all the varieties of pork, chicken, and duck that your heart desires to go. I especially liked their selections of egg and rice noodle soups with meat.
author: Lianna N.

description: Perfect hole-in-the-wall HKG style BBQ place. Cheap, quick, and tasty Hong Kong style BBQ : roast pork, BBQ pork, roast duck, etc. Cash only and probably not the cleanest place but tasty and cheap.
author: Aaron H.

description:
I was in the neighborhood and saw the good reviews, so I checked out the place and I was very disappointed. 
The place is very crowded and everyone is loud. The staff are far from friendly, and one lady with short dark hair kept screaming at customers and other staff. Also the chefs didn't wear gloves and they'd touch people's cash and the food again without washing their hands. I had to wait for a very very long time to get my food. I ordered the roast duck and pork with rice which was pretty horrible. The duck was oily and mostly skin and bones. To top it all, the restroom was absolutely disgusting.
author: Sydney X.

description: They are still the cheapest, best with big portions.  The guy next to us had a meal with rice, soup, bittermelon and chicken for 6.00 including tax.  Our meal total was 14.00 for 2 and leftovers for another meal.  Go figure.  We had wonton, noodle, and beef tender tendons and bittermelon with black bean sauce beef and chow fun.  Yes this place is cramped and tsbles are a bit greasy.  But it is an experience.  You get served quickly, you eat, and you don't lounge around.  So much to eat but so little room in the tummy. The duck looked good.
author: Helen L.

description:
Meh -- I guess it gets the job done when you're craving meat but I've definitely had better and fresher in NYC. I ordered the BBQ pork and roast duck. The pork was too tough and really lacking that glistening sweet glaze that makes BBQ pork really outstanding. I also think they microwaved my dish but I was too hungry to complain.

The duck was better but still not as tender as I'd like it to be. Their complimentary soup was really good though.

Cheap and filling - $10 + tip for a lot of meat -- and I really was craving meat. But I don't think I would come back. 

CASH only.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Came here on a Sunday at noon and it was packed, but the turnover is so fast that it took about 15 mins to get seated even with a few parties in front of us. 

I was after the delicious duck/wonton noodles. Extremely generous servings of duck, I expected like 4 pieces for the price, but they gave almost more than I could eat! At least 8 pieces.

The surprise of the day though was the $3 porridge. We ordered 2 bowls, thinking it would be personal sized bowls at $3... but turned out to be LARGE bowls, the size of the noodle bowls! We took almost all of this home because that one porridge bowl serves about 8 personal sized bowls of porridge! Amazing!!! Talk about great value. 

Also the da dou miao (veggies) was cooked nice and garlicky. We didn't really order it, the waiter forcefully recommended/ordered it for us, and we were too noob to decline. But in the end I'm glad we didn't.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Originally we were going to China town for some good Cantonese dim sum, however, the waiting time was almost an hour. With my hungry stomach, we decided to walk across street to give that corner restaurant a try. Obviously, they were very busy during their lunch hour. They have the counter for barbecue pork and duck. It looks so fresh and good. We had been waiting about twenty minutes to be seated, and steated with sharing a table with other customers. 
-environment: old table, old tableware. The wall was dirty, they might need some cleaning and paint
-service: waitress were nice but rush, you'd better decide what you want quick. 
-food: their barbecue duck was very good and flavorful. You can choose the meat you want from the duck. We like the duck leg, and they were generous on the meat portion. We had a clay pot of oysters with barbecue pork, it's a good amount of portion and it was very yummy. The spicy ong choi was well cooked. And their won ton noodles was ok, the noodles texture was not the Cantonese type of noodles. That was a very Cantonese style lunch for us, and we enjoyed them a lot. 
The price was cheap, you cannot find another Cantonese restaurant as cheap as this one, plus their food was good too. Happy tummy.
author: Karmen S.

description: The owners are really nice and the food is good. I used to come here pretty much everytime I'm hungry and in CT.
author: Yvonne Y.

description: The head cook ( the tall guy with a hairy mole on his face) at the restaurant cheated me. Bought cooked  lamb stew and the scale clearly said $7.29. He charged me $8.00 telling another customer in Chinese that he charged me $8.00 instead of $7.29. He thought I thought I don't understand Chinese.
author: Mary W.

description:
This is probably one of my favorite comfort food places to eat in SF. It's one of the few HK style cafe/restaurants that I know and trust in SF. 

I'm going to forewarn you right now, this is place isn't the cleanest. The service is meh but the food is good. 

I always order the BBQ Pork with rice and it's so good. The panfried noodles with chicken are also good. The prices are a steal and if you eat there, they give you the house soup on the house. (ha) 

It's a local place where they try to move a lot of people so if you're a table of one or two don't be surprised if you have to share a table. 

If you're looking for some noodles, meat over rice, or some won ton noodle, I highly recommend this place but don't expect five-star service. (She's always nice to me :) )
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Torn between 3 and 4 stars - main thing keeping me back from 4 stars is the greasiness of the food.  I've been to Kam Po twice - first time was several years ago.  All I could remember from that visit was how greasy the food was.  Decided to give it another shot - and yep, the food is still fairly greasy.  Any hoot, more on that later.

Kam Po is located on one edge of Chinatown, not too far away from the main drag.  Definitely a hole in the wall, and you'll see a good handful of locals coming in and out to pick up some of their BBQ meat items to go.  Seating space is OK - they have enough room for perhaps 8 or 9 parties.  Yes, their selling point is authentic Chinese cuisine and cheap prices.  Rummaging through the menu, you'll see items in the $4.xx to $6.xx range.  We picked up 3 entrees - beef noodle soup ($4.65), chow fun ($5.10), and roast duck lo mein ($6.00).  Our total including tax  and tip was about $20 and our party of 3 left pretty full.  

I would say the portion sizes are about average for a Chinese place.  I was a little disappointed with the noodle soup - amount of noodles wasn't huge (hence, for a party of 3, each person got a small amount of noodles).  The soup tasted OK, but I thought it was odd that the soup was a little on the greasy side as well.  I like my soups to be hot and comforting - not to leave me feeling like I wouldn't need to use any Chapstick for the rest of the day.  Chow fun was also a tad more oily compared to other places - I know it's normally greasy, but Kam Po seems to like to take it up a notch.  Lo Mein was pretty OK - noodles weren't hugely flavorful, but they put in a decent amount of roasted duck (meaty portions, not just bones).  

Service - well, pretty standard for Chinese eatery.  Cleanliness was also on par with your other Asian spots.  

Overall, if you like cheap Chinese food, this is the place.  If you don't like greasy food, this isn't the place.  I wouldn't mind stopping by here again since it's a great place to go if you're on a budget.
author: Laura C.

description:
This place is always packed so I had to try it out. Especially when you live nearby and walk by it everyday.

Whole Peking Duck (roast duck) costs $18. Their prices have gone up since the old yelp reviews. 

Picked this up for my family on Xmas Day and they said it was the best Peking Duck they have ever eatin.
author: Joy M.

description:
Wait Time: 5-10 Minutes for a BBQ dish to go. Can't speak for other dishes. 

Unique Factor: 1/5 - Quick, Simple, Classic Hong Kong/Cantonese comfort food. 

Service: Chinatown service - you get your food and that's about it. Depends on their mood, sometimes you hear the bald "butcher/chef" saying degrading things (if you understand Chinese) to his possibly wife, who works as the waitress.
author: Vivian Y.

description:
I came here KNOWING that the service was shitty. I was prepared for that. But I didn't know it was THAT shitty. 

I was craving rice porridge in the morning and this was one of the only places that was decent enough on yelp. Despite all the warnings, I came here anyway (worse decision of the day). It was around 8:45 on a Monday morning. I walked into the restaurant and no one was there, it looked like they were still setting up.. which was strange because I thought they weren't opened yet (even though on yelp it said open at 8am)

Whatever. someone finally came out from the back, the chef? literally just stared at me then continue doing what he was doing, when he finished he handed me a menu then went to the back again for a good 5 minute. Leaving me in the front. After some awkward waiting time, I finally manage to order what I needed to order, got my food, then left. 

My ride porridge was good. I liked it. But it doesn't matter how great the food was, it still didn't justify the crappy service. 

There are a ton of restaurants in Chinatown, we'll survive without this one.
author: Yen P.

description:
In a city nearly defined in its culinary circles for the endless array of choices when it comes to inexpensive, very good Chinese food, Kam Po Kitchen deserves to be mentioned in this conversation. 

Dingy hole-in-the-wall restaurants throughout Chinatown, the Richmond and Sunset districts that specialize in Cantonese cuisine seem to be synonymous for authentic, cheap, very tasty Chinese food in generous portions.

Chief among my Cantonese favorite dishes are the Char Siu (roasted or barbecued meats) that always consists of duck, chicken and pork. Other popular dishes include chow mein and chow fun, lo mein, congee (rice porridge), wonton noodle soup with a variety of meats and soups that usually includes lettuce and some type of meat, meat and vegetable rice plates and seasonal vegetables.

Kam Po Kitchen had a pretty comprehensive menu list and is known for preparing most of these traditional and uniquely flavored dishes exceptionally well, including what many say are some of the best Chinese noodle soup in the city.

We reluctantly chose lighter dishes this evening because of our prior dinner reservation at Tony's Pizza Napoletana just a block away and dropped in looking for something to tie us down until then.

The noodle soup dishes, we figured, were a must-try and not too heavy. A friend also ordered a plate of steamed offals that we could share.

The mixed innards (offal), $3.95, were a good mix of steamed pig ears, intestines, stomach, gizzards and liver sparsely layered with a soy sauce and sesame oil mix. It was a rich and uniquely flavored, traditional dish that made for a great starter or appetizer.

The beef tendon noodle soup, $3.75, was a very good choice because they use the peripheral parts of the tendon which carried bits of flesh and fat, giving it a real beefy flavor and a meaty depth. The stringy egg noodles went perfectly with the hearty chunks of tendon and really soaked up the flavor of the delicately seasoned beef broth.

The shrimp wonton noodle soup, $3.25, had great texture and good flavor in its ingredients and nearly met my high standards for this dish. The gumdrop shaped, succulent shrimp wontons were made with whole shrimp and complemented with a mild soup broth and tasty wide rice noodles that were velvety soft and luxuriously smooth. The broth could have had more flavor. Otherwise, it would have been prepared to perfection.

Most dishes fall under $5. I hope to return and try their Char Siu that they are widely known for to gain a broader perspective on the food here. Upon my one visit, I felt fairly certain Kam Po ranks among the best Cantonese style noodle soup restaurants I have tried. Their shrimp wonton noodle soup, in particular, is worth repeated visits here.
author: Andrew K.

description: This is the place for great bbq pork and duck! I was in the mood for some fatty pork and this place delivered the goods! Simple yet so flavorful especially with a little rice. I'll be back!
author: Nate E.

description:
Came in around 6PM on a Thursday. They still had plenty of roast duck, chickens, char siu, roast pork, octopus and all those BBQ foods. However, hot foods were running low by this time. It contained very few choices. Therefore, I got half the guay fay chicken and one pound of octopus.

 Guay fay chicken meat was not at all rough, it was indeed very smooth and very tasty. Didn't even need the oily ginger sauce that I almost always use for my chickens because of the blandness. But this was one of the times that I don't need to dip the chicken in the ginger dip and can still manage to eat the white meat parts. 

Octopus, to me, was average. Nothing special. Nothing horrible. However it was definitely fresh. Also, I think this place is the only place in chinatown that sells octopus. Be sure to stop here if your in chinatown and want some octopus(:
author: Wendy T.

description: $7 for a bowl of bbq pork and shrimp wonton with noodles wins me over. Portions are generous. Expect dirty hole in the wall noodle shop that will fill your happy tummy and you will not be disappointed.
author: Richman L.

description: Good stuff! I ordered the Soy Sauce Chicken with Rice. My boyfriend ordered BBQ Pork with Rice. And we shared a Roasted Pork with Wanton Noodle Soup. The portions were pretty decent and the price was right...only $19 for those three items. Service was alright. Cleanliness was probably not of the highest order. This seemed like a pretty authentic style of cooking. Out of all the items ordered, I liked the BBQ Pork the best -- I'd give that a 4/5 and would return for that. I loved the way it was seasoned. Soy Sauce Chicken was pretty good -- 3.5/5. Neither one of us was super stoked about the soup. It was nice to have some warm soup on a cold day. And it wasn't bad. But it wasn't a favorite either. We both liked the BBQ pork the best. I'd give the overall experience a 3.5 out of 5.
author: Renee F.

description: This place is amazing! Anyone who knows me will tell you that I am a duck aficionado. I had to get the half duck and a pound of pork. Bother items were so tasty! The service has room for improvement, but I wasn't expecting much, especially because I don't speak Cantonese or Mandarin. I had leftovers for days which was really handy. This place is really affordable, but at the same time very intimidating. If you can strap on your big boy pants and place your order, be ready to eat some of the juiciest duck you have ever tasted!
author: Kaitlyn F.

description:
I use to come here as a kid. Cash only,  and price is extremely reasonable considering everything around these are expensive.  Found free parking at 7pm . Food hasn't come out yet but will update when this happens.

Service so far is typical Chinese style which is fast and efficient.
author: Chi H.

description: Cha siu was great, and around $12 a pound. However, there's a huge language barrier and so if you're ordering at the meat counter go with someone who speaks taishan cantonese-- because they speak in a dialect that is hard to understand and will get mad at you for not understanding.
author: Y W.

description:
I only put three stars, but here's my actual rating:
4 STARS for food taste
2 STARS for poor service.
But I guess you can't really expect too great if a service from any Chinese restaurants. But I gotta say, their food taste great for a very cheap price!

They only have two waitress at a time, so the service is slow. Warning: most of the waitress dont really speak english. So either bring a chinese friend with you or just gesture at which stuff you want from the menu i guess. 

Keep in mind, their food taste great especially the claypot menu! I love their tofu claypot (:

Its in chinatown, traffic is crazy.. So i suggest you walk or take the bus here. Parking is going to be hard to find too.

CASH ONLY!!

Cheers!
author: Inge C.

description:
I'll never go back to this place !!!! After I paid 15℅ tips, the server/owner told me I have to give 20℅. The reason was their food is cheap. Seriously????? That's something new to me

Anyone have the same experience??
author: Sweety Smurf S.

description:
On a whim, we went here after a day spent riding over the Golden Gate bridge. Everything we had (shrimp fried rice, char siu won ton mein, taro/duck claypot, sauteed pea shoots in garlic) was amazing. And there was so much of it! Leftovers for days!

This place certainly reminds me of Hong Kong (except the service is quite friendly) and the food is excellent. I'm definitely coming back the next time I'm in San Franciso!
author: Eric C.

description: If you like things being somewhat authentic and to eat among the locals, welcome to this place. The food is very good, large portions, cheap (we ate for 30$ being seven.. We just had the impression to steal). Don't look too close to the cleanliness and be ready for this Chinese peculiar way to be greeted and served and you should have a good time.
author: X L.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE. BBQ pork over rice (char siu fan) is so, so good. When my family visits, this is a must! For $5.60 a box, you get 2-3 meals basically. Cheap, fresh, and absolutely delicious, you can't go wrong with any of their meats honestly.
author: Stephanie C.

description: So good and so cheap! Fresh noodles. Had the Shrimp Wonton and 炒麵. Both very good and not at all oily. Service is nice as well.
author: Amanda L.

description:
Worst service ever! I'll give a zero star if I can!

Alert: If you cannot speak Cantonese and don't want to be pissed off by the arrogant stuff, don't eat here!

I waited around the counter for more than 5 min with no customer before me, and finally I just left feeling really angry.

I asked to order food twice in English, but the man behind the counter seems cannot hear and buried himself in slicing the duck, this really pissed me off! Another waitress just kept on walking around without even looking at me! Seems they are really confident about their food that they can just ignore customers.
author: William T.

description: Have been here a few times over the years. It has some very good and decent quick, comfy noodles and rice plates, along with a few clay pot items and very good barbeque items. The one thing that just turns me off is when the chinese ladies don't really communicate well; I had asked about two different choices on the menu and she keeps telling me it can't be done or, it's a different kind of meats. A bit frustrating. And then, at the end, there's always the "leave tip! words to the non locals. however, they don't seem to do that with the chinese elders.
author: Dennis Y.

description: Nothing wrong with Kam Po, but I just can't go all the way to four stars.  We had mustard  greens, soy sauce  chicken and duck wonton noodle soup.  All were fine, with the wontons in the soup the best.   On the other hand, all that, with tea and rice for less than  $25 before tip.  Who can complain?
author: David R.

description: I am visiting from NY and I figure the food here would be comparable to NY Chinatown.  You definitely don't come here for the decor or cleaniness.  However the portion they serve is outrageous.  It was so much food for so little price.  I got mapo tofu rice dish which was quite tasty.  My son for a huge bowl of congee and my wife for roast duck noodle soup.  Flavor wise profile is so so.  Nothing to really boast about except for the extravagant portion.
author: Kevin C.

description: Every time we're in the neighborhood, this is where we go!  Awesome authentic Chinese food and known for all their bbq and roast meat.  Been going to this restaurant for over 20+ yrs and just decided to write a review.  Their food never disappoints, everything is priced reasonably, and you get a ton of food!  We usually end up having leftovers.  No complaints about that.  We always order beef tendon because it's tender and delicious.  Maybe it's not something everyone would eat, but we love how it's made here!  Duck, bbq & roast pork (yummy crispy skin!) are good here too.  Always a satisfying experience for us.
author: A. C.

description:
The very windy interior is not the best during cold months. We dropped during the evening when it was a little chilly to find their door propped open and vented windows open as if it were a hot summer's day. Good grief, I'm surprised they can even stand the hilly draft blowing napkins on the floor and chilling you to the bone. They did eventually close the door, but it's still a cold restaurant, so don't how up without warm clothes!

Crsipy roast pork was dry and chewy, and the crispy skin was soggy and flavorless. It was actually kind of bad. I would not recommend this.

The roast duck had an excellent flavor, albeit on the salty side. A shame it was a little bony too. As far as the skin and meat go however, it was tasty.

The wonton soup was a light broth with wonton filled with mushrooms and possibly meat. They had a slight woody flavor that we weren't super excited about, but they are ok.

Rice is a ridiculously cheap, light, and flavorless affair. Unless you are jonesing for rice, this is not the place to get it. Flip side is that they I've you a big bowl of the crap for $1.
author: Marc M.

description: What the duck!  This is the best Chinese food ever.  The perfect little place that doesn't have many tourists but lots of locals...tells a lot.  For $15 you will not be able to finish a couple of meals for two people.  Had the duck and it was the juiciest, most tender, and flavorful I have ever had.  Choice after choice with some really unusual ingredients if you are adventuresome.  And this from a chef that owns his own restaurant.  TRY THEM!
author: Craig F.

description:
Since pretty much every restaurant was closed on Thanksgiving Day except for the restaurants in Chinatown, my family and I decided to stop by Kam Po for lunch. The reviews for their roasted duck made my mouth water, and seeing all of the BBQ delicacies in the storefront window ... 

I think this restaurant's roasted duck is the best I have ever had in my life. They don't give you any additional sauces for their meats (BBQ, sweet and sour, etc.) and to be honest, you don't really need it. The meat was tender and tasty, but the lightly crisp skin was so tasty! The BBQ pork was also really delicious. The pieces of meat weren't too fat, but not too skinny either. The fried pork was just okay. I've had better, and so I wouldn't recommend ordering the fried pork here. I think we had more pieces of dry skin than I would have liked. 

Also, the waitress kept recommending the spare rib noodle soup. She said it was really good, and though my mom didn't really want to have spare ribs with the noodles, the waitress made it sound so good that we just went with it. Haha bad decision because they were so dry and not tasty ...

I only give this restaurant 4 stars instead of 5 is because we told the waitress what we wanted to order. She changed it up and said it wouldn't be enough food for us and made the 2 delicacy with rice to be 2 different BBQ items with separate bowls of rice. I think what we wanted in the first place was fine, but sometimes waitresses in restaurants think they know their customers' stomachs more than we know our own.

Cash only! And buying a whole roasted duck carryout in SF seems so much cheaper than in LA!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
It took 15 minutes to take my order with 3 people working because the lady ahead ordered 3 ducks and was super picky about it but that's not their fault I guess.

I got the duck wonton noodle soup and it was amazing. Silky, chicken broth with chewy egg noodles, giant meat filled wontons, and succulent roast duck. The soy chicken over rice was also one of the best things I've ever eaten in Chinatown. The chicken was so tender and flavorful, like it had been marinated and roasted all day. Must try the pork next time. 

If you're a carnivore, this is a must try.
author: Fiona Y.

description:
Food (4.5/5): My bf and I split shrimp fried rice, roast duck, and bbq pork. Both meat dishes were perfectly cooked with lots of flavor without being too salty. The fried rice wasn't the best I've ever had, but pretty solid.

Service (4/5): I wasn't expecting much, since a lot of reviews mentioned that service was whatever, but everyone was really friendly to us, even though we didn't speak Canto. 

Value (5/5): We left full and with leftovers for $20 total! So worth. Haha we're always on the lookout for cheap and yummy places, and I'm so glad we found this one. Definitely will be back :)

Note - cash only!
author: Abby S.

description:
Hole on the walls. I like it very much. Come here often.

Clay pot with rice and various meats will take 30-40 min to cook. Gonna try it one day.

Hours are bad sometimes. They closed early a few times.

Communication is not the best with the waitress even in native tongue. She can be argumentative even when she did something wrong.

Ordered 1 lb BBQ pork and 1 lb roast pork to go. The butcher put together in one box. It's over 3 lbs total at the end. She argued the butcher can't be too accurate, right!!!

She asked... I instructed her to separate amount for dine in and 2 separate take outs, but we will pay together in cash. She gave us the total amount only without breakdown. She argued because we wanted to pay together.

Oh well, I can overlook these flaws and still support them.
author: Zack W.

description:
Huge portions, super cheap. Doesn't taste super amazing, and hence why only 4 stars. Still, it's better than majority of bad restaurants in Chinatown.

On a side note, the manager here impresses me with her multitasking both the togo counter and waiting the tables.
author: Tuan V.

description:
Black Pepper Beef & Rice is delicious. The rice plate serving portion seemed very generous so it's definitely a nice lunch meal. Service is good and some of the staff members here are friendly. There is also a fair amount of seating available if you plan on eating here.

Overall:
- good food
- good prices
- good service
- positive first experience

I'm definitely making my way back for lunch when I am nearby.

*The Soy Sauce Chicken, Roast Pork and Roast Duck - lean and delicious!
author: Bennett W.

description:
I was craving something meaty one afternoon and settled on getting half a duck to go. $8. What an absolute steal! The quality of the duck is also on par with the "high-end" Chinese restaurants I've visited.

Quite the trek up Broadway but so worth the leg burn.
author: Linda X.

description: I went in there with my parents twice today - the first time was to try and get a table for lunch.  It looked like too long of a wait so we left.  Then we stopped by after lunch to get a roast duck to take home.  We stood in line behind the counter, all 3 of us.  When it got to our turn, as soon as I opened my mouth and started speaking Mandarin, the guy behind the counter miraculously found not one, but two take-out orders he needed to work on.  And both of these were sizable orders, compared to our order of just a duck to-go.  This isn't the first time I've been discriminated against in Chinatown because I can't speak Cantonese, but this is definitely one of the most blatant.  Needless to say, we left in disgust, never to ever set foot here again.
author: Judy C.

description:
I friggin' loveeee this place!! After my friend recommended this as a "default" of his, I just had to try it for myself!

Here's a tip:
- If you're dining in, you just seat yourself and they'll bring you menus.
- If you're taking out, you get in line at the door.

I ended up in line when I wanted to dine in. Fail whale. But they were nice enough about it :)

We ordered:
Chicken on Rice - Yes, this was kind of amazing. Its the hunan kind of chicken..and it was super juicy and tender. yumyumyummmmm~
Duck - You CAN"T do duck wrong in Chinatown. Seriously..plus it was only $13 for the duck. AMAZING.
Wonton Soup - This is ONE serving which is big enough for 2-3 people to share it! PERFECT with some rice and duck...mmmm..

Wonderful place to catch a quick bite. Don't expect anything fancy or service to be spectacular..but DO expect some really good comfort food.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Locals go here because the food, meat and rice plates are cheap, cheap, cheap!!!...and good!!!

Sometimes, there is a line to wait and order up some chopped up, cooked meat, but it is do-able - especially with the huge portion and unbeatable price you are paying for.

I dislike the uncleanliness of this restaurant.  The bathroom feels murky to me.  The dining area needs to be refurnished.  I think if you avoid the need to go to the restroom and  can get over the worn out decor, this place would be a good dine in for you!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Uber cheap and pretty tasty roasted duck wonton noodles.
However, service is super slow, esp for a Chinese eatery. 
Hence the long wait.
Took them 20++ mins to get me my dish
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
Seriously amazing down home Chinese cookery! There's not much to be said about the decor, its barely clean but if you look beyond the greasy tables and the stacks of old newspapers you'll find one that Kam Po is probably one of the best Chinese places I've tried in Chinatown. 

1/2 Roast Duck - Im a huge addict to great roasted duck, from the crispy skin to the moist fatty meat, there's just something comforting about that smell of five spice that sort of reminds me of autumn. KPK nailed this down! 

Small Roast Pork - Small really wasn't all that small. Probably a good half pound of killer roast pork that came with rice and a side of pickled cabbage. My thoughts, rich fatty pork, I mean come on, how can it be so good? Even the crunchy skin didn't stand a chance against me and my love for pork.

Shrimp Wonton Noodle Soup - About this time our server pushed together another 2 top table against ours. With just the 2 of us ordering so much food, shit just got real. The soup had a good flavor and the chewy shrimp wontons were even better once I adorned them with a whole lot of chili paste. 

Beef Chow Fun - Greasy beefy and awesome! The noodles had a good amount of char and smoke flavor from a wok that's hot as hell. One thing to note is that the portion sizes here are huge and very sharable. 

At this point we were starting to hit the wall. We had chowed like it was our last meal though considering how hung over we were, it might as well have been. With this meal sitting in our bellies our hangovers started to subside. So another insight about KPK, a definite hang over cure.
author: Alexander C.

description:
My last meal on Earth would be their roast duck over rice. Good duck with drippings over perfectly done rice at Kam Po is one of my favorite things. I sometimes buy their whole large duck.

I like their roast pork as well. It has good flavor and is one of the better versions that I've found in Chinatown.

Besides the BBQ items it's also generally a good restaurant for Cantonese food.
author: John W.

description: The duck and the chicken as well as the noodles - they make me crave for San Francisco! A ridiculously cheap eatery but the flavours and quantities are definitely worth more. Tip: don't lose patience with the shoddy service; it's a small place that is always packed and the two waitresses are doing their best so have some patience - it's worth it!
author: Sadia H.

description:
4 stars on the ROAST DUCK. 

The BBQ pork is not very good, I have had better. Garlic Chinese broccoli is ok, not very tasty. There is a soup that comes with your meal - put it over your rice!!

This place is like eating at home at your grandmas. Big Asian bowls and Chinese plates. It is not fancy at all - they are also a "pick up" and "to go" location. 

It is the BEST BANG for your buck. So much food for SO CHEAP!
author: Belia P.

description: Still going here over 10 years long and 10 years strong. I still maintain this place has THE BEST Cantonese BBQ on the planet. It's a fortunate thing this place is tucked away im Chinatown SF, or I would be here every other day!
author: Doug R.

description:
We ordered roast pork and duck. They taste very bland, but they are at least very cheap. The shop owner, who received money from a previous customer, obviously thought it was okay to not washing his hands using soap and water. He briefly rinsed his hands using water, and the dried his hands on a towel which looked old and colored, and then chopped up the duck for us.

I have had Peking duck at several restaurants in multiple cities in the U.S. In my opinion, the best one is the Sang Kee Peking Duck in Philadelphia. Kam Po Kitchen ranks towards the bottom on my list.
author: Holiday W.

description:
Don't know what the fuss is all about.  The guy who was cutting the meat also handled money without washing his hands.  GROSS!!  

I ordered a roast pork and duck with rice, sure the value is good for the price, but the duck is tough.  Would I come back? No!!!
author: Kevin L.

description:
First off, this place isn't the cleanest, nor is the service the best but what it lacks in those two categories, it more than makes up for with it's food. I ate here the first weekend I moved here and have been going back whenever I am craving some good down to earth Chinese food. Not only is the food here good but it is extremely cheap as well, we were able to order enough food for four people and order half a roast duck and BBQ pork for just under $50 and let me tell you I was stuffed. 

You see many restaurants around china town with various roasted and barbecued meats hanging in the window, don't let that discourage you from going in, this is probably the best part of the restaurant. I've come by multiple times to grab a quick dinner or some barbecued meat to go and the taste/price of the food is enough to make me want to come back many more times.
author: Zach C.

description:
we came cause I saw shrimp only wonton noodle soup hong kong style which is hard to find, 99% of places use shrimp and pork in their shrimp wonton noodle. the other 1% is 3000 miles away from NY Noodletown. 

not as amazing as NY Noodletown in the broth but no one is. also the noodles while al dente wasn't as light and chewy as NYN. the duck while good was on the salty side cause of the dripping sauce and to many cuts with no meat. also ordered their char siu pork which was disappointing. it wasn't a deep dark red more light red in color and it had an affect on flavor. also very few cuts had the dark red crusty ring around it which also ruined a bite. it would take me three weeks later to rectify my taste buds with proper char siu in the most unlikely place.
author: NYSD G.

description:
What's with all the hate? It sounds like folks are expecting a lot from this place--it's supposed to be a hole-in-the-wall small operation with small tables for casual eaters, folks! Look at all the customers who know what they're doing, and you'll see 8 out of 10 come here for the take out Roast BBQ Pork, which is clearly the whole reason why this place exists!

Order take out if you can, since that's what this place is for! Or if you want to stay don't make a whole feast and order 10 dishes :) I don't think they expect you to tip either. It's supposed to be the Chinese version of fast food!

The BBQ meat certainly is one of the best I've eaten, with large portions. Look no further if you're craving so savory BBQ-ness
author: Henry L.

description: Prices have gone up like everything else here in Chinatown.  Roast meat still good.  Lots of customers lined up for their roast duck and such.  Owner and workers been here for more then 20 yrs.
author: Mar H.

description:
Cheap, huge portions of pretty good chinese/canto food!
I came here on a Wednesday afternoon, around 1.30pm. There was a lot of spaces. Service wasn't THAT bad, just that they were not super attentive. Got seated within a minute. It wasn't a big shop. I ordered a pork rice plate and the portions were GENEROUS! Rice was inconsistent, with some parts soggy whilst others hard. The meat was tender in general, with 2 pieces being really hard, dry, and a little chewy. Not a bad experience. Good spot for a quick, filling meal!
author: Audrey H.

description:
So much tasty food for such a small amount of money! My boyfriend and I made a big mistake ordering 2 separate dishes thinking that the portions would be on the smaller side since the prices were so low. Nope! We ended up boxing up half of our dishes because there was so much. No matter, they made for tasty leftovers later on that evening. :) 

We weren't the only ones to make this mistake. The table next to us ordered 3 bowls of soup and ended up laughing at their portion sizes while scratching their heads wondering how they would finish it (they didn't and ended up taking the rest home).
author: R B.

description: Yummmmy. We had the bbq duck wonton egg noodle soup, soy sauce chicken fun noodle soup, Chinese broccoli, two meat rice platter. All were delicious. Easy 5 stars if it weren't for the rude gesture of leaving a tip when we haven't yet left....
author: Jo J.

description: Amazing service, authentic, and inexpensive Chinese cuisine. Had the roast duck, shrimp won ton soup, Hong Kong style fried noodles
author: Mikey M.

description:
Kam Po draws a steady stream of Chinatown locals who get fresh barbecued meats to go. As a dine-in place, I can get over the grungy lack of superficial cleanliness (sadly typical of many U.S. Chinatown restaurants, as I'm used to seeing), so I decided to give this place a try based on the high average Yelp rating. 

The roast pork wonton noodles were cheap ($6.25 including tax) and generously portioned. Rice and noodle dishes were even cheaper and looked just as large. Still, taste was just average. Moreover, the roast pork was very fatty and some of the wontons had inedible bits in them (likely pieces of shrimp shells). Overall, meh on a quality scale. To their credit, service was fast and courteous given that I can speak Cantonese. 

Grab your order of barbecued, custom-butchered meats to go, for lunch or dinner at home. If you're conscious about the fat, make sure to trim it out on your own.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Sad to report that they are no longer the Sui Gow (dumplings in soup) Kings in my book!  Today's order was mainly comprised of ground pork. mushy shrimp pieces, and small amounts of wood-ear fungus (you know, those dark crunchy strands).
Fortunately, my BBQ pork (cha siu) was lean and tasty and the portions, as usual, were very generous.
Not sure whether they are compensating now for the low prices by skimping on the quality.  Sad sad meal...
author: Mike C.

description:
If you like affordable greasy Chinese food in large portions.., this is the place for you!  Kam Po Kitchen is more idealistic for takeout, as the dining area is small and the bathroom is nasty.  You can always tell how authentic the Chinese restaurant is by how dirty their bathrooms are.

As of 1/8/13; Kam Po Kitchen received a Food Safety Score of 83, which means "Needs Improvement".  If you ignore the cleanliness of this restaurant, you'll appreciate the quantity of their portions for the very cheap prices that you pay.  The food is very flavorful, but it is too greasy.
author: Johnny W.

description: Cheap, straight forward, simple yet authentic chinese food. When I visit chinatown, and I don't want to wait for the big dim sum places during lunch hour, I go here, Is it cramped and perhaps less than comfortable? Yes. Is it loud? Yes. But it's chinatown, the whole place is like that. At least it's cheap and good food. That is all.
author: Peter K.

description:
Definitely a hole in wall, I wouldn't have gone there judging by the looks of the place but my BF grew up eating food from here and told me it was bomb, so I go skeptically. 

It only took me one trip here to fall in love with their food, I mean how can you argue with cheap food that comes in huge portions!? 

Every plate is under $7 bucks and the food is more than enough to fill you up! 

I love the eggplant dish with rice. So good that when I was deprived of good food in Santa Cruz, I asked my BF to drop some off on his way back to school!
author: Kelly L.

description:
Took my wife and a visiting friend from Ohio to Kam Po yesterday.  This was my second visit. 

I ordered a half duck. I will confirm that this was the best duck I ever ate anywhere. Large portions of meat and the outside was prepared in a way that was tastefully superior to any I ever had. Only $6.50!  Five stars for the duck. 

Pork fried rice was good but not exceptional. (About $5.55)  Regular size portion. Three stars.

Beef over rice. Large portion of that with so much beef. (4.65) Good taste. Three and half stars.

Beef chow fun. (4.65) Wonderful taste and not overly greasy but about right. Good portion of beef. Enjoyed it.  Four stars.

Beef stew wonton soup (4.75) . Very good and tasty. Large portion. Soup had a wonderful taste to it as did the added meat and noodles including the wonton. Four stars.

Restaurant was crowded (weekday 1:30 PM)  At one point, we had to share our table, but that was all right. 

Service was average. 

Prices are EXCEPTIONALLY low. Large portions, good food and low prices. Five stars for price/value.

Overall would give it a four star. 

Will be in town until October. Will be sure to return there.
author: Steven G.

description:
Food was delicious and cheap, despite looking like a "hole in a wall"!  I would have given 5 stars if it wasn't for the service, but I can't blame the waitress since she was the only one there serving (she tried her best) as well as being the bust boy.

Don't be hesitant go in and try...especially their duck!!!
author: june b.

description:
The server threw the menu at me. My jaw dropped.

Another server saw it and she intercepted her service. Their food is fresh but don't expect decent service. I found out through my Chinese co-workers not to eat in, just order to go, I work 10 feet away from that place.
author: Lee Y.

description: Decent roast duck and beef chow fun. Cash only. Interior decor reminds me of 1940-1970's HK eatery.
author: Maggie S.

description: Update! During lunch I always see a crowd here, and after coming back to try their lunch combos I can see why. For $5-$7, cash only, you get large scoop of rice, some cabbage, and a generous helping of whatever protein they have hanging there. I always see these people lining up for their crackling siew yuk (roasted pork belly), or their roasted duck. Both are really crispy and fresh. You can also get BBQ pork or chicken. There are plenty of other things on their menu, however I'd only recommend the things I mentioned above. Really good value considering the portion and quality. You can sit in or order to go from the counter which can be a bit more intimidating. Its not the cleanest place if your sensitive to that so i can't give it full 5.
author: Huy V.

description: I am not into super strange food and cannot eat with chopsticks.   After looking at the menu, I was quite nervous to eat here and nearly demanded that my family leave and go to a pizza joint.    But we found some innocuous things to order and ended up being pleasantly surprised.   Sweet and sour chicken and shrimp lo mein were the clear winners.   Huge portions.  Definitely enough to share.   Cash only.   Give this place a try.
author: Addison H.

description:
I call this Chinese soul food. 

I used to come here alot when I was younger. There's been so many owners since then but the quality of the food remains good. It's a little run down, it can be dirty (just wash the utensils in the hot tea) and the waitresses can be a bit rude, but I swear the food is good! I love their meats - roasted duck is my favorite and I have it over rice or wonton noodles. If you feel like having more than one type of meat, you can can order it that way too - like roasted duck and soy sauce chicken over rice. They're not shady with the portions and it just delicious. Easy, quick, delicious meal.

Please try not to get grossed out with how run down/dirty it is! Give it a chance if you haven't been.
author: Rosie W.

description:
This is probably the 4th place I've been to in SF where yelp has failed me. Out of about 8 places. 
I ordered the duck and the bbq pork on rice.
The rice had some weird cinnamon spice in it. Both the pork and the duck were crappy cuts, really fatty and boney. It was also served lukewarm. 
The only advantage is that it was cheap, but this is SF so still not that cheap. Expensive by Sydney standards. 
It's just not worth going here, I'm not sure how these places get to 4 stars...
author: Michael S.

description:
How lucky are we San Franciscans to have Kam Po and Cheung Hing in our city???? These two temples to Chinese deli greatness could be visited as part of a progressive meal and I'm not writing about Democratic-party politics here.

I once attended an event at E & O Trading company honoring Anthony Bordain and was awed by his statement that, and I paraphrase, all great chefs have at their core a Chinese chef.

How is it that Kam Po can make cucumber soup that would make many chefs cry.

And the Sha Shui and roasted pork? Well, it's right up there with same dishes served at Cheung Hing although in this poor writer's opinion Cheung Hing marginally edges Kam Po.

Enough pontificating. If you're west of Divisadero and have jones for Chinese deli,  get some at Kam Po!!!
author: Jay D.

description:
Coming from LA, I used to always joke around that when you're in Chinatown, the health ratings all have different meanings. A = "Americanized," B = "Better," C = "Chinese. "  Keeping that in mind as I trekked down Broadway, I knew this place would be legit. Minimal decor, crowded seating area with mismatched chairs, and a somewhat questionable kitchen area. 

I forgot about all of these things as soon as the food arrived. Every bite I took brought me back to my summers in HK. I have never been a fan of roast duck, however, the duck here is phenomenal.  The best way to describe it is a hybrid peking and HK BBQ duck with thin crispy skin and flavorful juicy meat. The preserved egg and pork congee was probably the best I've ever had. It's also worth noting that the portions here are HUGE. The burly construction worker sitting next to me filled up on one order of roast duck and rice before heading back to work. Needless to say, I had delicious leftovers to bring home and enjoy the next day.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Cash Only.  We went to Kam Po Kitchen for dinner Fri 11/26/10.  It's a hole-in-the-wall place in SF Chinatown on Powell St.

We were heading elsewhere, but have always to try this place & since it was in front of us we went in.

Food is cheap, but not all that great.

I got a Roast duck wonton noodle soup $5 or so.  I got it with large rice noodles.  Some pieces of the duck were good, but others mostly bones & fat.  Wontons were small, some bok choy with the soup.  Just ok.

B. got beef stew noodle soup about $5 - one piece of beef stew was tender, other pieces he said wasn't very tender.  He got egg noodle & like that ok.

B. ordered chicken feet about $5 - I thought they were pretty bad.  Not very tender, not enough flavor.  Skip it.

Someone ordered a plate of 1/2 roast chicken meat & 1/2 bbq pork over rice w/ side of veggies.  That looked good.

Another table tried to get chow fun - waitress said they ran out of chow fun!  That's strange.  They picked chow mein instead.

There's 1 unisex bathroom - didn't use it.

Before tip was $15.20.  Cash Only.
author: Ann L.

description:
Word of the day: value. Value, value, value.

I can't give this place 5 stars because the service was basically cold. I didn't really feel that wanted there, perhaps as I didn't speak Chinese and only ordered two dishes. Also, I feel like our bill was fudged a bit but it was still cheap so whatever.

Ordered sweet & sour chicken with rice and chicken chow fun. Each dish was $4.65. FOUR. SIXTY. FIVE. I couldn't believe my eyes, but I went with it.

Hefty portions of really tasty, well-prepared and well-presented food. This is the BEST food I've ever gotten for the cost. Without exaggeration. I'm not sure I've ever, in any city or country, been served a better meal for a raw $9.30 before tax. Our bill came to $12.50, maybe I'm wrong but at current tax rates I don't know how we got there. Still, after tip I left $15 which for what we got was still pretty cheap honestly. They were pretty good about refilling on hot tea, so there's that. Also the soap in the bathroom was watered down. I hate when restaurants do that.

For REAL though, I've not ever had so good a meal for so little. It isn't a beautiful shop with the nicest employees but... VALUE. I'd come back if I were in Chinatown.
author: Riki N.

description:
visited San Fran Jews for Jesus, great and a place to stop...AND for an eatery= ...has Cantonese special dim sum,  Barbeque hehe duck too, goodie hehe, large portions...some are just ok...yet fairs better than others in China towns. high price and you never can be sure other places....here it is priced right reasonable and a little wait in the lunch rush, don't bring a big group, unless you wish to split into smaller groups...
or wait the while. David in His amazing grace, and stay tuned..i do get around...don't know how to comment on INTERNATIONAL TIPS Israeli, Italy, and more countries eateries, seemingly not listed...ISRAEL...great hummas and veggies and grains...but if your an American guy in Italy in Rome...go to Ladispoli by the sea.. don't trust most of the guys,  hoards of kids, or ...'guests' there
author: David I.

description: This place was totally misrepresented. It is not fusion. It's Japanese which would have been fine if that is what we were in the mood for. Do not say Asian Fusion if you are heavily one type of food!
author: Benny R.

description:
I never realized how great this place was until I went off to college! Everything here is super delicious and cheap! Their seafood jeen meen and beef chow fun (dry or wet) is my all time favorites! Their won ton noodles and roast pork/duck are really good too! There always seem to be a line though!

This is pretty much a hole in the wall place but definitely worth going to try. Authentic chinese food! Can't wait to go back to get some!
author: Shanna C.

description:
This place reminds me of back home in LA. I basically grew up in Chinatown, and sad to say that it's slowly disappearing. However, the one in SF? WAY different story.

I was hungry and didn't know what to eat. Therefore, I called a friend, who knew the area, to recommended me a place. She said it's something HK on the corner of Broadway and Powell. Wander around, found the place and she told me "I miss their dry fried noodles." So, she decided what I was going to eat.

Going in, the actual place brought back childhood memories of me as a young one, in Los Angeles Chinatown, having mommy order some food to go, to take home. Or just staring at the dangling ducks behind the glass.

I placed my order in Canton, and asked how long is the wait. Server said, "not long at all". And I waited. Not even 5 minutes has passed and BAM! My order's done. I even said, "wow, it came out REALLY quick" and the server just smiled.

The noodles were $5; however, the $5 is filled with grease, with not as much MSG as like how I had the two noodle dishes from Sam Woo's happy hour. Tastewise, it's a bit bland. Not really complaining THAT much because I was able to find a cheap dinner in SF.
author: Tom T.

description:
Food is not bad, HUGEEEE PORTIONS!!! lol. service sucks if you cant speak chinese, and its still  not that great when u can... lol

the food was good, i got the Black Bean Beef Chow Ho Fun with gravy. Not bad. except they threw hella bell peppers on it. I HATE BELL PEPPERS GROSS. I picked it all out, and my coworkers ate it all for me. haha. 

Pretty authentic I must say. Another one of those 1 mile hikes to get here from my office. 

The tables are kinda sticky and small. 

Oh, did i mention they're dirt cheap? haha. 

I'm gonna come back for some roasted pig and duck!!!!! NOMS NOMS NOMS


=] Happy Face for me today!
author: Judy W.

description:
If you're looking for fancy, not the spot. This place is good Chinese comfort food. All the BBQ and roasted items are on point. Their porridge has good consistency and options are vast. My favorite... The frog clay pot with extra ginger. Rice and noodle plates never disappoint. 

Service is okay. Not the greatest but eating in a place like this your not looking for a concierge. Good food and decent service! I'm a regular!
author: Jason T.

description:
After seeing this place packed full of people with delicious looking food, my friend and I spontaneously decided to eat lunch here. The portions were huge, and the food was cheap, but the food wasn't the best. 

We ordered a Beef Stew Flat Noodle Soup (Ngau Lam Tong Ho), a Wonton Noodle Soup, and a plate of Cha Siu. The Cha Siu was probably the best part of the meal. It was pretty lean, tender, and juicy. I thought it was seasoned pretty well with salt and savory spices, but it could have been sweeter. It didn't have that glistening glaze on the outside which was kind of a let down. 

From the outside windows, the noodles soups looked pretty good. It was the main reason why we got them. I could tell that the wontons were all shrimp just by peering through the glass. Despite the really slow service, I was still really excited to dig into my bowl when it arrived. When I took my first bite, my excitement quickly dwindled as the broth and noodles were so bland. The wontons really were all shrimp which is what you'd find in more desirable upscale wontons, but they also lacked any kind of seasoning. My friend's broth was similarly bland, and her beef was tough and flavorless. It was pretty disappointing all around. Maybe the roast duck is better? I guess on the plus side, it's cheap.
author: Nei N.

description: Bomb roast duck wonton noodle soup. Bowl was loaded and flavor was excellent. Noodles were thin and chewy. "I'll be Back!"
author: Jack N.

description: Kam Po, how do you do it so well? Like everyone says, the bathroom is tiny, service is ridiculous, and it's quite sticky, but man, you're at a Chinese restaurant in Ctown. What are you expecting? Look, their prices haven't changed in years, and you still get the same gigantic portion sizes for $5.88 a plate. This place is seriously ridiculous. I mean, they have a dish that has noodles, flat noodles, wontons, and roast pork in soup. It's $5.88. Not a joke. Food comes out super quickly and piping hot. Seriously, this place kicks major butt. It's so small though, so you're going to have to stake out a table if you're coming on a weekend or during rush hour.
author: Danny C.

description:
Good food, alot of chinese People but thats what makes it Authentic :-)

Dont ask for water or else... :-)
author: Clipperson P.

description: This is the only Chinese restaurant I've been to that reminds me of the Chinese restaurants back home. It's cheap, big portioned, and delicious Chinese food.
author: Enoch L.

description: My Asian friends showed me Kam Po and I cannot get enough of this place! Right outside the Broadway Tunnel is this gem. I always call in and order the Shrimp Chow-Mein (Very tasty), Curry Chicken, Beef & Broccoli, Tofu Soup and a few containers of rice. Large portions for cheap! Doesn't get any better than that!
author: Julian T.

description: Cheapest hole in the wall chinese restaurant in the city. You want Hong Kong style pan fried noodles? There's no extra charge unlike other places. This is where all the Chinese people go. :D
author: Walter W.

description: I really love the BBQ pork or duck here. Everything is just right. And the price too! Probably the best in the bay area, especally if you consider goodness for the money. I know a place in Oakland that might be a little bit better, but it's several more dollars an item..Is it 30 percent better? Nah
author: Paul M.

description:
Cheap and DELICIOUS--people do not come here for ambience or exceptional service.

Regardless of the latter, Kam Po deserves four stars for the nommy food alone. The bf and I each got the roast duck (crispy skin + juicy meat + tasty sauce = orgasms in my mouth), which comes with a hearty portion of rice and veggies. We also split the shrimp wonton soup, but it was so much food that we had leftovers.

A meal for two and a snack for later, for only $13.50??? We'll definitely be back! I'll try the BBQ pork next time, though it might be hard to pass up that scrumptious duck--but for ~$5 per meal, I'll probably end up just ordering and chowing down on both. :)
author: Michele P.

description: Was caught off guard with the huge portion sizes, however i was then left with left overs for that late night Chinese food fix! Not complaining :)
author: Chanise F.

description: We literally went in and ordered roast duck, roast pork, pig feet, chicken feet and steamed rice. No funny business - just real down to earth good ole grub. Happily satisfied with promises to come back.
author: T C.

description: Ordered beef chow fun and roast duck. The chow fun was dripping with grease and had no flavor. The duck was ok. Big portions but would not come back.
author: Heather A.

description:
Cheap, good, questionable cleanliness and more Chinese patrons than other races. Just the way I like my Chinese dive restaurants. 

If you want some hoity-toity experience, go to Yank Sing. But, if you want some down home southern Chinese cooking, this is the place! 

Beware, it gets crowded for lunch and you might have to share a table. 

My go to winter lunch is the won ton noodle soup. Hand made and oh so comforting!
author: Brian L.

description: Roasted duck over rice was so so so amazing!!!! You must try it! But has to wait for pretty long time to be seated.
author: Kyle X.

description:
Ewwww . . . just ewwww . . . 

I love a good deal but there's a sanitary line that I draw in the sand that a restaurant just shouldn't cross and this one does.  By golly, I wish they'd raise the price of all their dishes by a dollar and use the proceeds to buy a bit of hygeine.  

The roast pork is pretty good and I love their vegetable dishes but if I were to buy something there again (which I doubt I would), I would eat somewhere else because the environment there is just so unappetizing.  From the sweaty butcher up front with a foot-long hair coming out of his facial mole to the greasy dirty tables and chairs, I'm just not a fan of Kam Po.  Sorry folks.
author: Linda H.

description:
Many of you wondered, "How was my Thanksgiving?"

"Well I worked, but I love the Holiday pay though!"

My wife knows I love the food from Kam Po. And this Chinese deli/restaurant also sells cooked Turkey on Thanksgiving Day and Christmas. She bought a half of a cooked turkey, which weighs five pounds, for $3.00 per pound. In addition, the short-haired waitress and the dude behind the counter seen me, as an employee of San Francisco, and seen my wife dined here many times and gave us a discount on half of the cooked turkey.  

Most of the turkeys I've had for the past thirty-seven Thanksgivings were very dry and unbearable to eat. But Kam Po's version was very moist. Especially eating it for dinner, when she bought the half  bird earlier this afternoon. And Kam Po's gravy with the turkey was thick, tasty and covers the rice and vegetables (made by wife) very well. 

Most of the Chinatown Delis also sell cooked turkey on Thanksgiving, but Kam Po makes a good bird and affordable too. Even without my discount. 

"Happy Thanksgiving, everybody!"
author: Matt G.

description: I ordered beef tendon noodle soup for take out and it was okay. Three stars because I was hoping the soup would be more of a beef broth, but it tasted rather fishy.  After calling in the order and waiting in line, I wish I had ordered the barbecued chicken/pork with crispy skin.
author: Krystle L.

description: Affordable solid little no-frills chinese place specializing in roast and bbq meats it seems. Had a non-standard "hainan chicken" dish here ($6), along w/ some dou miao ($6.50) to balance out the meal. The chicken dish while tasty was closer to the canto "Bái qie ji", or poached chicken w/ a ginger-scallion-garlic oil sauce, on top of a bed of pickled vegetables. AFAIK, that is not the type of sauce one uses for hainanese chicken. The rice also was lighter flavored and colored; I'm told really good hainan chicken rice should have a nice yellow hue and be more strongly flavored of chicken. Still, the food is a great deal here; I wanna come back and try some of their jook. (They also serve a hefty shrimp dumpling and roast duck noodle soup here for a little over $6! Screw Katana-ya.)
author: Linus W.

description:
Kam Po Hong Kong Kitchen rules: believe the hype. 

This joint is the sort of locals-only joint that is in it for the long haul what with their mind-bogglingly extensive menu, unpretentious portions, and budget-friendly prices. The only drawback I could possibly foresee is the wincing disgust of vegetarians attempting to find a guilt-free offering here. Having lived near this bastion of Chinese soul food realness for more than fifteen years my friends and I have come to call Kam Po H.K.K. by the nickname "Meat, and meat alone." Located just two blocks West, uphill from what most tourists would consider the Chinatown exit/North Beach entrance portal, I encourage any and all SF visitor ballin' on a budget to make a detour for this deliciousness. Just be aware that you will be dining with multiple carcasses hanging in plain view, the whole roasted pig being more of a plus than a drawback.
author: Kelly O.

description:
Is the place dirty? YES
Is this seating comfortable? NO
But is food good? YESSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSS

I have a lot of respect for this restaurant. While other restaurants in Chinatown increased their prices over the years, Kam Po maintained modest and affordable pricing for the community.
author: Fu D.

description:
If you're looking for the best roast meats in Chinatown, hands-down it's probably found at Kam Po Kitchen. In fact, rumor has it that they provide the roast meats for several other eateries around. 

I believe it's almost 4 years to the day that I stumbled upon Kam Po. I had just moved to the city and got lost in the labyrinth that is Chinatown at night but it was a most fortuitous detour since I found my go-to Chinese roast house. 

First off the roast duck is just such a guilty pleasure. Wonderfully fatty and tasty with the most perfectly crispy and succulent skin. Order it over rice and you can easily split it into 2 meals. The roast duck in wonton noodle soup is also one of my favorite hangover cures. The plump wontons and the warm soup work in tandem with the duck to get me out of my funk. 

If you've never seen a whole roasted pig come out of the roaster then you need to get here. It truly is a sight to behold when they bring the whole perfectly roasted hog out and hang it on display for all to see. What's impressive is they actually go through more than a pig a day. But wait till you bite into it. The crispy skin is perfection - the kind of thing that makes Anthony Bourdain salivate on camera. 

I've had other dishes here ranging from salted fish fried rice to dry fried beef chowfun and they are all decent but the real stars at Kam Po are without a doubt their roast meats. Considering that meals here are so inexpensive (most average around the $5 mark) though, it's hard to order something wrong.

The service is fast and earnest here especially the lady with the short cropped hair. She is a star here and runs a very tight ship. She negates the attitude from the grumpy butcher.  Don't come here for the ambiance. It's a dive. Order take out if you're afraid of the place but trust me you won't regret it. The food at Kam Po is truly yummy.
author: Jon L.

description: My first review was simply a complaint on the wait. Kam po is hands down the best roast duck in SF. I can't go to Chinatown without coming here. Duck heaven.
author: Junel S.

description: If you're around Golden Gate bridge, Palace of Fine Art or Lombard Street and if you're looking for an authentic Cantonese restaurant, then Kam Po is the place.  Parking is always difficult in the Richmond district.  The restaurant is "hole in the wall", small and busy.  We ordered soy chicken, char-sui, salt and pepper prawn, beef egg plant, beef fried rice, beef chow fun and vegetable  crispy chow mein.  Everything was excellent and the price is very good.
author: james V.

description:
Good reviews are hard. It's so much easier to dismantle than to praise. Good reviews sound flat and uncreative. Humor is easier when it's harsh.

But Kam Po is good. Very good. On a street full of Chinese restaurants, Kam Po is full when the rest are empty. The flavors are intense but not just sweet and salt, like so many American Chinese places. Where else can I get pork liver lo-mein if I ever wanted it. I haven't yet, but I like the option.

I chatter with the woman who I think owns the place with her husband, the only waitress I've ever seen, in a mixture of English, Cantonese and Mandarin, and I don't even speak Cantonese. She gives me free soup because I eat there all the time and I'm too thin. She's like my second mother, and my first mother loves Kam Po because it's so cheap, so good, so fresh. When you sneak off to the tiny bathroom, glance into the kitchen. Last time I did, I saw the whole hogs hanging from the ceiling.

I always order the duck. Now, I get a whole one so later in the week I can eat duck from the fridge and tide myself over before I go back. But a 1/2 order of crispy duck is the way to go if you don't want leftovers, and it'll only set you back $9. 

Cash only.
author: Liuyin S.

description:
Last night in SF we went here for dinner. Seated quickly, waitress was a little abrupt and was sure to tell us cash only before taking our order. The place was full and there was only the one extremely busy waitress. Also it seemed strange they did not have ice. 

We ordered beef chow fun, wonton soup with roast pork, and rice plate 1/2 duck 1/2 pork, it was all very good and CHEAP!
author: Shawn G.

description:
5 stars! Don't make the mistake we did by ordering too much food. The dishes are giant, don't be fooled by the price. 

THE DUCK IS A MUST!!!

If you're looking for a cheap place to eat in Chinatown, this place is perfect. (most dishes are a little over 5 dollars)
author: Robert C.

description:
Let's get to the point: this place gives you RIDICULOUSLY LARGE DELICIOUS PORTIONS for CHEAP. 

We ordered Beef Intestines, Beef Tripe, Chinese Broccoli, and several bowls of Wonton Noodle Soup, and Duck Noodle Soup. All of the portions were insane, everything is between $4-$7 and it's SO MUCH FOOD. More importantly, it was delicious, savory, and filling.

This place was actually very busy for a hole-in-the-wall place. My BIGGEST COMPLAINT is that the restaurant is SUPER SMALL and PRETTY DIRTY. The floors were sticky and there was crumbs and things of that nature everywhere.

Service is fast, friendly (particularly if you can speak Chinese), and it was an overall enjoyable experience if you exclude how cramped and untidy it was. If you're visiting San Francisco and you're hungry, swing by here with some friends, share the food family style, and be satisfied out of your mind.
author: Corey P.

description:
I returned here for lunch last week due to some field work in the area.  The menu now still shows a lot of Chinese BBQ rice or noodle soup dishes for under $5 before tax and tip.  For $4.95 I got a pretty good bowl of roast duck and wonton noodle soup.

The waitress who served me was quite nice, a plus for a restaurant like this.  I recall it wasn't as busy as previous times I came for lunch (don't recall if it was because it was a later hour like after 1pm).  That was good for me because in the past during very busy hours the service can become very disorganized (especially when there's also a line of people ordering Chinese BBQ for takeout).

Also, keep in mind that this is a Chinese BBQ place where the "star attraction" is the roast duck.  Therefore don't expect a super-clean place.
author: H K.

description: This is one of those small mom and pop Chinese restaurants. They don't focus too much on their interior decor and presentation. The food is really cheap and they give you quite a lot. My parents and I ordered seafood chow mein, chow fun, and porridge for only $15.10 total! We also had enough to take home. They used the same bowls and plates that I use at home so I feel like I'm eating a home cooked meal. The food isn't amazing but you definitely get what you pay for.. And maybe more.
author: Connie V.

description: Ordered roasted duck over rice because of the good yelp reviews. I am not a big fan of duck meats as a lot of times the ones I had were too gamy. But I really enjoyed their roasted duck.  The skin was so crispy and the meat inside was tender and juicy. Plus, the portion was generous for 5 dollars.
author: grace k.

description:
Hot diggity duck!

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/0Yw-OWhZAU8BI852cx21ug?select=4pgA69Ao2Eth6PuchWOdXQ

I'd dropped into Kam Po several times over the past few years to pick up components for dinner, such as some chopped up roast pork or a box of steamed rice, but I had never tried anything off the menu.

I finally had my chance when I was working nearby yesterday. I walked in at lunchtime and stopped in my tracks...why had I never noticed before that the big menu on the wall is only in Chinese?

I started scoping out what the 99% Chinese patrons and 1% smart tourists had on their tables and kept going back to the roast duck that an older gentleman seemed to be greatly relishing.

Wow. So incredibly flavorful. The accompanying steamed cabbage and white rice picked up the wonderfully rich brown sauce from the duck, and the duck itself was moist, tender, fatty goodness.

I came thisclose to stopping back in later for another order for dinner but decided to wait. I'll leave the memory of that velvety duck percolating in my mind for another few days...let the anticipation build up. That way it'll feel like the first time all over again.
author: Valeria R.

description:
IF POLICE OFFICERS EAT HERE, THEN YOU KNOW IT MUST BE GOOD.

Went on a food run here today and got the Roast Duck over rice to-go. It was only $4.75! which, for roast duck is as cheap as you can get. The duck was not just skin and bones like other places I've had it and the butcher actually gives you good portion sizes. It's topped off with some steamed cabbage and soy sauce that soaks in with the rice magically.

There's also other poultry that looks mouth watering so I'll have to come back soon! Too bad they don't have any hot sauce.. I'm not too fond of the oily chili flakes but can't blame em.
author: Albert L.

description:
great portion nice price.
I love that they ask if we want the Char siu fatty or lean
I like it lean.
author: Rina C.

description:
I saw the reviews and thought I should finally try this place.

We had the duck rice plate and bbq pork. The BBQ pork was pretty good but overall just felt a little gross after eating it. Amazing $5 prices but yeah, not totally blown away. it didn't help that the chef had this ginormous mole with the longest hair ever sticking out of it...
author: Karen S.

description: You won't write a review unless it's super good or super bad. Kam Po is the former one. Every time I get a chance to go to San Francisco, no matter whether I am hungry, I always stop by and have my special triple combo meal. Although the service there maybe not that perfect but the FOOD definitely worth it, let alone the incredibly  reasonable price! Just go and get ready to be blown away!
author: 峤

description: Good..straight up  chinese food.  Super huge portions and cheap.  If your starving great place to stuff your gut.  99percent locals who couldnt have been nicer and tried to help us order
author: Steven K.

description:
CHEAP. DELICIOUS. FILLING. CHEAP

What more can you ask for if you can get a decent meal for just about $6! My favorite go to choice is the Roasted Duck with Lo Mien OR Wonton Soup. Regardless, they're both delicious and filling. These go around $5.

The place is packed during lunch and dinner time so be sure to get there early to snag a spot. It's so popular that they always seat small parties on the same table and just hustle and bustle the flow to get customers full and going.
author: Joyce M.

description:
Great little spot if you want classic Chinese in China town!  The plates are big!  I recommend the garlic broccoli.  

The duck wonton soup is great and also comes with chow win noodles in it, so no need to order another noodle dish.

Also, they only accept cash!
author: David W.

description:
Key word is CHEAP but quality is not sacrificed

Rice plate with choice of BBQ item is $5. Not $5 and some change, just $5. Char siu and roast duck are both great here. When you get it to go they fill up a whole box with rice, throw some veggies on the side, and load it up with greasy meat. Perfect for anybody on a budget.
author: Harry T.

description: How about the guy that cuts my meat don't handle bacteria and disease infested cash and then touch my meat which leads me to have diarrhea or worse and then they will deny it because I can't prove it. Fucking sick.
author: U L.

description:
PLEASE LOOK AT THE PHOTO I POSTED BEFORE GOING THERE.

The table top containers looked like they haven't been cleaned in months!!! 

The food was really greasy but cheap and the portions were generous. If you are okay with the EEK factor than this is the restaurant that suits you. For me, I think not
author: Pamela I.

description: The roasted duck is succulent and so moist! This will definitely be my go to for roasted duck when I find myself in the Chinatown area.
author: Chauanh D.

description: Pork & Duck, their best in meat.  This place has been here since I was a little fry.  It doesn't have all the decor & glamour, but they don't need it.  When Asian businesses open up in Chinatown, it stays like that forever, the same, things falling apart.  Americans tend to fuss over furniture, seating, accommodations, etc.  Kam Po may not have all the glitz looking at it from the outside in, but it works.  Nothing changes hardly but they have it going on with a stream of patrons.
author: BanBan B.

description:
Oh Hell Yes! WTF?
This is so deep shit!
Must to get the HK style BBQ duck because, thin crispy skin and flavorful juicy meat.

I hate myself for loving the Kam Po!

Midnight, gettin' uptight, where are you?
You said you'd meet me, now it's quarter to two
I know I'm hangin' but I'm still wantin' the Suckling Pig
Hey, Kam Po, it's a fact they're talkin' in town
I turn my back and you're messin' around
I'm not really jealous, don't like lookin' like a clown
I think of the Roast Duck every night and day
The Roast Duck took my heart and the Suckling Pig took my pride away
I hate myself for loving the Suckling Pig
Can't break free from the things that you do
I wanna walk but I run back to your Roast Duck over rice to-go.
That's why I hate myself for loving your HK BBQ duck 
Daylight, spent the night without your Roast Polk
But I've been dreamin' 'bout the lovin' the Suckling Pig
I won't be as angry 'bout the hell you put me through
Hey, man, bet you can treat me right
You just don't know what you was missin' last night
I wanna see your face and say forget it just for spite
I think of the Suckling Pig every night and day
It took my heart and it took my pride away
