I hate myself for loving the 1/2 roast chicken meat & 1/2 bbq pork over rice 

I hate myself for loving Kam Po!

..... shit, I feel like I am seriously drugged by tons of msg ..... and going to Hell .... tomorrow morning, ...... hope I can still wake up,..... and take a shit .... if I could ,... it'll be A bomb. Did you know that HK style bbq duck gets me a big bomb every next morning. every time I said my self, "I hate myself for eating the shit!!!"
I will be dying, on X'mas day.

Up date, I'm still alive! Merry X'mas!
author: Nobu K.

description:
Huge portion of no frill Chinese delicatessen. Super duper cheap that makes you wonder what you got yourself into. Most people leave with a takeaway box after their meal.  Hidden away from the touristy spot of Chinatown itself. Wish I didn't have to tell anyone about it. 

Ps. If you're extremely sensitive to how clean a restaurant has to be or spend too much time wondering if that table was well wiped down, please avoid this place...or Chinatown entirely. This place is clean enough but I know people who can't stand slightly damp tables. Heads up.
author: Amolrada T.

description: I've been coming here since I was an infant.  It's a family favorite and I appreciate that in the past 20+ years I've been a customer -- not much has changed.  The duck and roast pork from kam po is my favorite in all of the Bay Area.  Can't beat the prices of this historic Chinatown spot.
author: Dylan M.

description:
To me this is as comforting as it gets; wonton noodle soup, duck noodle soup, you name it, you got it! To be truly honest, the roast duck is right on, it's juicy and fragrant. Good place for a quick lunch and with the crazy hilltop winds, you're served with a cup of hot Chinese tea, and i mean HOT! 

Maybe the place doesn't look much, but it has that hong kong old coffee house vibes, somewhere to get a great and easy bite without having to put on a suit. Parking might be a little bit of a pain, but if you want great food, then you'll probably just have to find one to stop by.
author: Ann Hui Y.

description:
2.0 Stars. I am biased. I know Kam Po can do better. They are off their game.

Their portions are still very big. Unfortunately, their prices are not rock bottom cheap.
They used to do a better job at tenderizing their beef or at least used better quality beef. My ordered bitter melon w/ Beef over rice. The beef was a bit chewy. Good hefty portion of rice.

I ordered their Duck Won Ton Soup and it was $5.80. That's about the market rate. That's a problem... Kam Po is known to be cut rate...now they are on par price-wise. I think I counted 6 won tons in the soup. I believe it used to be 8. The won tons do not seem as tasty as in the past plus they're smaller, too. The Duck was still tender and juicy as always. Thank God. If they had messed up their duck...what's the point in visiting Kam Po's anymore.

I keep coming back because I do enjoy their duck, the waitress with the pixie haircut is hospitable, and they validate the Chinatown Park N' Ride ticket.
author: Winston W.

description:
This place is really terrible.
Dirty, smelly.
Waitress has bad manner, rude.
Here doesn't accept card.
I ordered hainanese chicken rice and I got terrible salty boiled chicken rice, soup came when I'm almost done. Waitress asked for tips that she doesn't deserve.
author: Natcha N.

description: I come here to eat dinner with my mom sometimes. It's one of those places that I like coming here with my mom. I think the food is great! The place feels a little dirty though.
author: Hina W.

description: Super legit. I always love being the only white couple in a joint. Hong Kong style noodles and the Mongolian beef are standouts
author: Martin R.

description:
Great fast food styled Chinese food. It is really popular in the area and really cheap. During rush hour you may have to share a table with people if you really need to eat. The atmosphere really gives you a sense of Chinatown. It looks ok in the photos but it more like one of those holes in the wall type restaurants. 

Food I recommend:

-- The duck with rice
-- Mongolian beef fried noodles (custom not on menu)
author: Andrew W.

description: The roast duck and barbecue pork over rice is delicious and best deal at $8.50. It's a typical loud Chinese restaurant with dodgy hygiene but it's what it is. Authentic hole in the wall.
author: N A.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. They have authentic Chinese food for a very low price. You get a massive portion of food tasty  which is always good for taking home for a late night snack.

Only problem is that they barely speak english, so do not try to make some extra wishes. They probably get it wrong....which can be really surprising in some cases!

Defiantly best restaurant in china town!
author: Laurens F.

description:
This place has seriously gone done from previous times I've come. The food is salty and bland at the same time. I don't know how they do it but my chicken chow Marin had such salty vegetables and super tasteless chicken. The noodles were probably the best part of the dish. Just the noodles. Maybe the sauce that they were fried in helped a bit. 
When the bill came, and in the middle of packing up our leftovers, the waitress hurriedly comes back and waits for the bill. Instead of adding tip I decide to hold off and she asks about the tip. I tell her since she's in such a hurry she can pick it up later. I hate being asked for tips. I know this is in Chinatown and I shouldn't expect anything better but c'mon. Seriously? Can you not wait? Pissed me off. If my mom was not there leaving the tip I would leave nothing and tip her with some advice to treaty he customers a lot better and not ask for your tip.
author: Alex T.

description: One of the best places in the city! Sure the BBQ rice plates are the way to go but it is good to try other thing due to the great prices.
author: Mister T.

description:
Look, it's Chinatown.  You're not going to Chinatown for ambiance or cleanliness (unless that ambiance is greasy counters and bad service).  You're going specifically to Kam Po for the amazing duck.  I have the distinct suspicion that anyone that's complaining about the cleanliness has never been to foreign countries and ate at the local street-food-type establishments.  I mean, that's why you're in Chinatown in the first place, right?  Authenticity?

As for the people complaining that the food there isn't that good, I have no idea about the other food there because I only go for the duck.  Just like I only go to McDonald's for a Big Mac not dessert and I only go to Peet's for coffee and not lunch.  I don't know why people would go to a place known for its duck and order beef and broccoli.  

Get a whole roast duck or a $5 duck plate lunch; and if you're that big of a wimp, take it to go.  You won't regret it.
author: Matt S.

description: Here's the dirty on this place:  It's dirty.  But if you can get over that hurl, I meant "hurdle",  the duck, roast pork and the bbq pork is what's popular here.  We also like to order the curry Singapore Rice noodles, you order this and other menu dishes from the Lady, not with Mr. Cleaver.  Mr. Cleaver, the deli guy with the stern look, he doesn't like anyone, so don't take it personally.  Here's how you can have a smooth transaction: Know which cut of meat you would like before you get up to him. Would you like your pork fatty,  a bit fatty or with little fat, do you want a young duck or a large duck.  Just to let you know, a little fatty on the pork is the better choice of the three.  Have your money out, the longer you take the greasier your bag will be when he hands it to you.  It's a sick game, and I know it's "fowl"  here, but they do good chinese bbq here.
author: Chris O.

description:
i love this place! For less than $7, you can get a lot of food that is not only tasy but also authentic. 

the last time i was here, i ordered the claypot rice. the waitress told me i had to wait 30 mins, i told her fine. The wait was worth it! the flavoring of the meats and rice was amazing. Along with a side bowl of their house made soy sauce... perfect! 

for $7 I got a generous portion of claypot rice, complementary winter melon soup and a plate of bak choy. Definitely worth it!
author: Connie M.

description:
We came into Kam Po on a rainy Tuesday evening around 7:45 and sat right down without a wait. The menu is extremely extensive, but the husband and I are boring people, so I ordered the yang chow fried rice and he got chicken chow mein. And apparently both dishes come with soup, because we got soup without ordering it.

But ohhh... the pork! The BBQ pork in the yang chow fried rice is so delicious it should be criminal. Both of us stuffed ourselves and declared we were finished multiple times only to find our forks drawn back to the plate of fried rice for "just one" more bite of pork. 

Our entire meal came to around $10, and we took most of the chow mein and what little was left of the fried rice home, which was more than enough for my lunch the next day.

An elegant night out this place is not, but it's cheap, fast, delicious, and provided lunch the next day, which adds up to four stars in my book.
author: Whitney G.

description:
My "other" go to place in china town...

I usually go to Yee's because it's closer to work and I dig their happy hour but sometimes I'll trek the extra couple of blocks to Kam Po.

First of all, Kam Po is almost always busy and there's little space; it's a squeeze to get in most of the time and if you are a larger person I would avoid it altogether.  Second; this place is pretty dirty, I haven't gotten sick yet (I eat here about twice a month) but if dingy restaurants are a turn off than don't bother.

So, why five stars?  The food is awesome and relatively cheap.

My favorite?  The roast pork lo mein!  The roast pork is super tasty and I love crackled skin; simply amazing.  The lo mein noodles come with oyster sauce and some steamed cabbage and a side soup.  The soup seems to be whatever extra pieces of whatever they have lying around thrown into a broth; sometimes it's just a broth with a  few pieces of unidentifiable goodness, other times it's packed with unidentifiable goodness. It think it's $5.60 or something; awesome meal.

I've tried their other stuff and it's all good; congee, noodle soups, etc. etc. but I always come back for the roast pork.

If you are an adventurous eater, enjoy real chinese food, and can put up with a dingy crowded restaurant than this place is for you; it's a genuine hole-in the wall treasure.  If you're looking for fine dining, keep walking.
author: D D.

description:
Ordered beef with veggies over rice....one of the simplest dishes to make.  Very little beef even for $6 a plate. Service was quick and efficient but the portion was very small.  Taste was good but not great. 
I've gotten bigger servings of beef from a gourmet food truck and we know their portions aren't big!
author: Doug W.

description: I have no idea how this place received a health score 86/100. They must have cleared the restaurant for a day and all night. I eat here because it's cheap and convient to my job. Other than that its beyond filthy though.
author: Tasha L.

description: Sorry I'm not a fan. Don't know why people are raving about this place. The duck is good. But so are all of the other million places in Chinatown... If you wanna wait 30 mins for an order and deal with a rude waiter/meat cutter..... Then be my guest. I won't be coming back here. I came here because I thought It was crowded so I assumed it would be good. Don't be fooled. Sometimes crowded places are not necessarily the best...
author: Eileen W.

description:
Hole in the wall- good food. I grew up in this ghetto CT and this has to be one of the dirt cheapest place for some artery clogging food. I ordered my two item and quickly finished it. It was a surprise to myself-- since I have been on strike with eating rice... I scarfed down the yummy food.. and was so happy I wanted to buy some to go! 
One of the best Chinese BBQ hole in the wall to go to!
author: Monika T.

description:
Great prices, tasty food, big portions. 
They have the usual selection of Chinese food, with porridge choices that get under $4 a serving. 
The only thing is that since their kitchen is so open and they walk in and out of it a lot, the seating can be a tad sticky. Utensils and plates are always clean though.
author: Karen C.

description:
What a big no no.

I picked this place only because we were being mad rushed by Mr. Rushy Rushmore who wanted to pick the first dirty hole in the wall he saw - granted, we were all about to eat each other because none of us had eaten for hours- so we were all power walking - in hot pursuit for a decent looking CLEAN place to eat.  

(Note - next time, bring more quarters for the parking meter.)
I insisted we eat at a place with hanging ducks, which McRushmore was fighting me every hungry step of the way. The reason I wanted duck so much was because I wanted to compare the duck in SF compared to the best duck I had which is still in Philly.  

So which bullhead wins? Soju Soldier has nothing on Mademoiselle B - please. But she is a gentle soul so she does pick the 1st hanging duck restaurant she sees for Tiffy & Ricky are just innocent victims in this tug of yelp war.

So, we sit down at our first table. That day was a little chilly - so I have no idea why the restaurant had the air or a fan on full blast. So I suggested we move to another table. The others obliged because everyone was chillin like a villian as well.

So we sit in the cut of this restaurant and even though we were pretty much the only patrons other than 2 other tables - service is less than prompt. 

We ordered only 4 dishes and didnt eat so much as inhaled the food. 
All of us were in serious grub mode. Every plate was polished.

Here's what we had...
1.Beef Chow Fun (I always order this when I'm at a Chinese Restaurant) this had no flavor and no color. the worst I've ever eaten.

2.Crispy Pork - the best dish - it was not oily, the breading was crispy and the pork was lean. 

3.Mixed Vegetalles Dish as they call it - had bean curd and thin glass noodles in it as well - pretty yummy - just wished they used more fresh veggies instead of the canned vegetables 

4.Duck on Rice bowl - no duck meat was on the tiny 6 pieces of duck we were supposed to receive. Should be called duck skin on rice bowl.

NOTE: I am a fantastic food photographer even with my old digital camera so do not be deceived by my photography skills and be suckered eating here.
 
All in all - I say a yummy, non-rushed, leisurely meal was wasted by eating here.
author: Enjella L.

description:
Crazy cheap. Crazy good. Crazy busy!

Food = plentiful, savory, delicious, and just filling!  Presentation = good.  Noodles, rice, wonton soup, congee/jook, and some stir fry dishes.  Come here for their BBQ though... innards, duck, roast pig, BBQ pork, etc.  Oh yeah...the duck here is LEAN.  No, not fat-free, lardbutt, I said LEAN (as in not all fat!)

Service = hustle, bustle but super friendly!

Decor = throwback to 1980's NY Chinatown joints.  

Seating = simple tables and chairs.  If it's busy, expect to sit with a bunch of unknown people.  They'll keep the tabs SEPARATE.  

Prices = cheap! Cash only, yo!

Overall, we'll be back...whether it's take out for dinner fix or quickie lunch fix.

Quasi-Chinese Lesson of the Day: 
Kam Po...is the same phrase as the words Kung Pao (in Chinese characters)...which is derived from  gng bo , literally, palace guardian.
author: Fannie S.

description: My girlfriend and I just found a MAGGOT in her Chinese broccoli. We politely told them, showed it to them, and they did nothing. We told them we wanted to leave, and they brought the check! Haha. Left a $20, won't be back. It took this to happen for my first ever Yelp review. I'll stick to Henry's Hunan.
author: Curt P.

description:
Okay so I am pretty much a fanatic of all things duck. Roast duck is what I refer to as "O.G Duck" (Original Gansta Duck) since it's the first kind I ever had. I've been eating it since I was a wee munchkin and have experienced very awesome versions and not so awesome version. 

Kam Po had the former - the duck was succulent, wasn't just bone and skin like some places (although I'll never turn down duck skin, let's be real). It was greasy, yes, but wasn't overly so. Super flavorful, delicious, moist, everything chinese roast duck should embody. 

Here's where 2 stars (and potentially three) were deducted. I walked in at 7pm on a Saturday. The restaurant was somewhat busy but there were a few tables open. Everyone was already eating already so in theory, I should have been helped right away right? 

WRONG. 

I was ordering half a roast duck to go. I walk in, say hello. Three guys, include the butcher, look up. No response. The waiter goes back to filling tea kettles. The dishwashers continue washing. The butcher goes back to putting lids on condiment containers full of sauce. NO ONE ACKNOWLEDGES ME. 

I literally watched the butcher put lids on 30 sauce containers ( I know bc I had enough time to count all them) and then he started putting them away in a box before I cleared my throat loudly and asked to be helped. 

At that point it was pretty smooth sailing (minus some english/chinese language barriers). Regardless, I understand when you go to Chinatown, especially one known for FOOD, you will get shitty service. This is to be expected. But at least when I walk into most places, they acknowledge your existence. Jesus. 

Anyway, I will go back maybe but will continue to shop around. If y'all know of anywhere that does Roast Duck better, holla at me.
author: Carmen K.

description:
Likes: inexpensive Chinese food, quick service, fish congee, won ton noodles, dry pan fried beef flat noodles, pork with the crispy skin

Dislikes: didn't really like the won ton for some reason, tasted funny.  parking not
author: Karen M.

description: I came here with my brother when he came to visit me here in SF. He said he wanted "authentic crispy duck". Authentic crispy duck is what we got! The duck was so flavorful and absolutely fantastic. We ordered a whole duck, kung pao beef, sweet and sour chicken, and bok choy. All of our items were absolutely phenomenal. I'm looking forward to coming back here again.
author: Noa R.

description:
My buddies told me about $5 duck rice plate for a while now and I was thinking " wow what a great deal, lets go try it one day!".

Well that day finally came and as you can see from the score I gave them, you can tell shit probably happened. We sat in and I was excited waiting for this duck rice plate my friend kept boasting about. Our food finally came and as I was eating half way in, I realized a lot of my duck pieces were pinkish. I looked at both my friends' ducks and it was gray, so I thought something is wrong here. 

My friend called the lady to the table and I spoke to her in Cantonese. I asked her, "how come my duck is so red?" She replied only one piece was red and I was flipping through all the pieces I did not eat and I pointed out that my friends' ducks weren't red or pink at all! She kept denying the restaurant's mistake and told me to take it home and microwave it! What a slap in the face to the customer. 

I did not tip them at all because most of my food was inedible... I will not come back no matter what people say about this place. Surprisingly a high rated restaurant turns out to be illegitimate. If you go home with a stomach ache, I would not be surprised. 

Food sucked and service sucked, that's a double zero. If you are hungry in Chinatown and have a tolerance for crap, then be their guest. They will be happy to get $5 from you, I am sure of it.
author: Victor Q.

description: I'm not sure why this place gets all the 4 and 5 star ratings.   It was ok for was ok for what it is but I'd say average at best.  I am from NY who has the best China town there is.  I guess I had my hopes too high.   This place would not make it in the big apple.
author: Shane C.

description:
This is my new favorite Cantonese restaurant in SF. It reminds me so much of the dirty and grungy restaurants that I frequented when I lived in China -- none of which would ever pass a standard health inspection, but all of which are always crowded because of authentic, delicious Chinese food at outrageously low prices.

If you can stomach the unsanitary environment (including very questionable silverware -- e.g., deep brown stains on white soup spoons) and don't mind stuffing yourself into a crowded, loud space (during weekend lunch rush hours), then you're in for quite a treat at Kam Po. 

I'm actually surprised at how good the service is here -- on the surface, Kam Po should have the laughably-horrible customer service that we've all come to accept and love from Chinatown restaurants. The two waitresses were unbelievably busy, but always made time to come fill up our tea and bring us whatever we wanted. They even cracked a smile once or twice.

The most entertaining spectacle of the restaurant, however, is the butcher behind the counter, elevated as if on a stage. This is someone who possesses a razor-sharp butcher knife as an extension of his arm, slicing and chopping through pork ribs and duck necks in a way that looked strangely artistic. You could imagine a Beethoven symphony playing in the background as he beautifully butchers the back bones of a suckling pig. Benihana performances ain't got nothing on Kam Po. 

--------------------------------------

FOOD:

Roast Pork = Incredible. The skin was perfectly crispy and the meat was unbelievably tender and juicy. We got there a little late, so the meat was a little cold from hanging on the hook throughout the morning, but the juiciness wasn't compromised in any way. I can only imagine how delicious it must be immediately after cooking.

Roast Duck = Pretty good. I'm more of a fan of the Beijing-style roast duck with the crispy skin than this kind, where the skin is soggy from sweet and sour sauce. The meat was very tender, but I just don't really like having it drenched in so much sauce.

Preserved Egg & Pork Porridge = Possibly the best preserved egg porridge I've had in San Francisco. There are so many full flavors packed into this porridge that it makes every bite delicious.

Garlic Sauteed Pea Shoots = Loved it. It's a little oily, but the garlic flavors explode with each bite. The pea shoots are very nicely stir-fried, without being overcooked like they usually are. Keep in mind that it's actually pretty-hilariously written in Chinglish as "Garlic Pea Sharts" on the menu. I want to give Kam Po an extra star just for that.

Total: $20 after tax & tip. Yes, it was seriously that cheap.

--------------------------------------

Kam Po is like a wonderful slice of the true Chinese neighborhood experience. I've tried many restaurants and delis in Chinatown whose food is comparable to (and probably even better than) that of Kam Po, but Kam Po definitely delivers the full experience that I love most about Chinese restaurants.
author: Roy C.

description: This place has really really good food. Got two different chow fun dishes, green vegetables, soup, roasted duck, and pork. (Yes my family eats a lot...). Everything was delicious and cheap! Service was fast too. Would definitely come back!
author: Carolin F.

description:
Tried this place because I passed by and the smell of wonton noodle soup drew me in. That's how my bf and I found our beloved wonton place in HK so we thought we had found the ONE in SF. 

However, this place was a bit disappointing. The staff of two middle-aged women were welcoming and super nice. We got the huge chicken leg as a side and duck wonton noodle soup. The chicken leg had good flavor on the skin- soy sauce-y but the insides were a bit too dry. THe wonton noodle soup base was good and light. THe wontons were pretty good-had a lot of shrimp and yellow chives. However the noodles were not so good. Tasted wheaty and a bit dry. Did not have any elasticity. 

But haven't tried any other bbq meat/wonton place in SF so I'm not sure how this is compared to them. It's decent I guess.. but nothing compared to the ones I've had in HK or NY's Big Wong.
author: Elizabeth N.

description: The best roast duck and roast pork in Chinatown. The Chow fun and HK style pan fried noodles (chow mein) are top notch too. Very good Wonton, meaty morsels wrapped in just the right thickness of Wonton skin. Atmosphere for dining is undesirable, prefer to order to go. The food is actually deserving of 4.5 star rating.
author: Paul L.

description: Cheap, quick fix if your hungry. Little on the oily side but what you expect from a fast Chinese joint. I go here weekly
author: Tinh T.

description: Was looking for a place to eat for cheap in Chinatown and a friend of mine suggested Kam Po to eat dinner. When we first sat down the table was a bit sticky and was a bit cramped with small tables but I don't really mid that as long as the food is food. We ordered seafood food rice and it can pretty fast and the flavoring was pretty good and it also came with house soup. Would return to try some of there B.B.Q. later on.
author: Peter C.

description: Kam Po has, hands down, the best BBQ pork in the city. The porridges are authentic and delicious as well. It's nice to know that I can always count on piping hot porridge any day of the year since they are open all year round. Take note that they do not have a takeout menu available and it is cash only.
author: Jessica K.

description:
San Francisco has some really great Chinese "chop" houses serving up heaping dishes of BBQ duck, BBQ and roasted pork, and several varieties of chicken over rice, but there is only one the I've been coming to consistently with my dad over the years.  Taking a break from our urban exploring, my buddy and I decided to drop in for some solid Chinese food to fill our empty bellies.

We decided to sample a little bit of everything and ordered two-item plates of BBQ pork, cold-boiled chicken, roasted pork, and soy sauce chicken over rice.  While the cleanliness is a bit suspect, all of their meats are top quality for a Chinese restaurant.  Everything was very meaty and generally devoid of excessive fat, and the portions were huge.  If we knew that we wouldn't have to walk around with it for the rest of the day, we probably would have taken the leftovers home.  In fact, there was so much food that we probably could have just shared a single plate between the two of us.

Whenever I'm in North Beach, I'm pretty much drawn toward Kam Po for lunch.  It's a fantastic bargain and I would normally be able to make two meals out of the one, saving a lot of time and money while enjoying great food.  For the price of a fast food meal, I can get some of the best, authentic, Hong Kong-style BBQ short of actually going to Hong Kong!

Food: 9/10

Service: 6/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 6/10
author: Joe M.

description: Food was pretty decent.  Foo Young BBQ Pork with Rice was not what we expected at all.  The prices were very affordable, we haven't seen prices like these at a Chinese restaurant in years!  I posted pictures of the menu if you don't believe me.  The food was not particularly amazing, but the for the price, I would definitely come again!
author: Alissa Y.

description:
I always always always come back to Kam Po for lunch whenever I'm in Chinatown. Even if I'm stopping by, I'll get a box to go. The best is the roast pork and the FRIED RICE! Omg, the aromas of all the meats mixed together with the rice makes me drool every time. At $4 a rice plate, you really wonder if they are even making a profit. So cheap! And they give you a lot of rice and a side of veggies AND delicious complimentary soup.

Don't come expecting excellent service or anything- the restaurant is CROWDED. You'll be sitting with other people, your tables are less than a foot away, and it'll get awkward. But it's all a part of the experience! Sit down, don't put your bags in the aisles, shut up, and eat your food. It's Chinatown.
author: Sally C.

description:
Still a fan.  Last meal there was ok - soup noodle was lacking a little flavor but you still can't beat the price, portion and speed.  

For the first time, we ordered stuff to go.  We called to order soy sauce chicken over rice and a beef chow fun to go on our way home and they were ready when we got there less than 10 minutes later...here's the topper, $8.90!  2 orders including tax - $8.90!  Crazy.  It was damn good too. 

We ordered to go again.  This time, roast duck over rice and bitter melon and beef pan fried noodles - $9.80!  Still under $10!  

Fast, cheap, large portion...this is the place.
author: Gloria H.

description:
OK - I love finding the "out of way" local place that serves authentic food for a good price.  This is that place!  If you are looking for an American restaurant that is clean and neat where you do not have to rub shoulders, stay away!  

We walked in and the waitress asked a local to share a table and gave us the 4-top where he was sitting (we had 4 people).  At first I was worried that the other couple would be offended by the disorder or the ducks hanging in the window or possibly the large cooked pig that was hanging by its rear legs with cooked juices dripping in to the sink.  Thankfully, they were as adventurous as us!  

The food was amazing, the service was fun to watch, and the entire time we were dining, we were the only Caucasians in the place.

LOVE IT!!!!  Get the duck!
author: Chris J.

description:
Loved the shared tables at this place -- we shared with two old Chinese ladies and tried to order what they did. But they ordered so much food, we couldn't keep up! There was bbq pork, steamed chicken, wonton soup, fried rice ... it just went on and on. 

Kam Po was very cheap, though other reviewers are right about the sticky tables and cramped conditions. Also, it's pretty tricky to figure out what to order (and you can go really wrong that way), so it's best to read more detailed Yelp reviews before arriving (which we hadn't).

Kam Po was lively and fast, but I didn't think the food was actually that spectacular. It certainly has a dedicated local following, so they must be doing something right.
author: Jesse A.

description:
Just as I was complaining to a friend that there were no cheap Chinese places of quality to eat in Chinatown I found this place.  

My friend and I stuffed ourselves from a plate of HK style house chow mein and Hainan chicken for $10.50 including tax.  And it came with free house soup.  Given we had to pack the leftovers home, it came to like $3 per person per meal tip included.  That's what I call good price-value ratio.  Actually, that's what I call - "time to stop cooking because it's cheaper to eat out."  That's it.  I'm done with cooking.

I'd had HK Style House Special Chow Mein at a few other places, but they were usually like $10.  Granted you didn't get a tonne of seafood (just shrimp), but there were generous portions of meat.  Instead of being dried gross BBQ pork, their slices were tender.  I guess they must be popular for their BBQ stuff as there was a lineup out the door when I walked in.

Don't use the bathroom though.  Or practice getting really good at holding your breath for very long extended periods of time first.  I don't know how I didn't pass out immediately from the toxic fumes from that thing.  Ewwness.
author: Pokin Y.

description:
There are two things for certain when coming to Kam Po: 1) you'll probably be eating at a greasy-looking table wiped down by a towel about 3 months past its prime; 2) the food will be ridiculously good. So if you can overlook #1 (when did we all become such sissies in SF?), then you're in for a treat.

Kam Po is definitely my go-to spot when I'm hankering for roast duck, roast pork, bbq pork, or any other culinary treat that can be hooked and dangled in front of a window. In particular the roast duck wonton noodle soup is my favorite in the city. The wontons are super flavorful, perfect ration of meat to wrapper without that weird gummy consistency, and don't make me feel like I'm eating dumpling bought from Costco; and they are definitely not at all skimpy on the roast duck portion which is more than generous.

Kam Po is one of those places that actually feels and looks like what one would imagine to be an authentic Chinatown restaurant.

Looking forward to my next bowl of soup!
author: David H.

description: Service here can be crazily bad! We waited 25mins just for them to take order. Food are not bad, but I don't think you can enjoy the food anyways with this bad service.
author: Qiaosi C.

description:
Definitely a hole in the wall. One waitress for the whole place (albeit a small place). But the crowded tables tell you that people think it's worth the wait and then some!

Dishes were ordered for me and everything tasted pretty great. Just ignore the fact that the waitress takes orders left, handles money, wipes down tables, and serves food without washing her hands between any of it. :D

8 people were fed dinner for under $60, with leftovers for the next morning. Definitely a bargain in San Francisco.
author: Eva N.

description: Yum!  Great, authentic Chinese food! I was very pleased with the food each time I came here with friends.  However, the environment wasn't the best.  The bowls and tableware was sometimes dirty-ish, and the bathroom is a bit scary.  Feels just like China though.
author: Aishan S.

description:
Crazy cheap Hong Kong BBQ joint!  I was afraid to order the congee (they have a dozen kinds) because it was so cheap (under $3) and no one had ordered any.  Rice and noodle plates seemed to be the most popular items.  You can get pig's feet, organs, kidney, tendon and liver.  We shared a table with a guy who was digging into beef & bittermelon with rice.  It's a full size dish for $3.50!  And you get free hot tea.  Don B. accidentally drank someone else's tea!

I ordered dumplings ($3) figuring that was a safe bet.  You get 7 large dumplings, some bok choy and a shrimpy broth.  The dumplings had very thin skins and they were filled with chopped shrimp, wood ear fungus, bamboo shoots, chives, etc.  They were good but I was hoping for juicy pork dumplings.  These weren't juicy.  I had two cubes of their roast pork - one piece was very chewy and dry and the other was pretty good.  

It looks like Kam Po has been here forever.  They've got ducks and pigs hanging in the BBQ area.  People share sticky tables in close proximity and the place is filled with Cantonese (locals I presume).  A true hole in the wall. I gave them another star just for their prices. It must be cash only.
author: Lolia S.

description:
Kam Po Kitchen's updated their menus for 2010 (see pictures) and now includes clay pot Porridges and clay pot rices.

The prices are a tad higher than before but it's still a great place to go for $5-6! I've never eaten here, but we always order stuff to go every week all year long! Although it can take 30 minutes before it's ready, the clay pot rice dishes are excellent. Their porridges are always a good choice to warm your body.

The Roast Duck, Roast Pork and Soy Sauce Chickens great choices for when you're to lazy to prepare the "meat" at home.

Other favorites include: Singapore Style Vermicelli, Beef with Scramble Eggs over rice and Beef Stew Won Ton Noodle Soup
author: Peter L.

description: If you're looking for a cheap chinese meal, this is the place to go. The portions are also quite big considering the amount you pay.  The roast pork was very fatty and juicy. However, the wonton skin was not as silky smooth as I normally prefer.
author: Tina W.

description: Food had little flavor. Had soup, fried rice and a tofu dish. Would not go back.
author: Sara R.

description: Service is terrible. Duck won ton soup is mediocre at best. Perplexed on why this place is so highly rated when there are far better gems in Chinatown. Skin on the duck was not crispy, broth had bits of bone debris in it. Yuck.
author: Arthur N.

description:
This place is a true Chinatown hole in the wall that has CHEAP food in remarkably large quantities. 4 stars for the large quantity and cheapness, 3 stars for the food taste.

I ordered the roast duck and beef chow fun. The beef chow fun lasted me at least 3 meals. Really greasy, but super worth the $4.30 I paid. The roast duck was probably drenched in sodium, but it was still pretty good with the rice underneath. Also less than $5. What a steal.

Atmosphere is very grungy-esque, but still, lots of people on a Tuesday evening.
author: Adele Z.

description:
First time at this spot out of the many, many times I've been to Chinatown. It is sort of hidden on Powell and Broadway away from all the other restaurants off of Stockton and the lower part of Broadway. It was one of the only places open at around 7pm on a weekend. I was with two of my white friends who had never been to Chinatown before and hardly ever eat Chinese food. I felt bad for bringing them to some place that I've never been to, but it turned out to be OK.

Walking in this place looked like any other to-go Chinese place with roasted duck and chicken hanging in the window and cooked foods in heated plates on the side. However, they also had a good amount of seating on the inside. There were a good amount of people. Couples, families, and just random people there to grab dinner. It took a while for us to get seated and a menu because there was only one "hostess" who was running around taking orders, serving, boxing, and cleaning.

We got three dishes: beef chow fun, beef broccoli chow mein, and bbq pork over rice; and  we also got a free soup. The food was extremely oily. Nothing was special as the bbq pork was fatty and dry, the beef chow fun was oily and the meat was dry, and the beef and broccoli was kind of bland. The soup was probably the best part of the meal.
author: Kevin H.

description: Nothing special here. Came for the beef chow fun and it was just OK. The people at the table next to us all got some egg noodle duck stir-fry, so maybe that's the item to order.
author: L L.

description: I got the Beef & Fried Egg Rice plate, which had a strange gelatin all over it. It looked like they poured raw egg drop soup all over it. The soup it comes with had a tasty broth. I may come back may not. Average.
author: Bonnie N.

description: So cheap and good. A Chinatown staple for roast pork, roast duck and bbq pork. Each of the meats were tender and flavorful. They are familiar to my taste buds and comforting to my tummy. The bbq meat order comes with a huge serving of rice, meat and veggies. They will ladle sauce over it. Cheap comfort food that opens til 8 pm.
author: Eve C.

description: I ordered the rice with roast duck.  It was awesome!  Very tender and flavorful duck.  The meal also came with soup and some cabbage.  My mom got the rice with roast pork.  It was good, but can't compete with the duck.  Service was good.  Everyone else dining there was Chinese. Seems like an authentic place.
author: Susan P.

description:
It's greasy. it's cheap. It's authentic.

All the roasted/barbequed pork/duck/whatever's hanging on the walls you can possibly imagine, for $5.

If this ain't your spot for Chinese food...I really don't know what is. Probably should go with someone who speaks Chinese though, otherwise ordering could get a little complicated. It's that legit.
author: Anthony L.

description: Very reasonably priced, extremely tasty.  A basic BBQ butcher counter with restaurant attached.  Staff was very accommodating of our group order, and the food was quickly prepared and delicious.  The atmosphere is not fancy, but the quality and value were outstanding!
author: Jay S.

description:
I used to come to this place after school every Saturday. It was the tradition that kept me going to Chinese school.  

The food here is good and fast. There are two women who work and they seem to have boundless energy. It might also have to do with the fact that I'm never here unless its around lunch time.

It's a small place, but the women make it work. There's really only two places to walk between tables, which makes dine-in a little less disruptive from other customers. If you're looking for a quiet place for lunch though, its not your best bet.

The food here is made very well. Most recently, I had a Chicken and Bok Choy dry Flat Noodle (I have no idea how to say this in English), and it was really good. The Chicken was lightly fried and the Bok Choy was cooked well.

The only reason I'd give this place 4 stars instead of 5 is that the silverware for dine-in is questionable and its really crowded all the time.  But that's only for dine-in. Take out is fast and great!
author: Lily W.

description:
not great but i don't know where else you can score duck for five bucks

besides, i enjoy seeing the deadstock through the glass in front
author: Clark G.

description: I was debating of going here for an early lunch or to the Mee Heong Bakery for their spareribs and rice. The bakery had 5 tables and was packed. This place had a decent amount of elderly people. And when you see elderly Chinese people in a restaurant one knows the prices are good.
author: M C.

description: If you are looking for a hole in the wall Chinese restaurant, this would be the place to go. Price is incredibly cheap and the portions are very generous. If you are not too hungry, you can definitely order 1 dish and split between two people. For certain dishes, it comes with a soup as well. But other than the great value of the food, the restaurant offers little else. The service is lacking and sanitation is questionable. But I guess you can't ask too much from a Chinese restaurant in Chinatown
author: Teresa W.

description:
A quick BBQ spot on the corner to get a quick BBQ fix. Most of the time when Im there I always ordered the BBQ pork over rice plates, besides that they have other traditional easy made fast meals typical chinese food too. If you happen to dine there, if youre lucky soup is on the house. 

Its not a nice place to be, but what can you say its cheap and good, even the police officers and meter maids stop by to eat here too.
author: Linh D.

description: Like eating at grandma's house. Everything fresh, piping hot, delicious, home cooked traditional Cantonese "comfort food." Inexpensive, fast, real. Consistent over the years. Their Cantonese BBQ is one of the best. Eaten here hundreds of times with my fam and friends and NEVER DISAPPOINTED. Good food, Aww shoot. Now I'm craving their "syu yok ap fan" (BBQ roast pork, roast duck combo rice plate lunch) and it's 1AM!! What do I do now?! Can't wait till tomorrow lunch. GOOD FOOD. nuff said.
author: George F.

description:
another 5 star review for food only.  

chinese people get scared away by this place - so this is a warning to all non chinese people - this is a hole in the wall.  its been this way for years, and the food is excellent.  ignore the fact that it looks "gross" (aka normal chinatown).

the service is fast, done by one gal who is pretty damn good at her job.

the soup noodles are top notch - we had bbq pork spareribs with noodles, and crispy roast pork with wonton mein.  both items were under $5 (each was $6 including tip).
author: Jason J.

description:
cheap, dirty, delicious. That probably sums up Kam Po Kitchen.
:)
My grandparents live up the block from this place, so I basically grew up walking past this establishment. I recently came here for dinner with my family. 

Mom: Chicken and salted fish fried rice
Dad: Peking duck over rice.
Brother: Beef and tomato with pan fried noodles with extra sauce.
Me: Fried flat rice noodles with no beef

The bill was $20.20...that's pretty damn cheap. Where else are you going to find a place with yummy Chinese food for four adults around 20 bucks in Chinatown! 

PS, the chili hot sauce on the tables are to DIE FOR.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
It was cheap. Yes, but not clean at ALL. I get it, the "hole in the wall" spot is charming and always has delicious food - but this spot just takes the cake for dirty. I appreciate small, dinky spots that are cheap and yum, but Kam Po is just too much.
I called in an order about 30 minutes before and they didn't even start cooking it until we arrived! Our won ton soup was cold, they don't have potstickers and the chow mein was bland. 
Will I be back? Maybe, it's so close, but I'll try out the other 400 options in the 5 block radius first.
Bottom line: it's dirty.
author: Francesca F.

description:
A shabby and authentic Chinese deli. (Or that's what I'm told. What do I know from "authentic Chinese deli"?) The restaurant is usually crowded, and there's a line at the counter where you try to tell the guy with the huge cleaver what you want. He's surrounded by all manner of cooked ducks, chickens, and pork ribs, plus vats of chicken-feet, intestines, and various mysterious glistening things I don't know what the hell they are. The menu is huge, full of typos and authentically contains things you wouldn't be caught dead eating, but also includes duck, pork, noodles, soup, and congee. The service at the tables is slow, and the staff's knowledge of English is spotty. 
However, the duck is wonderful. The skin is crisp and tasty, and the meat is juicy. I've had a pork and noodle dish that I really liked, and some random soup that was also good. The barbecue pork is swell too. I accidentally ordered congee (rice porridge) once, not knowing what it was, and it was filling but seriously bland. (I think it's supposed to be that way.)
The place is not as clean as it could be (I dinged it a star), and the staff gets impatient with non-Chinese speakers. But I've enjoyed my meals there, and I'll happily go back if there's an open table.
author: Paul M.

description: The place is crazy cheap for food.  You may get food poisoning but its cheap!  Most dishes are $5.  The BBQ meats are kinda gross though.  The duck is good as long as its warm.  They served cold roast pork and duck.  When these items are served cold the fat is disgusting.  I'm always sweating so my fat is nice and soft.  Getting a table is a shit show.  +1 star for the price.
author: Fatty A.

description: This place is always busy that must count for something right???  been coming here for the last 13 years and the taste of the food hasn't change a bit. The soysauce chicken, roasted duck, roasted pig is amazingly good and crunchy. From noodles to rice plate you name it im pretty sure you will love this place for their prices and great taste of chinese food
author: Allan A.

description:
I always order the duck here. And it's always 4.70 for a lunch meal. About as cheap as it gets. Seating is pretty limited so I always get it to go and eat it in the park a block away. The whole duck is great as well. A terrific design of nature. Enough fat on one bird to confit two legs, plus the carcass left over to make a sauce. It's a self contained dinner that even comes with its own cooking element.

p.s. the guy chopping up the birds has probably been working there for years but everytime I say "duck" he acts like it's the first time he's ever heard the word. If someone wants to fill me in on how to say "duck" in canto that'd be great.
author: B C.

description:
Huge portion of roast meat on rice for $7. The duck is delicious and fatty. The roast pork I had was a bit dry, so I'll probably have to try it again to see if its just a one time incident. 
Yeah, the restaurant is dirty and the tables and chairs are sticky; what else would you expect.
author: Jun W.

description:
It's cheap, greasy, and Chinese.

What's not to love?!

I came here with my in decisive sisters and after walking around Chinatown with empty stomachs, we ended up here. My sister is a regular here so she knows how to order.

Because of her, I continue to learn how to eat.
author: Karry D.

description: Kam Po Kitchen is the one place that, I have not gone back in a very very long time since my high school days!!!  I am surprise that this very old chinese restaurant is still here for such a very long time. The food item what, I like most when coming here for lunch at Kam Po was having their Hong Kong Style Pan Fried Noodle. Kam Po Kitchen is not that bad of a place their food is not that bad at all and the food prices are very cheap.
author: William B.

description:
I ordered the Roast Pork... LOVED IT! it was so flavorful, juicy, and the skin was still crispy after about 2 hours sitting in the car. 

The cha-sui was a little too fatty, next time I'll ask for non-fat instead of half and half. 

The location is good and the bbq  is cheap.
author: Elsa Y.

description: It's great! They have all your Chinese meat and butchery stuff here! Steamed chicken, BBQ pork, and some rice plates/entrees. I really like the ginger sauce that comes with the steamed chicken. It's crowded (C.Town is always crowded anyways) And it's yummy! $21 for steamed a whole chicken and 1lb bbq pork? FANTASTIC BABY!
author: Kevin C.

description:
Ambiance : -2.5 stars  (yes, minus 2.5)
Cleanliness : -2.5 stars (another minus)
Roast Duck over rice :  10 stars (a TEN? yes, indeed...)

So, they add up to 5 stars. 

This is one of those hole-in-the wall in SF chinatown that offer generous portion of authentic cantonese food for a bargain.  The grandmas and grandpas in chinatown who frequent this joint don't seem to mind the presentation but they definitely won't tolerate anything that is less than perfect roast duck, roast pork, BBQ pork, or won ton noodle.  At least that is my theory as to why their signature food is so good.
author: perry h.

description:
Oooo the memories this place brings back! Once upon a time when my parents weren't too busy from work, we actually trekked to Chinatown each weekend to spend the day grocery shopping and eating! 

I loved the days when we walked up the hill and I would get excited to order my usual, Beef Stew Ho Fun Noodle Soup. It was theeeee best! My brother always ordered the House Crispy Noodles and it was the most magical concoction I've ever heard of. They are noodles that are deep fried shaped like a bird's nest and topped with stir fried meats and veggies with sauce that makes the middle soft but retains the crunchy side of the noodle. It's a great combo. Called Chien Mein (translates as crispy noodles)  and you can have it with chicken, beef or seafood. The house crispy noodles includes intestines or livers, so if you're up for the challenge, try it!

I continued to come back here for lunch without my family when I grew up old enough to go out by myself. I brought my boyfriend here when we first started dating after school since we went to Galileo and he loved the crispy noodles! He never heard of it before and couldn't believe he was deprived for so long. It's also dirt cheap! its only about $3.50 for a whole plate that can fill you up. In fact, everything here is dirt cheap. I know it's probably not the cleanest place, but hey, I grew up in Chinatown and the food there probably helped me build immunity to a sensitive stomach and I can eat practically anything. Thank you? 

Don't think about the hole in the wall place, you'll forget all about it as soon as you see, smell, and taste the food!
author: Connie C.

description: Why oh why didn't I walk out when the couple next to me found a bug in their food. But nooooo, I stayed and how I wish I didn't. Absolutely the worst Chinese food I ever had. I had the BBQ ribs which not only tasted nasty but appeared cold. Stay away!
author: Barry P.

description: This is the best Chinese food I've ever had in US. Very authentic contonese. If you are looking for great taste, big portion and reasonable price, this is where you wanna go. More importantly, the owner of this place is great! I've been there several times and once my parents left their bags with important belongings and they kept those bags and waited for us to go back and pick up.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
Quintessential hole in the wall...and it was delicious. 

We had: roast pork and rice, roast duck noodle soup, and beef and tofu over rice. The beef and tofu was average, but the roast meat items were standouts. Looking around, I knew the place was legit because we were surrounded by old Chinese people.  Each item was less than $5. Service was super fast, though not exactly friendly. Whatever though, you come to this place for the food - especially the roasted meats. 

Can't wait to come back again!
author: Jennifer K.

description:
This place is not exactly hole-in-the-wall, but hole-in-the-wall prices for sure.

This place used to be my mother's go-to place for roasted goodies like duck, pork, chinese bbq pork, etc.  And their roasted duck tasted just like the one from Hong Kong.  Very authentic, cafeteria style eatery spot with tight seatings.  kinda dirty, kinda just like hong kong too....

5 bucks get you a nice huge lunch plate with your choice of meat with complimentary soup.  $10 bucks for 2 people with leftovers for the bf as snack.  One of my all time favorites.
author: Gigi T.

description:
Would like to start off by saying i am white. 
Pros:
-cheap
Cons:
-you get what you pay for which isnt much
-gross
-terrible service
-dirty
-dont speak English
author: zach w.

description: It's an interesting atmosphere. The interior design is more suited for a Hong Kong-style cafe but it has Chinese BBQ. Their rice plates and chow fun are pretty good. Cheap, too!
author: Henry P.

description: Really really good roast pork over rice.  The price is a deal and you will be full hours later.  The pork is moist, tender, and flavorful.  Even the cabbage is so tasty.  Be warned.  This is a local's place.  Don't be afraid that almost everything is in Chinese on the wall.  There is an english menu.   They do understand what is on the menu.  Oh, and a tip.  Make sure you know what you want before you go in.  It's crowded and busy.  Everybody wants their food right now.
author: Jack R.

description: I've only had the roast pork (siu yuk) wonton noodle soup. It's a pretty filling bowl with several wontons and a lot of roast pork. It's a pretty good deal because I paid about $8 after tip. There's actually quite a huge selection of different dishes... vegetables, rice, meats... pretty much all the standard cantonese foods. The best part about the restaurant is sitting inside facing the counter, and watching everyone at work. There's usually one waitress around who always has a smile on her face. There's another tough looking woman, whose duties revolve around managing the money, the chopping block, and serving customers. She seems like a real strict boss type, but after a while of watching her at work, you'll soon come to see that she's just a really hard-working person who means well. Finally, there's butcher who is never without his cleaver. He might be handling money when he's the only guy behind the counter, but don't misunderstand. He's here to take care of all the meat, from the roast ducks behind the window to the huge slab of siu yuk hanging as the centerpiece of the room. Everything about him from his physical appearance, demeanor, and his skill with the cleaver indicates that he is the embodiment of the original chinese deli butcher. Come if you're interested in some nice chinese food with some real characters to observe while you eat.
author: Andrew S.

description:
hahahahah...........this has to go to my list of 5 star food at 1 star places.  I haven't been here since I was a kid.  

I came here with my old roommate because it was close by and the food here is good and cheap.  I think I saw an order on the menu that was around 2.60.  I couldn't believe my eyes.  As for the food, it is pretty damn good for a hole in a wall Chinatown restaurant.  The broth on the soup was awesome, the wontons were good (not great because I have had better but for 4 bucks what can you say), the roast pork and roast duck were killer!!!

I need to start coming back to Chinatown to eat more often.  It's sorta an adventure when you haven't eaten here for a while.  I will definitely come back to this place.
author: jason g.

description: Came here since I was in SF and wanted some legit Canto food. Prices were very reasonable; our party of three ordered a roast pork and duck rice, a soy sauce chicken rice, beef chow fun, and a seafood tofu clay pot, and that came out to be around 25 dollars (plus a lot of leftovers enough for a second meal)! The roast pork was crispy on the outside, and both the duck meat and chicken were tender and juicy. Since being a legit Chinese restaurant, service wasn't the best, but we got our food in a timely manner (and the waitress seemed overwhelmed manning the whole store by herself). Would come back again if I go back to SF!
author: Raymond C.

description:
I love it here! My friends and I always come here if we want some good roast duck or roast pork over rice. Seriously, for $5 you can get that. 

This place is always PACKED! 

I remember I used to come here a lot when I was young, then I stopped because my mother got into the whole health trend. But now, screw that, I want me some crispy duck skin.

Here are a few tips if you decide to go to this restaurant:
1. Be aggressive. Don't wait around for them to notice you. Once they see you, let them know you are here and how many people you have.
2. Don't drink too much of the tea. I'm not saying the tea is dirty (it might be), but this will help you NOT use their bathroom.
3. The only things that should be ordered here are rice plates paired with some sort of roasted meat and crispy noodles.
4. Don't sit and chat with your friends like this is some sort of cafe. It's not. People around you will think you look stupid.
5. Bring your own bottle of water. 
6. Respect the waitress. She works here 7 days a week during all the hours that this restaurant is opened. She's the first one here and the last one to leave. Cut her some slack.
author: Jenny Y.

description: Do you want to be drinking water all day because of MSG?  Do you like your food hanging up at eye level with cooks snorting and sneezing all over it.  Do you like being treated like a white POS?  - Then come here.
author: Kyle K.

description: This is my favorite chinese deli to go to.  The waitress here is so funny and very efficient.  The BBQ food is awesome.  I have always had great food here.  The waitress there always makes us feel welcome.
author: remy m.

description:
I've been to quite a few Chinese restaurants in Oakland and this is my first Chinese restaurant in the city. I've finally discovered the formula to good, cheap and authentic Chinese food!

- Whole roasted duck and chicken steaming from being under heat lamps
- As many red furniture and decoration as possible. It's for good luck!
- Handwritten Chinese menu on the wall with the only understandable (to me anyway) characters being the cost. I'm SOOOO tempted to throw a dart at it and order whatever the dart falls on. =D
- Free mystery soup with your meal. It seems like the soup is whatever leftover that they have in the kitchen - spinal cord, chicken feet, carrots, mystery meat - and then they boil the mess out of it. The soup itself tastes good if you don't think too much or look too closely at what's inside the soup.
- Chili, soy sauce, vinegar, ground pepper condiments in little containers in the middle.
- Freaky (to an American anyway) menu items: frog, pig intestine, sea cucumber, hairy mushroom, etc.
- The waiters are there to take your order, give you food and drink and give you your check. That's it! Don't expect anymore from them. 
- Sticky tables. Ewwww...

The more of the above that a Chinese restaurant has, the more authentic the food will be. Kam Po has ALL of the above! I will be back for sure if I want real Chinese food and not Americanized-garbage that a lot of places...** cough ** PF Changs ** cough ** have.
author: Don D.

description:
3 n half stars

Hmm this place is your typically hole in the wall of chinatown. So the place is a little greasy and grimey. The Chinese bbq is above par roast pig bbq pork and duck. For those who are adventurist there are pig intestines , bbq chicken livers, and pork stomach stew in soy sauce. There are the tradition wonton noodles with ur choosing of a meat . Apointer if u get bbq items on soup dish always ask for it on dish, its a much better cut. This place is really inexpensive and yes its cash only and they close around 7pm.
author: Jorm K.

description: Their roast pork and BBQ pork are both pretty good . Their chicken leg is not ... it's very dry and lacks flavor . Will be back to try their chicken and roast duck .
author: Eileen L.

description: Dirty little place, but they can make jook and wonton soup any way you want it, and their roast duck is sumptuous. Very affordable prices. Don't take skittish people here, though. I haven't been back in a while, but this is the kind of place that stays precisely the same for years and years.
author: Josh K.

description: Probably one of the best places in Chinatown that I've had good duck in awhile. The service is really friendly. The food is amazing. What else can I say?
author: Claudia M.

description: This use to be my favorite place to dine until we found a roach in our food!  Never went back.
author: Marie E.

description: Food is very good and super cheap (4-6$)!! Huge portions. A typical Chinese restaurant. No beverages can be bought, only tea.
author: Ferdinand W.

description:
fan of the suckling pig.

fast and quick takeout such as beef chow fun and salty fish fried rice.

can't be too bad as this place is always packed.
author: Dorothy L.

description:
This has GOT to be the DIRTIEST restaurant on the face of the planet. I haven't been here in years but my aunt loves this place because they give u a lot of food and it's CHEAP. Who cares if the plates are still greasy and the water cups still have lip marks on them? Who cares if the waitress and meat chopping guy wipes their nose and has greasy hair? Who cares if the bathroom has probably never been cleaned since they opened?

No thank you. I'm not that desperate for cheap food.
author: Jenny T.

description:
Preserved egg w/ pork porridges - hands down. no complaints!
Bbq pork and roast duck - hands down. still no complaints!
Shrimp w/ scrambled egg chow fun - not bad. 
Seafood chow fun - huge disappointment. Not much flavor. 

Now, the bathroom.... quite disgusting and scary. But if you have been to China and survived, then you should be ok.
author: Sue C.

description: This is not going to be a fair review. I haven't had good chinese food in five months. I was missing authentic char siew and liver soup. So this was like a dream come true! Now I just wished I spoke cantonese better...
author: Eugene T.

description: Good food, big portions, great prices.  I love the rotisserie pig hanging in the kitchen!
author: Kevin P.

description:
This place's dry chow-fun is really something! Its taste is comparable to the ones I have had in Macau and Hong Kong.

Everytime I am there I order a chow-fun along with a dual-combo rice. The dual-combo consist of "white cut chicken" and bbq pork. I don't know how they do it, but it is so delicioussss! The portion is so generous that even two people cannot finish the entire plate of rice.

Their BBQ pork and fire roasted pork are to die for. The skin on the fire roasted pork is so crunchy that not any other place can compete with them in Chinatown.

-1 Star for sanitary condition...
author: Chi T.

description: On the suggestion of one coworker we went together with another coworker for lunch. He told us beforehand about the butcher and the questionable cleanliness of the place, but said the food was cheap and good - I was in. Yes, the place is crowded during lunch (thankfully we got there a little early), it's not the cleanest looking place I've been in, but the food was pretty good. We all got the roasted duck with rice and cabbage and some soup. The waitresses were busy and only checked on us once, but that was ok with me. Overall I'd definitely go back and I liked the food - roasted duck and rice for less than $5 can't beat it.
author: Travis R.

description: This is one of the few last inexpensive restaurants available in San Francisco. Most plates are less than $5 and satisfying.  Food is decent. Hygiene is not excellent but I doubt anyone had issue, that's why I give a four stars. For non-Chinese pals, you can still enjoy your meal but not expect native speaker around, most people can get away with what they want for their meal. And don't expect to be pampered, they are generally very busy.
author: P. C.

description:
This place is no freaking joke. Whoa. 

I walked up and was thinking, man, you're really trying to impress me aren't you? Just kiddinggggggggg!

But yes, it's definitely a bare bones restaurant. I had the won ton soup with roasted BBQ pork (not bad, LOTS of pork but the broth was relatively flavorless) and the roast duck on rice. The duck was good and it was an extremely generous portion. 

You could definitely get by on a really really small budget by eating here. There was more than enough food leftover for dinner which basically means you could easily eat for 4 bucks a day if you so desired roast meat galore and rice as your sole diet.
author: Alli J.

description:
Food Quality is good and food taste good.

Reasonable Price.

Recommend to go if you like chinese food.
author: Gruber T.

description: this is the spot for Chinese food. the roast duck  over rice is the bomb and only under 6 buck!!!!! it is a little dirty but the food overcompensate the service and cleanness. Some people would compelling of the service but this is the spot to eat real Chinese food
author: janet l.

description: Wow, really good simple Chinese food. The place looks like nothing but was pleasantly surprised at the food quality. The portions are really big, so it's easy to order too much. Fried rice and pad tai were delicious.
author: Lena G.

description: Ridiculously cheap, but kind of dirty and the food was pretty bland. Typical Cantonese place. I'm not a fan of bland, greasy Canto food though, but that's pretty much all you can get in Chinatown, so for what it is, this place is fairly good. Nice windows in the dining room. Bad service. And again, CHEAP.
author: Max M.

description: Great little gem in Chinatown! Great prices! Large portion and decent taste! Recently we order the tendons over veggies, claypot rice and porridge! Always come back for a cheap dinner with leftovers!
author: Maggy C.

description: Not as dirty as some had mentioned. Maybe they started to make an effort to clean up. Roast duck was great! Sweet and sour pork was great too!
author: Johnatton L.

description: Generous portions and fresh ingredients make this a clear winner at this price point.  Had the duck, pork, soup and broccoli with  garlic sauce for $21.
author: Daniel P.

description:
It is what it is. Cheap and moderate chinese food in SF Chinatown. But it's really delicious after you had a long day that included driving over 400 miles in the open road, getting lost for 2 hours searching the Macy's building and Chinatown while the navigator is passed out cold in your passenger seat and last meat had was 18 hours ago.

So we ordered the roasted duck over rice, assorted vegetables, beef chow fun and roasted pig. The duck was bleh, a rip off that came only about 6 small pieces over a bowl of rice. The vegetables dish was decent. The beef chow fun was surprisingly good, beside how hard is it to fry chow fun with beef. The roasted pork was alright, I wish it had came more, besides roasted pork are usualy expensive and each dishes were only 5 to 6 bucks each. Can't argue much.

So yeah, either I was really really hungry or the food was just too delicious that we CLEANED up the bowls and plates.

ps: The Chinese kid knows the whats up in Chinatown and listen to him.
author: Rick W.

description:
I love coming here to grab some BBQ Pork and Roasted Pork.  I haven't tried the duck or chicken, but the pork is definitely good stuff.

Since it's off the main streets of Chinatown, it's not nearly as crowded with tourists, but you have to be careful 'cause a lot of locals will fill it up on weekends.

One of these days I've gotta try their actual food 'cause I've only ordered their BBA togo.
author: Jason K.

description:
Everyone crams into this lunch joint b/c it's got some of the juiciest roast duck and pork in Chinatown AND it's unbelievably cheap.  Just keep in mind it's a hole-in-the-wall crammed with scrubby tables and a restroom you should pretend doesn't exist.  Carry anti-bacterial, wipe down your utensils, chow down, then jet!

++ | Roast Duck / Pork |
Order it any way you like (over rice, in soup, half/whole, to-go, etc.), as long as you try some of Kam Po's reknowned roast!  Some people will ask for extra "duck sauce" (au jus) or ginger-garlic paste to taste.

++ | Rice Dishes |
Monstrous heap of rice w/any selection of the standard Cantonese sautés.

-- Noodle soups
Don't order any of the noodles! The soup base is bland and the noodles are grocery store boring.

A filling, quick and dirty lunch = $5/person
author: Christina J.

description: Greasy Chinese food, but good greasy. Maybe even great greasy.  I admit I am biased towards greasy (good) Chinese as it's nostalgic. Definitely come here for their BBQ on rice, but I love it all since it's yummy home cooking to me.  They're small and busy, so you'll likely be sitting at a damp, newly wiped table with strangers.  Out of the way, but worth it.  Cash only. Yelp majority are right once again.
author: Yan E.

description: I only order one thing from here: char-sui won ton mein. LOVE IT.
author: Jocelyn W.

description: Best cheap authentic food I've had here since moving across the country. Cheap, fast and complete hole in the wall.
author: Cindy T.

description:
I'm not sure if Kam Po even has a menu printed in English. They certainly have lots of things written in Chinese taped up in their windows and along their walls.

And I have never eaten INSIDE the restaurant. Always ordered TO GO.

But I do know they've got some of the best damn Roast Duck & Roast Pork in Chinatown because... well... it's hanging right there in the window!

I don't think the fellas with the meat cleavers that work behind the counter speak much English, but we've developed an almost unspoken understanding over the years... all I do is ask for a half order of Roast Duck & Roast Pork over steamed rice, TO GO, and the fellas grab the duck & pork off their respective hooks, place em on the cutting block, and do what I can only describe as... well... *MAGIC* with that meat cleaver!

All this food & the show for just $6? That's one of the best deals in town, my friends.
author: John Eric S.

description:
I'm amazed that I haven't reviewed this place until now, because, really, when it comes to affordable Chinese restaurants you can't get better than big portions + good food + bare basement prices. Whether it's wonton and roast pork noodle soup or a soy sauce chicken rice dish, you get gigantic portions (that to a normal person is two servings, but I tend to eat a lot). That's not all as well, before you get your entree you get a bowl of delicious homemade soup. All that for less than $6 (I wish I could get anything for less than $6 now that I live in DC)

Okay, so the place may not be the most sanitary of places. The tables are pretty cramped and during busy times you'll have to share. And yes, it's cash only (but that's pretty much anywhere in Chinatown anyways). But really, all that is worth it for the lipsmaking goodness coming your way at Kam Po. I'm definitely looking forward to coming back to San Francisco again and eating another delicious meal here.
author: Jon W.

description:
This is one of my favorite hole in the wall restaurants for lunch/dinner in Chinatown.  

The roast pork and peking duck is excellent!  I usually get their special for dinner which is 3 full entree with rice and soup for $18.99!  You cannot beat this price and quality at any other Chinese restaurant.  

Definitely check this place out!
author: Jo S.

description: The best thing here is their roasted duck with the white noodles(don't know what it's called in English, but in Chinese, it's 'Lai Fun'). Mmm. Haven't been here in ages though!
author: Vivian L.

description:
They got 88 out 100 in their health inspection.  I've never got sick from eating this place.  They sell a lot so, there's never any stale food.  All local Chinese customers eat here, not like NanKing where there's only "white" folks (get it?).  

I love the wonton with noodles for $2.55.  23 years ago, it was $2.30, so their prices are super reasonable.  
A bowl of JUST wonton is like eating a bowl of dim sum.  Lots of shrimp in the wonton.   You got to try their wonton it's truely amazing, like dim sum.  It's the cheapest and best wonton, I've had..."Two Kinds o BBQ" is $5.50 which is a lot of meat.  Feel free to share it.

It's not fair to review a restaurant if you havent' eaten their food.  I've been eating in Chinatown for over 30 years and this is a secret hold in the wall.   Yes, the tables are old, but they are clean.  Once in a while the floors are sticky, but they do wash it every night.  Most good, cheap places like this one is CASH ONLY
author: Sunny O.

description:
I came here because they have my name in their name.

Cheap and good.
author: Po L.

description:
I can't believe I'm giving this place 4 stars. Honestly, I'm just going to pretend I've not seen the inside. It isn't clean and for now, I'll live in denial about what the health department has likely said about this place. 

That said, the food always tastes really good and they have some of the best duck ever. Really cheap food with gigantic portions. If you're willing to brave the place to get the food, check it out... even better, send someone else to pick up some take out and live in denial.
author: Anita B.

description: Okay, so maybe I was ordering the wrong thing, or I was setting my expectations too high.  On that note I would give a 2 star rating but feel that it wouldn't be fair to do so since I clearly wasn't having the same experience that other reviewers were having.  I'm glad people have posted their suggestions on what to get because I could've used a few pointers.  I will say this though, their service was really good.  It is a small joint, so if you're coming in during the lunch hour, you might be stuck with a wait.
author: Margaret N.

description: Great place.  Keep with the rice plates - we got Roast Duck and BBQ Pork; great and only $4.75 (including soup).  The butcher is outstanding and the portion sizes are good.  Comes with steamed cabbage and good sauces.  Nice people.  Cash only.
author: Brian C.

description: This place is disgusting. I came here on my lunch break and ordered the roast duck like everyone recommended. It ended up in the trash and made my way over to Golden Boy.
author: Mike S.

description:
I was craving for roasted duck very badly so I went on Yelp and wanted to find a decent roasted duck place and I found Kam Po Kitchen.

This is  a review for a To -Go experience,  my hubby bought me a whole roasted duck and before I open it, i was expected to see crispy skin and juicy meat, but when I open it..oh nooooooooo, the duck is super fatty, there's one big layer of fat below the skin and the skin was soft and I felt like this duck has been sitting more than one day old and it costs $13

I will never go back again.
author: Amy A.

description:
This place is always full! The food is extremely cheap. Five dollars in your pocket? Well that gets you a meal that you could split into lunch AND dinner. I always get the roast duck with rice or the roast pig with rice. I could admit although, I have had better BBQ pork, I don't hate it or anything, I just don't like it. I lived in Chinatown most of my life and I have had WAY better bb pork/ roast pork/ and roast duck but this place does the trick. It is decent food for a very cheap price. I come here at least once a week.

4 stars just because its not all that clean or organized...
author: Nelson Z.

description: Understaffed and super tight seating. We got to know our neighors pretty well there. Be aware incoming guests will stand over you while you wait for your bill or while you are wrapping up your meal. Good bitter melon dishes. The wait staff sometimes screws up orders as we witnessed for the next table.
author: Rrr X.

description: Roast Pork/Roast Duck Combo! $7.45 and well worth it. It's always a bit cheaper when you get just one item alone but as a carnivore, the combo for me is a must. What has me praising this place is the portions and pricing...two things that pair together well when used right. Look past the "greasy spoon" ambience at this place and try it out! You're guaranteed to keep your tummy and your wallet full. Great Food! And for those of you adventerouse eaters...go ahead and try your hand at the pig intestines, or maybe some chicken feet, but the roast pork or duck here is the staple! RECOMMENDED
author: Marcel W.

description: Ill keep this short and sweet. The place looks a little questionable health code wise, but after closer inspection it seems like it might pass. The food on the other hand is undoubtedly fantastic. One of the gems of chinatown here in SF. I live one block away and this place is a consistent stop when wanting inexpensive, yet delicious food. Roast duck, chow mein, and the clay pot menu are the best items, but dont take my word for it. Just give it a try.
author: Emilio B.

description:
I wanted to give this place four stars because it was (have not been there in a long time) the cheapest, nastiest place that you could get good food from.  My criteria for a good place to eat have changed though.  I've seen bums eating in there on occasion but I didn't care.  I just chatted with my friends, ate the food, paid, and left.

The duck can be quite good (4+ star, IMO) but make sure you chose the right one.
author: Jensen L.

description:
Food: Noodles - 4 stars
           Rice plates - 3 stars

I used to come here a lot when I was in my pre-teen years and then every so often when I was in high school. It was cheap and tasted good.

The place itself gets pretty noisy in the busy hours, and the service gets a little slow too, but that's because they have only 2 waiters and it gets really busy around the lunch hour. Cleanliness wise, is just okay. One side there are tables to sit and eat, and there is a small part where you can order to go food.

I was just here in the past weekend, and man have things changed. It used to be that the rice and ho fun tasted pretty decent, but now...We ordered a shrimp chow ho fun, and it was extremely oily, even for chow ho fun, and pretty tasteless. We also ordered a rice with beef and veggies. The beef had a weird taste to it, and the sauce's taste changed too (not sure if it is because they changed the chef or not...). We ate the veggies and some of the rice, but left the beef.

The last dish we ordered was beef tendon noodle soup. This is the one thing that still tastes great. Even after all these years, their noodle soup still taste the same. The soup base was just as tasty as ever, and they gave a large helping of the beef tendon and noodles. I recommend getting the noodle soups (especially the beef ones) because they are a must try.
