I really can't say the same for the rice dishes anymore. 

The place is cheap and the beef noodle soups are to die for.
author: Jay L.

description:
If you take it for what it is, this place is great. The food is incredibly cheap and, for the price, is pretty damn good. I ordered the beef chow fun, which was a bit greasy and slightly lacking in flavor, but for the quantity (huge portions) and at $3.90, I really couldn't complain. They also give you free soup. There was actually a fly in mine, but I wasn't that surprised...and didn't even really care. First, I was way too full from my dish to have any room for soup. Second, I knew I wasn't eating there for the cleanliness, and for the prices, I really couldn't complain. As long as your expectations are in line, this place is actually a fairly decent hole-in-the-wall kind of place.

Also, this place is a lot more crowded during lunchtime than dinner.
author: Willy C.

description:
This place is a small hole in the wall with great food at very good prices!

This place has the best pork with crispy skin, and their Roast Duck is on par with the best in the Bay. As if that's not enough, their prices are awesome for the generous proportions they give you. I always stop by whenever I'm in the area!
author: Donald F.

description:
1) Super cheap (usually $3-$5) 
2) Super big portions 
3) I don't recommend drinking their soup because I found soggy newspapers in my soup once, and it makes me think they just pour whatever other customers don't finish back into the big pot and reserve
4) And because of #3, i don't think this place is necessarily sanitary 
5) Area is small
6) 0 ambiance
7) Rather crowded
8) Sometimes their food isn't all that fresh, i.e. the wontons 
9) I suggest sticking with the rice plates with the chicken, cha sieu, or  roast duck (because those are made fresh) 
10) I come back once in a blue moon
author: Emily L.

description:
I wear a constant grimace the moment I walk onto the streets of Chinatown. My dad parks on Russian Hill (because parking sucks in Chinatown) and the view is gorgeous. I can see Alcatraz to my left and houses sloping down and then up into the distance. The sun is out but it's a windy day in SF and I forget to wear my jacket. I'm in a T-shirt and shorts. I get increasingly angry about my attire as I walk around the overpass onto the sidewalk. I see glimpses into shops as I pass by doorways. One is a dimly lit barber shop and another is the behind the scenes of a butcher shop. I make out a slab of roasted pork lying on a metal countertop. We turn the corner and we walk into Kam Po. Kam Po used to be owned by this man in the 90's who gambled a lot. He had two restaurants and had a hot temper. He used to beat his wife and his mother. (ho ma faun uh!) He lost $200,000+. So he gambled until he had to flee the states (jow low) because people were running after him with butcher knives (pack yau). He also disappeared with a truck load of coveted shark fin, sea cucumber and other expensive Chinese delicacies.
I walk into Kam Po (which really is called Gum bo) and I see my mom at a table so I join her. I'm with my younger brother and mom and dad. My dad talks about the owners and who's working at the restaurant today and who's not. I zone out and observe all of the people in the place. The place is small and I feel very cramped. The table is sticky. The waitress comes over with our cups of tea and our menus. We order. I can see the grime on the laminated menus as she takes them away. There is a red lace curtain that runs along the bottom half of the windows of the place. It serves to just block passersby from seeing you in the restaurant. I can't help but stare at the old lady (ah mo) at the table diagonal to me. She's staring at me too. We have a staring contest and I win. Behind her I see a small closet doorway and men keep walking in and out of there. It's a bathroom. There was a particularly rotund male who had to slip in sideways. I wonder what it smells like in there.
The waitress comes by with one of our four orders, a stack of plates, chopsticks and napkins. My brother takes a plate and inspects the bottom of the plate. My dad tells him that's not a good idea. I grab the cleanest plate and pair of chopsticks. My brother exchanges his set for a new one by walking over to the butcher part of the restaurant and grabbing a pair from a mass of red chopsticks. I try our first plate and it's pretty darn tasty. Our second plate comes and my dad says, "Doesn't this look great (jang!)." In my head I think, "no, actually it looks like throw up." I eat it and it is pretty good despite what it looks like. Do health inspectors come to Chinatown?
To my right, a well dressed teenage couple is ordering food. After they order a gay couple sits down next to their table. One of the two males is white, so the waitress comes to take their order and I hear her say, "die coke, roas pok mmhmm...vally vally good."
author: Louisa L.

description:
day 6

solid 3 star review. i came here cuz my eating compatriots said you aint a true yelper foodie unless you eat chinese food at a place that has dead ducks hanging in the window. whatevs. panda express never had hanging ducks and i been completely happy. dude my feet are hurting, i said lets go to the closest ones but no way, these chicks wanted hanging ducks. dude i dont know what crimes the ducks committed but i dont want to see them hanged and walk 4 blocks to see it. im a daffy and donald fan for life!

we were 3 koreans and 1 chinese kid who looks filipino. we ordered yet my favorite dish was the one the chinese kid ordered. let koreans order at korean place and chinese order at chinese places. 

chow fun? fun but not the best. the duck? pretty good. the veggie plate? ew. the crispy suckling pork that the c-kid ordered? dang its like a slap to the face. i was mad he held out on good chinese dishes on me all these years and let me eat panda all this time. the crispy pork was good. 

panda, add it to the ala carte!
author: Sam Y.

description: Good take-out Chinese food.  Anytime I feel lazy and don't feel like cooking dinner, I order food to go here.  Prices are insanely cheap for the amount of food they give you.  This is not the cleanest place to eat at and you may have to share a table sometimes.  But hey this is Chinatown, and sharing a table is the norm, so get cozy!  The waitresses work their butt off here so give them some slack.  The butcher that cuts up the meat for you in the bbq section is hella funny.  He's always trying to make you buy more than you need.  So you gotta be tough with this guy.
author: Lucky M.

description: I have struggled to find good Chinese food in SF and this place is authentic, delicious, and a great great value.  Food: YUUUUMMM.  The noodle dishes are really good (singaporean noodles and chow mein).  The roast duck and rice dish is huge and always good.  The people in there eating are legit Chinese ppl.  You may not like the ambience (it is Chinatown) and just know if you sit by yourself they like to do it family style so some person(s) may just sit with you.  But don't worry, they really don't talk to you.  You get these HUGE portions and each dish is from under $4 to less than $7.  This stuff is GOOD.
author: Deal G.

description:
every time I hear the term "dirty hole in the wall", I think of Kam Po Kitchen immediately. the place would probably not pass well with the health rating but what I don't see, I don't care. if you want a quick good bite with the best deal in Chinatown....here it is. no frills and not the best Chinese place to give off any great impressions to first timers.

I've been a regular here since I was a kid growing up in the area (in fact, my family first moved into an apt. upstairs when we first immigrated to the States). my mom reminds me these days "only $3 for a bowl of noodle with EIGHT wonton!" that is a bargain you can't find elsewhere.

* if getting the soup noodles to go, ask for the soup in a seperate container so you don't end up with soggy noodles.
author: Katie K.

description:
This is my all time BEST place for Chinese food in the city for three reasons - 1)great food, 2)huge portions, and 3)CHEAP PRICES.

Be forewarned, it is impossible to get a table between noon and 1:00 so either plan your lunchtime meal for 11:00 or after 1:30, it's that popular.

The decor is a step up from a hole in the wall but the food speaks for itself.
author: John C.

description:
I have been buying meat (hanged on the rack) from this place a few times a year for a couple of years. Quality is ok. I like it mainly because it is easier to find parking on this part of Chinatown. When I buy I usually bring the exact amount, so that I don't get any change back from the person who chops up the meat -  the change money is always mixed with grease.
About two months ago about one hour from closing, I bought a $6 soy sauce chicken (this is the small size type, cheaper). Got home, open the box, right away I could smell the spoiled odor. Got back to my car, drove back there, looked for parking again, knocked on the door (they closed already) they did not examine the content of my returned box but gave me my refund! From my experience,  the person who chopped up the chicken (I think he is the owner?) should know that it was spoiled because as he chopped it up, he should smelled the bad odor.
Yesterday, I bought another $6 chicken during lunch time (should be pretty fresh at this time of day). Went home and found chicken meat to be rubbery and skin so chewy that I cannot break any skin in the box. Believe me, I have good teeth. I was eating that chicken with a friend (who specifically wanted soy sauce chicken for dinner) at home and it was extremely embarrassing. And frustrated again because the same guy who chopped up the meat should know it was very chewy (from the feel of the knife gets into the chicken). I did not go back to ask for a refund. I think I want to calm down for a few months to ease my blood pressure then see... 
My family has been in the restaurant business in the East Bay for twenty years. One of the restaurants we had owned, was a Chinese BBQ restaurant like Kam Po! So I had worked in a BBQ restaurant before. 
For irresponsible business ethics, one star.
author: Adrian A.

description: Wow, the char siu and roast duck over rice that we just ate was humongous ... LEAN duck, what's the secret?  Unlike Cheung Hing's and a few others I could mention, Kam Po's really got the roast duck down to lucious, lean duckie goodness ... it's like when you get a hunk of  crab claw meat on your Swan Oyster Depot salad and you get a nice mouthful of pure "MEAT" and it's culinary oral orgasm ... *satisfied smile* then gourmand after glow ... This was actually the 2nd day in a row I stopped by for roast duck on rice with roast pork for variety ... parking is such a bee-ach and those hot foods on display in the front are rather beckoning but it's pretty much a HK barbecue charcuterie to go for me ... as far as dining in goes, well yeah, decor leaves a lot to be desired but the prices offset that demerit so it's still one of those San Francisco treasures and the place to grab roast ducks, copious portions of roast pork, char siu, roast and boiled chickens, etc.  Heard those used to have roast goose and now I have kind of a hankering for that ... last time I had it was in Dong Guan and it was memorably good ... Kam Po Kitchen, the food's a steal, real deal and you will feel duck satiatied in the best of ways ...
author: Terry A.

description: Ive been going here since i was 9 years old when it was at their old location, which i guess is about 20 years.  they have had numerous owner and I think they finally have an owner that cares about cleaniness.  It stopped smelling like bleach.  their chinese bbq are the great.  I love their roast duck.  and their food is soooo cheap... they give you so much food, its insane!
author: Janet S.

description: the cheapest chinese restaurant in SF!!!  Ordered the beef chow fun, wonton soup with like 12 pieces of wonton and bbq pork rice plate.  The bill was $10.35.  What other places can beat that!  The place is small and can be dirty, just like any AUTHENTIC, typical chinese restaurant is.  But if you're use to little hole in the wall type of chinese restaurant and finding good food is the primary reason, then you gotta give this place a try.
author: Heidi F.

description:
The first time I came to Kam Po h.k.k. (I pretend it stands for Hong Kong Kapaow) I pushed aside the fork in favor of chopsticks which happen to be a far superior eating utensil. I'm not sure if chopsticks are usual fare for non-Chinese people eating in Chinatown, then again I'm not sure if many non-Chinese people eat in Chinatown or H.K.K. for that matter but either way the lady that serves food here seemed quite amused. Since then she has been very friendly, gives me free tea, and always makes it a point to give me chopsticks.

Anyway, the food here is the best, the best Chinese food ever in fact. Try anything that contains the BBQ Pork. I like it in the wonton soup or the China green chow-mien or even just plain by itself. The soy sauce chicken is also delicious as is pretty much anything on the menu. And you know it's fresh because they pull it straight out of the window. Oh and make sure you look at the menu you can hold in your hand rather then the menu on the window because it has more food choices on it.

If I could give a bonus star for every inch of hair that's growing out of the face mole of the meat-chopper guy, I would.
author: will s.

description: Well, it is what it is. Hence, the low prices. I don't really care that much because I'm used to these places. I wouldn't call anything healthy, but I'm just lunching, so I really don't ask for too much. There are very few places these days where you can get a decent Chinese meal for 3-4 bucks. (I'm Chinese, so I know.)
author: Alex Y.

description:
Made the trek to SF from the south bay a few days ago and went here for some food.

Like everyone said, this place has a lot of food for CHEAP CHEAP CHEAP, don't come here with huge expectations. The 3 of us ordered separate dishes that were all ~$4 each, but getting 2 dishes would've probably filled us all up.

The food was probably loaded with msg because i got so thirsty later that night.

A little thing i noticed was that this place is pretty small so people would end up sitting in a table with some other random person which was a bit amusing.
author: Daniel N.

description: Ordered #1 roasted pork with rice (how can you go wrong right? WRONG.). They give you the cheapest/dryest cut. Portions were huge but did not make up the quality of the pork. My advice would be eat at kin tin restraunt down at washington. Way better quality cuts but a little more expensive. 2 stars for portion size and price.
author: Jimmy C.

description:
This restaurant is the very definition of good, authentic, cheap Chinese food. I love the noodle soups but the full panoply of fast Cantonese rice and noodle dishes is available. Any dish with the BBQ meats that are on display up front will be a tasty bargain - roast pork (crispy skin), BBQ pork (that's cha siu), and roast duck are the three main ones.

The lady who seems to be there all the time is amazing - she doesn't need to write down your order and she always gets it right. She has amazing energy to keep going at all times of the day. She's my hero.

There's an English menu, but there's also Chinese language signs on the walls. I can read Chinese, but I've  never ordered the Chinese-only dishes - just because they feature things like frog and bitter melon that I really don't like anyway. If you want to be adventurous, tell her you want to try one of them - it won't cost much!

The place is small and the bare tables are packed in together with little elbow room. But that's part of the appeal, for me. No pretension, no creature comforts - just delicious cheap food.
author: Oh G.

description: I was tempted to give this place 4 stars because of the decor, which is obviously a pretty old, no-frills  chinese restaurant.  However, this place is worth 5 stars in my opinion because the food is really the best deal in town.  I am able to get lunch/dinner for less than $5.  My orders to go are served promptly.....one of my favorite places in chinatown!
author: Andrew G.

description: All I got was the roast duck and the BBQ pork, and both were good.  The duck was most likely fresh as it was a nice combination of fatty and crispy.  BBQ pork was about as good as I would expect from a BBQ place like this, nothing super extraordinary.  This is a hole in the wall type of joint where you can expect cheap food that has good quality.  Caveat: I have never actually gone into the restaurant (just dropped off people to pick up the duck), but I think this is probably the best way to go so that you can avoid both the hellish parking in the Chinatown area as well as the crowded restaurant.  The roast pork looked good even from my car in the street so I am looking forward to going back to try that.
author: Mike Y.

description: So my girlfriend who is white was wanting Chinese food.  And I being Vietnamese and eating authentic food,( Panda Express is good but like saying Taco Bell is Mexican food), decided to get some roast duck.  If it isn't hanging in the window you really have to wonder right?!  But needless to say Kam Po is DELICIOUS!  I usually get the Roast Duck Won Ton Noodle.  You get a bunch of duck.  A bunch.  And it is tasty and filling and all for under $5.  Then to go I get the rice, Roast Duck, and BBQ pork.  Its like getting 2 meals.  Lots of meat, great value and its quick.  Going there is ok but the people who work there are not so english speaking.  But then the food makes it worth it.  My girlfriend and I ate there 3 times in three days before.  The beef and broccoli chow mein with the chinese broccoli is fantastic.  During lunch hours you see a wide variety of people stopping off to get food to go.  And its worth it.
author: Jerry V.

description: Heyy Mel! how ya doin? (inside joke) i really don't like this place. actually, i dont think the place likes me. HAHA
author: Jasmine T.

description: this is the diritest, cheapest chinese place in all of california. with that being said, the food is quite good and honestly, to walk out 5 bucks eating all the different variety of chinese food you've ever wanted? its insane. i rmember i went with two people and we walked out under 10 bucks. and we were all full and happy. and peopel complain about roast duck over rice bla bla. then just order one to go. u get the whole thing, AND its cheap. can't beat the price man. i guess im just cheap. but thats why it gets 5 stars.
author: Rick L.

description: don't go here for atmosphere - unless the atmosphere you desire is an authentic chinese cafe.  the denizens of chinatown dine here, i do too!  it's always full of pensioners getting very good food for very reasonable (even cheap) prices.  we usually get noodle dishes here which are generous - especially the black bean beef chow fun.  the bbq pork is a tasty treat to bring home for snacking or a late meal.
author: Chris D.
